title: ~거든요 [geodeunyo] (You see; Explaining)
short_explanation: Used for explaining or giving background information to the listener.
long_explanation: '~거든요 [geodeunyo]' is a grammar point used in Korean when the speaker wants to provide additional information or background to the listener, usually as an explanation or justification. It is common in spoken language and indicates that the speaker believes the listener may not know or might be surprised by this information.

examples.kr: 저는 오래전에 학교를 다녔거든요, 그래서 현재 교육 시스템이 어떻게 바뀌었는지 잘 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun oraejeone hakgyoreul danyeotgeodeunyo, geuraeseo hyeonjae gyoyuk siseutemi eotteoke bakkwinji jal moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: You see, I attended school a long time ago, so I don't really know how the current educational system has changed.

examples.kr: 제가 지각한 것은 버스가 늦었거든요, 그래서 시간을 맞추지 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Jega jigakhan geoseun beoseuga neujeotgeodeunyo, geuraeseo siganeul matchuji mothaesseoyo.
examples.en: The reason I was late is because the bus was delayed, so I couldn't make it on time.

examples.kr: 저는 커피를 마시지 않아요. 커피에 카페인이 많이 들어있거든요, 그래서 잠을 잘 못 자요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun keopireul masiji anhayo. Keopie kapeini mani deureoitgeodeunyo, geuraeseo jameul jal mot jayo.
examples.en: I don't drink coffee. You see, coffee contains a lot of caffeine, so I can't sleep well.

examples.kr: 하루 종일 집에 있어서 지루해요. 날씨가 너무 춥거든요, 그래서 밖에 나갈 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: Haru jongil jibe isseoseo jiruhaeyo. Nalssiga neomu chupgeodeunyo, geuraeseo bakke nagal su eopseoyo.
examples.en: I'm bored staying in the house all day. You see, it's really cold outside, so I can't go out.

title: ~게 되다 [ge dweda] (End up doing)
short_explanation: Used to express an action or state that ends up happening due to certain circumstances or changes.
long_explanation: '~게 되다 [ge dweda]' is used when an action or situation comes about because of a certain circumstance or influence, often unexpectedly or unintentionally. It often implies a change from an initial plan or a passive result of external factors.

examples.kr: 저는 공부에 집중하다가 잠이 들게 되었어요. 참 기분이 이상해요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun gongbue jipjunghadaga jami deul-ge doeeosseoyo. Cham gibuni isanghaeyo.
examples.en: I ended up falling asleep while concentrating on my studies. It feels weird.

examples.kr: 처음에는 일주일 동안 한국어를 배우려고 했는데, 나중에는 한 달 동안 배우게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Cheoeumeneun ilju-il dongan hangugeoreul baeuryeogo haetneunde, najungeneun han dal dongan baeuge doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: At first, I planned to learn Korean for just a week, but in the end, I ended up studying it for a month.

examples.kr: 우리는 원래 여름에 결혼하려고 했지만, 결국 겨울에 결혼하게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun wonrae yeoreume gyeolhonharyeogo haetjiman, gyeolguk gyeoure gyeolhonhage doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: We originally intended to get married in the summer, but we ended up having the wedding in the winter.

examples.kr: 처음에는 회사에서 너무 많이 일하게 되었어요, 그래서 가족을 자주 볼 수가 없었어요.
examples.romaji: Cheoeumeneun hoesaeseo neomu mani ilhage doeeosseoyo, geuraeseo gajogeul jaju bol suga eopseosseoyo.
examples.en: At first, I ended up working too much at the company, so I couldn't see my family often.

title: ~게 하다 [ge hada] (Make/let someone do)
short_explanation: Used to express that someone causes or allows another person to do something.
long_explanation: '~게 하다' indicates that an action occurs because someone made, let, allowed, or caused it to happen. It can show compulsion, permission, encouragement, etc., depending on context.

examples.kr: 세탁기 가격이 너무 비싸서 가게 주인이 저에게 할인을 해 주어서 사게 해주었어요.
examples.romaji: Setakgi gakyegi neomu bissaseo gage juini jeoege halineul hae jueoseo sage haeju-eosseoyo.
examples.en: The washing machine was so expensive that the store owner gave me a discount and made it possible for me to buy it.

examples.kr: 그녀는 저를 기쁘게 해서 더욱 열심히 활동하게 했습니다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun jeoreul gippeuge haeseo deouk yeolsimhi hwaldonghage haetseumnida.
examples.en: She made me happy and motivated me to be more active.

examples.kr: 어머니는 제가 영어를 배울 수 있도록 도서관에 데려가 주셨어요.
examples.romaji: Eomeonineun jega yeongeoreul baeul su itdorok doseogwane deryeoga jusyeosseoyo.
examples.en: My mother took me to the library so that I could learn English.

examples.kr: 우리 팀원들은 저를 승진하게 하는 데 도움을 주었습니다.
examples.romaji: Uri tim-wondeureun jeoreul seungjinhage haneun de doumeul ju-eosseumnida.
examples.en: Our team members helped me get promoted.

title: ~게 해서는 안 되다 [ge haeseoneun an dweda] (Shouldn't make/let someone do)
short_explanation: Used to convey that one shouldn’t make or allow someone to do something.
long_explanation: '~게 해서는 안 되다' expresses the idea that it is wrong or not allowed to make or let someone do a certain action. It often implies an admonition or rule for proper conduct.
formation: Verb stem + 게 해서는 안 되다

examples.kr: 자기 시험에만 집중하게 해서는 안 돼요. 다른 사람들의 공부도 신경 써야 해요.
examples.romaji: Jagi siheomeman jipjunghage haeseoneun an dwaeyo. Dareun saramdeurui gongbudo singyeong sseoya haeyo.
examples.en: You shouldn't make them focus only on their own tests. They should also care about others' studies.

examples.kr: 계획을 먼저 확인하지 않고 진행하게 해서는 안 됩니다.
examples.romaji: Gyehoeg-eul meonjeo hwaginhaji anko jinhaenghage haeseoneun an doemnida.
examples.en: You shouldn't let it proceed without checking the plan first.

examples.kr: 어린이들을 TV 시청만 하게 해서는 안 됩니다. 독서 등 다른 활동도 필요해요.
examples.romaji: Eorinideureul TV sicheongman hage haeseoneun an doemnida. Dokseo deung dareun hwaldongdo pillyohaeyo.
examples.en: You shouldn't just let children watch TV. They need other activities like reading as well.

examples.kr: 고객을 오래 기다리게 해서는 안 됩니다. 서비스가 빨라야 해요.
examples.romaji: Gogaegeul orae gidarige haeseoneun an doemnida. Seobiseuga pparaya haeyo.
examples.en: You shouldn't make customers wait for a long time. The service should be quick.

title: 겠다 [getda] (will, guess, hope, wish)
short_explanation: A verb ending used to express ‘will’ (future), ‘guess’ (conjecture), or a strong wish or hope.
long_explanation: '겠다 [getda]' is a versatile verb ending in Korean that can express the speaker’s future intention (‘will’), their inference or guess (‘must be…’ / ‘probably’), or a strong desire/wish depending on context. It often appears with first-person statements or in concluding inferences.

examples.kr: 오늘 밤에는 비가 오겠어요. 구름이 짙고 어두워 보여요.
examples.romaji: Oneul bamenen biga ogesseoyo. Gureumi jitgo eoduweo boyeoyo.
examples.en: It will probably rain tonight. The clouds look thick and dark.

examples.kr: 그분이 저한테 화를 내시겠네요. 제가 지시를 따르지 않았거든요.
examples.romaji: Geubuni jeohante hwareul naesigesseyo. Jega jisireul ttareuji anhassgeodeunyo.
examples.en: He will probably get angry with me because I didn’t follow his instructions.

examples.kr: 이 책을 다 읽으면 한국어를 더 잘 알게 되겠어요. 새로운 단어나 문법이 많이 들어 있어요.
examples.romaji: I chaegeul da ilgeumyeon hangugeoreul deo jal alge doegesseoyo. Saeroun daneona munbeopi mani deureo isseoyo.
examples.en: I guess I'll know Korean better once I finish this book. It has a lot of new vocabulary and grammar points.

examples.kr: 다음 주가 되면 저는 새로운 스포츠 클럽에 가입하겠어요. 뭔가 새로운 활동을 시작하고 싶거든요.
examples.romaji: Daum ju-ga doemyeon jeoneun saeroun seupocheu keullebe gaiphagesseoyo. Mwonga saeroun hwaldongeul sijakhago sipgeodeunyo.
examples.en: When next week comes, I will join a new sports club. I want to start something new.

title: ~고 말다 [go malda] (Ended up doing)
short_explanation: Emphasizes an unexpected or often undesirable result: ‘ended up doing.’
long_explanation: '~고 말다 [go malda]' highlights that an action concluded in a certain way, often with a sense of regret, inevitability, or simply an unexpected final outcome. It can be translated as ‘ended up …ing’ or ‘finally ….’

examples.kr: 오랜 시간을 기다렸는데, 결국 혼자 먹고 말았어요. 친구들이 오지 않았거든요.
examples.romaji: Oraen siganeul gidaryeotneunde, gyeolguk honja meokgo marasseoyo. Chingudeuri oji anhassgeodeunyo.
examples.en: I waited for a long time but ended up eating alone since my friends didn’t come.

examples.kr: 제가 어제 너무 늦게 잠드는 바람에 결국 지각하고 말았어요.
examples.romaji: Jega eoje neomu neutge jamdeuneun barame gyeolguk jigakago marasseoyo.
examples.en: Because I went to sleep so late yesterday, I ended up being late.

examples.kr: 그는 공부를 계속 미루다가 결국 시험에서 떨어지고 말았어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun gongbureul gyesok mirudaga gyeolguk siheomeseo tteoreojigo marasseoyo.
examples.en: He kept putting off studying and in the end, he failed the exam.

examples.kr: 열심히 달렸지만 결국 첫 번째 자리를 얻지 못하고 말았어요.
examples.romaji: Yeolsimhi dallyeotjiman gyeolguk cheot beonjjae jarireul eotji mothago marasseoyo.
examples.en: I ran really hard, but in the end, I didn’t get first place.

title: ~고 보니 [go boni] (After doing, I noticed)
short_explanation: Expresses that a realization or discovery is made after doing something.
long_explanation: The form '~고 보니' is used when one notices or realizes something new after completing an action. It often implies that the speaker did not expect this outcome before the action was done.

examples.kr: 그림을 다 그리고 보니 정말 재미있었어요.
examples.romaji: Geurimeul da geurigo boni jeongmal jaemiisseosseoyo.
examples.en: After finishing the drawing, I realized it was really fun.

examples.kr: 고향에 돌아가고 보니 옛날 추억이 많이 떠올랐어요.
examples.romaji: Gohyange doragago boni yetnal chu-eogi manhi tteoollasseoyo.
examples.en: After going back to my hometown, a lot of old memories came to mind.

examples.kr: 친구와 이별하고 보니 그의 소중함을 더 크게 느꼈어요.
examples.romaji: Chinguwa ibyeolhago boni geuui sojunghameul deo keuge neukkyeosseoyo.
examples.en: After parting ways with my friend, I realized even more how precious he was.

examples.kr: 책을 다 읽고 보니 배울 점이 정말 많았어요.
examples.romaji: Chaeg-eul da ilggo boni baeul jeomi jeongmal manasseoyo.
examples.en: After I finished reading the book, I realized there was a lot to learn.

title: ~고 싶다 [go sipda] (Want to)
short_explanation: Used to express a desire or wish to do something.
long_explanation: '~고 싶다 [go sipda]' is used to indicate that the speaker (or someone) wants to do something. It can be softened to express one’s own wishes or used to ask politely about someone else’s wishes.

examples.kr: 저는 한국어를 배우고 싶어요. 그래서 매일 공부하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangugeoreul baeugo sipeoyo. Geuraeseo maeil gongbuhago isseoyo.
examples.en: I want to learn Korean, so I study every day.

examples.kr: 친구가 내일 영화를 보고 싶다고 해서 표를 사려고 해요.
examples.romaji: Chinguga naeil yeonghwareul bogo sipdago haeseo pyoreul saryeogo haeyo.
examples.en: My friend said she wants to see a movie tomorrow, so I'm going to buy tickets.

examples.kr: 오늘 밤에는 집에 가고 싶지 않아서 친구 집에서 묵을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Oneul bamenen jibe gago sipji anhaseo chingu jibeseo mugeul geoyeyo.
examples.en: I don’t want to go home tonight, so I’m going to stay at my friend’s house.

examples.kr: 요리를 배우고 싶어서 요리 학교에 가고 싶었어요.
examples.romaji: Yorireul baeugo sipeoseo yori hakgyoe gago sipeosseoyo.
examples.en: I wanted to learn cooking, so I wanted to go to a cooking school.

title: ~고 있다 [go itda] (In the process of doing)
short_explanation: Used to express an ongoing action or a continuing state.
long_explanation: '~고 있다 [go itda]' corresponds roughly to the present progressive in English (e.g., 'am doing'), but can also show a continued state (e.g., 'am wearing' something).

examples.kr: 그녀는 햇빛 아래에서 책을 읽고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun haetbit araeseo chaegeul ilggo isseoyo.
examples.en: She is reading a book under the sunlight.

examples.kr: 꽃들이 바람에 흔들리고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Kkotdeuri barame heundeulligo isseoyo.
examples.en: The flowers are swaying in the wind.

examples.kr: 그는 올해 내내 스트레스를 받고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun olhae naenae seuteureseureul batgo isseoyo.
examples.en: He has been under stress all year.

examples.kr: 우리 아버지는 지금 유럽을 여행하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Uri abeoji-neun jigeum yureobeul yeohaenghago isseoyo.
examples.en: My father is currently traveling around Europe.

title: ~고자 하다 [goja hada] (In order to)
short_explanation: A more formal/official way to express intention or purpose: ‘in order to,’ ‘for the purpose of.’
long_explanation: '~고자 하다 [goja hada]' is typically used in more formal contexts to express the speaker’s intention or plan to do something, similar to ‘in order to’ in English. It often appears in written or official discourse.
formation: Verb stem + 고자 하다 (often ~고자 + main verb in formal sentences)

examples.kr: 저는 한국어 실력을 향상시키고자 매일 한국 드라마를 보고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangugeo sillyeogeul hyangsangsikigoja maeil hanguk deuramareul bogo isseoyo.
examples.en: In order to improve my Korean skills, I watch Korean dramas every day.

examples.kr: 당신의 건강을 돌보고자 아침마다 일찍 일어나서 운동을 하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Dangsinui geongangeul dolbogoja achimmada iljjik ireonaseo undongeul hago isseoyo.
examples.en: In order to take care of your health, you should get up early every morning and exercise.

examples.kr: 기업의 환경 보호를 이행하고자 제품의 친환경 포장을 도입했습니다.
examples.romaji: Gieobui hwangyeong bohoreul ihaenghagoja jepumui chin-hwangyeong pojangeul doiphaetseumnida.
examples.en: In order to fulfill the company's environmental protection efforts, they introduced eco-friendly packaging.

examples.kr: 그녀는 진정한 행복을 찾고자 먼 나라로 여행을 떠났어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun jinjeonghan haengbokeul chatgoja meon nararo yeohaengeul tteonasseoyo.
examples.en: In order to find true happiness, she traveled to a far-off country.

title: ~곤 하다 [gon hada] (Often do)
short_explanation: Used to express the repetition or frequency of an action or state.
long_explanation: '~곤 하다 [gon hada]' is a pattern used in Korean to convey habitual or repeated actions. It attaches to action verbs to suggest that something happens repeatedly or as a habit. It generally reflects a recurring behavior, often in both the past and present.
formation: Verb stem + 곤 하다 (commonly used as '~곤 해요', '~곤 했어요', etc.)

examples.kr: 나는 마음이 힘들 때 종종 책을 읽곤 해요. 그러면 그리운 마음을 달래곤 해요.
examples.romaji: Naneun maeumi himdeul ttae jongjong chaegeul ilkkon haeyo. Geureomyeon geuliun maeumeul dallaegon haeyo.
examples.en: I often read books when I feel down. Doing that often soothes my longing heart.

examples.kr: 아침에 일어나면 항상 창문을 열곤 해요. 신선한 공기를 맞이하곤 해요.
examples.romaji: Achime ileonamyeon hangsang changmuneul yeolgon haeyo. Sinseonhan gonggireul majihagon haeyo.
examples.en: When I wake up in the morning, I often open the window. I often greet the fresh air.

examples.kr: 그녀는 새로운 레시피를 발견하면 자주 시도하곤 해요. 그래서 항상 새로운 요리를 만들곤 해요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun saeroun resipireul balgyeonhamyeon jaju sidohagon haeyo. Geuraeseo hangsang saeroun yorireul mandeulgon haeyo.
examples.en: Whenever she discovers a new recipe, she often tries it out, so she often ends up cooking new dishes.

examples.kr: 저는 운동 후에 항상 스트레칭을 하곤 해요. 그러면 근육이 뻣뻣해지는 것을 방지하곤 해요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun undong hue hangsang seuteurechingeul hagon haeyo. Geureomyeon geunyugi ppeotppeothaejineun geoseul bangjihagon haeyo.
examples.en: I often do stretching after exercising. That way, I often prevent my muscles from getting stiff.

title: ~기도 하다 [gido hada] (Sometimes do)
short_explanation: Expresses that an action is done occasionally or sometimes.
long_explanation: '~기도 하다 [gido hada]' is used to indicate that someone sometimes (not always) does a certain action. It can also be used to emphasize that there are multiple actions: one does A and sometimes B, too. The '도' particle shows this sense of 'also' or 'too.'

examples.kr: 저는 보통 축구를 보지만, 때때로 야구를 보기도 해요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun botong chuggureul bojiman, ttaettaero yagureul bogido haeyo.
examples.en: I usually watch soccer, but sometimes I also watch baseball.

examples.kr: 그녀는 요리를 잘하지만, 그럼에도 불구하고 배울 것이 많아서 요리 수업에 가기도 해요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun yorireul jalhajiman, geureomedo bulguhago baewul geosi manaseo yori sueobe gagido haeyo.
examples.en: Even though she cooks well, she still has a lot to learn, so she sometimes goes to cooking classes.

examples.kr: 우리는 주로 산을 등반하는데, 가끔 강가에서 피크닉을 즐기기도 해요.
examples.romaji: Urineun juro saneul deungbanhaneunde, gakkeum ganggaeseo pikeunik-eul jeulgigido haeyo.
examples.en: We usually go hiking in the mountains, but occasionally we enjoy picnics by the river.

examples.kr: 제가 보통 이른 아침에 일어나지만, 때로는 늦잠을 자기도 해요.
examples.romaji: Jega botong ireun achime ileonajiman, ttaeroneun neutjameul jagido haeyo.
examples.en: I usually wake up early in the morning, but sometimes I sleep in.

title: ~기로 [giro] (Decided to)
short_explanation: Indicates a decision or agreement to do something.
long_explanation: The '~기로 [giro]' construction is used to express that a decision or promise has been made to do something. It often appears as '~기로 하다', '~기로 결정하다', or '~기로 약속하다' to emphasize that a firm plan or promise is in place.
formation: Verb stem + 기로 (often followed by 하다/결정하다/약속하다)

examples.kr: 그녀는 다음 주에 시험을 보기로 결정했어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun daeum jue siheomeul bogiro gyeoljeonghaesseoyo.
examples.en: She decided to take the test next week.

examples.kr: 나는 내일 친구들과 영화를 보기로 약속했어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun naeil chingudeulgwa yeonghwareul bogiro yaksokhaesseoyo.
examples.en: I promised to watch a movie with my friends tomorrow.

examples.kr: 우리 부모님은 내년에 새 집으로 이사하기로 결정했어요.
examples.romaji: Uri bumonimeun naenyeone sae jib-euro isagiro gyeoljeonghaesseoyo.
examples.en: My parents have decided to move to a new house next year.

examples.kr: 우리는 다음 회의에서 이 문제를 논의하기로 했어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun daeum hoeuiese o i munjereul nonuihagiro haesseoyo.
examples.en: We decided to discuss this issue at the next meeting.

title: ~기로 되다 [giro dweda] (It's decided to)
short_explanation: Expresses that something has been decided or arranged.
long_explanation: '~기로 되다 [giro dweda]' is used when you want to indicate that some plan or arrangement has been set, often by an external decision or mutual agreement. It often translates to 'It has been decided that...' or 'It's arranged that...'

examples.kr: 회사에서 월요일에 회의하기로 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Hoesaeseo woryoil-e hoeuihagiro doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: It has been decided that we will have a meeting on Monday at the company.

examples.kr: 우리는 내일 오후 3시에 만나기로 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun naeil ohu sam si-e mannagiro doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: It's been decided that we will meet at 3 p.m. tomorrow.

examples.kr: 그녀와의 결혼은 내년에 하기로 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeowa-ui gyeolhoneun naenyeon-e hagiro doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: It's been decided that we will get married next year.

examples.kr: 다음 주에 친구들과 여행 가기로 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Daeum jue chingudeulgwa yeohaeng gagiro doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: It's been decided that we’ll go on a trip with friends next week.

title: ~기로 하다 [giro hada] (Decide to)
short_explanation: Used to say that one decides or agrees to do something.
long_explanation: '~기로 하다' is a common way to say 'decide to...' in Korean. It highlights that a resolution or plan has been set for some future action. It is also used for promises or mutual agreements (e.g., with friends or family).

examples.kr: 우리는 다음 주에 여행 가기로 했어요. 날씨가 좋으면 바다로 갈까 해요.
examples.romaji: Urineun daeum jue yeohaeng gagiro haesseoyo. Nalssiga joeumyeon badaro galkka haeyo.
examples.en: We decided to go on a trip next week. If the weather is good, we might go to the beach.

examples.kr: 나는 내일 헬스장에 가기로 했어요. 운동을 시작해서 건강해지기로 했어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun naeil helseujange gagiro haesseoyo. Undongeul sijakhaeseo geonganghaejigiro haesseoyo.
examples.en: I decided to go to the gym tomorrow. I decided to start exercising and become healthier.

examples.kr: 서윤은 미래에 스스로 직장을 갖기로 했습니다.
examples.romaji: Seo Yuneun mirae-e seuseuro jigjangeul gatgiro haessseumnida.
examples.en: Seo Yoon decided to have her own job in the future.

examples.kr: 우리 그룹은 사업 확장을 위해 더 많은 직원을 고용하기로 결정했습니다.
examples.romaji: Uri geurubeun saeop hwagjangeul wihae deo maneun jigweoneul goyonghagiro gyeoljeonghaessseumnida.
examples.en: Our group decided to hire more employees for business expansion.

title: ~기 시작하다 [gi sijakhada] (Begin to)
short_explanation: Used to express the start or beginning of an action.
long_explanation: '~기 시작하다 [gi sijakhada]' indicates that an action has just begun (or will soon begin). It is the rough equivalent of 'to start doing' or 'to begin to do' in English.

examples.kr: 그녀는 다섯 살 때 피아노를 치기 시작했어요. 그래서 지금은 피아노를 정말 잘 칩니다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun daseot sal ttae pianoreul chigi sijakhaesseoyo. Geuraeseo jigeumeun pianoreul jeongmal jal chimnida.
examples.en: She began to play the piano at the age of five, so now she plays really well.

examples.kr: 나는 아침에 일어나자마자 커피를 마시기 시작했어요. 커피 없이는 하루를 시작할 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun achime ireonajamaja keopireul masigi sijakhaesseoyo. Keopi eopsineun harureul sijakhal su eopseoyo.
examples.en: I begin to drink coffee as soon as I wake up in the morning. I can't start the day without coffee.

examples.kr: 우리는 처음 회의를 시작할 때부터 심각한 문제에 대해 이야기하기 시작했어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun cheoeum hoeuireul sijakhal ttaebuteo simgakhan munje-e daehae iyagihagi sijakhaesseoyo.
examples.en: We began to talk about serious issues right from the start of the meeting.

examples.kr: 저는 한국어를 배우기 시작한 지 1년이 지났는데, 아직도 배울 게 많아요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangugeoreul baeugi sijakhan ji ilnyeoni jinannende, ajikdo baeul ge manayo.
examples.en: It has been a year since I started learning Korean, and I still have a lot to learn.

title: ~기 위해서 [gi wihaeseo] (In order to)
short_explanation: Used to express the purpose or reason for doing something.
long_explanation: '~기 위해서 [gi wihaeseo]' means 'in order to' or 'for the purpose of.' When attached to a verb in the '~기' nominal form, it denotes the reason or purpose for taking a particular action. It is common in both spoken and written Korean when describing why someone is doing something (especially future or ongoing actions).

examples.kr: 영어를 잘하게 되기 위해서 매일 아침에 영어 듣기 연습을 하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Yeongeoreul jalhage doegi wihaeseo maeil achime yeong-eo deudgi yeonseubeul hago isseoyo.
examples.en: In order to become good at English, I practice listening every morning.

examples.kr: 운동선수가 되기 위해서 학교가 끝난 후에 항상 훈련에 참여해요.
examples.romaji: Undongseonsuga doegi wihaeseo hakgyoga kkeutnan hue hangsang hunryeone chamyeohaeyo.
examples.en: In order to become an athlete, I always participate in training after school.

examples.kr: 시험에 합격하기 위해서 많은 시간을 공부하는 데 투자했어요.
examples.romaji: Siheome hapgyeokhagi wihaeseo manheun siganeul gongbuhaneun de tujahaeosseoyo.
examples.en: I invested a lot of time studying in order to pass the exam.

examples.kr: 행복한 삶을 살기 위해서 자기 자신을 사랑하는 것이 중요해요.
examples.romaji: Haengbokhan salmeul salgi wihaeseo jagi jasineul saranghaneun geosi jungyohaeyo.
examples.en: In order to live a happy life, it’s important to love yourself.

title: ~기는 [gineun] (But)
short_explanation: Used to indicate contrast or an exception; similar to 'but' in English.
long_explanation: '~기는 [gineun]' is attached to a verb stem (or sometimes an adjective stem) to imply a contrast with a following clause. It acknowledges or concedes one point, while highlighting a contrasting fact or viewpoint. It is somewhat similar to 'but' or 'although' in English, often used to say something “is true, but…”
formation: Verb stem + 기는 (or Adjective stem + 기는)

examples.kr: 저는 여행하기는 좋아하는데, 비행기를 타는 것이 아직도 두렵습니다.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun yeohaenghagineun joahaneunde, bihaenggireul taneun geosi ajikdo duryeopseumnida.
examples.en: I do like traveling, but I’m still scared of flying.

examples.kr: 그 건물은 크기는 큰데, 상태가 너무 안 좋아서 리모델링이 필요해 보여요.
examples.romaji: Geu geonmureun keugineun keunde, sangtaega neomu an joahaseo rimodeilling-i piryohae boyeoyo.
examples.en: That building is large, but it seems like it needs remodeling because it’s in bad condition.

examples.kr: 그 친구는 친절하기는 한데, 솔직히 말해서 너무 많이 물어봐서 조금 짜증나요.
examples.romaji: Geu chinguneun chinjeolhagineun hande, soljikhage malhaeseo neomu mani mureobwaseo jogeum jjajeungnayo.
examples.en: That friend is kind, but to be honest, I’m a bit annoyed because he asks too many questions.

examples.kr: 이번 계절은 봄이기는 한데, 날씨가 아직도 춥고, 따뜻해지기를 기다리고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Ibeon gyejeoreun bomigineun hande, nalssiga ajikdo chupgo, ttatteuthaejigireul gidarigo isseoyo.
examples.en: This season is spring, but the weather is still cold, so I'm waiting for it to warm up.

title: ~기에는 [gieneun] (For doing)
short_explanation: Used to express 'for doing something' or 'in order to'.
long_explanation: '~기에는 [gieneun]' typically indicates that something is either suitable or unsuitable for a certain purpose. It can often be translated as 'for (the purpose of) doing X' or 'to do X.' It frequently appears with judgments about time, conditions, or suitability for an action.

examples.kr: 이번 시험을 준비하기에는 시간이 충분하지 않다고 생각합니다.
examples.romaji: Ibeon siheomeul junbigieneun sigani chungbunhaji anhdago saenggakhamnida.
examples.en: I think there is not enough time to prepare for this exam.

examples.kr: 운동하기에는 밖이 너무 추워요, 그래서 집에서 운동하려고 합니다.
examples.romaji: Undonghagieneun bakki neomu chuwoyo, geuraeseo jib-eseo undongharyeogo hamnida.
examples.en: It is too cold outside to exercise, so I plan to work out at home.

examples.kr: 좋은 성적을 받기에는 진심으로 노력해야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Joheun seongjeogeul batgieneun jinsimeuro noryeokhaeya hamnida.
examples.en: You have to make a sincere effort in order to get a good grade.

examples.kr: 축구를 배우기에는 나이가 너무 많다고 생각하는 경우도 있어요.
examples.romaji: Chukgureul baeugieneun naiga neomu manhdago saenggakhaneun gyeongudo isseoyo.
examples.en: Sometimes people think they are too old to learn soccer.

title: ~기 전에 [gi jeone] (Before doing)
short_explanation: Used to express that one action occurs before another.
long_explanation: '~기 전에 [gi jeone]' means 'before doing (something).' It is used to specify an action that takes place prior to another action. The literal translation is 'before V-ing' in English. It is very common when giving a chronological order of steps or instructions.

examples.kr: 운동을 하기 전에 충분히 스트레칭을 해야 해요. 그렇지 않으면 부상을 당할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Undongeul hagi jeone chungbunhi seuteurechingeul haeya haeyo. Geureohji anheumyeon busangeul danghal su isseoyo.
examples.en: You have to stretch enough before exercising; otherwise, you might get injured.

examples.kr: 집을 나가기 전에 전기를 꺼야 해요. 그렇지 않으면 화재가 발생할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jibeul nagagi jeone jeongireul kkeoya haeyo. Geureohji anheumyeon hwajaega balsaenghal su isseoyo.
examples.en: You must turn off the electricity before leaving the house; otherwise, a fire could start.

examples.kr: 수업이 시작하기 전에 숙제를 제출해야 해요. 그렇지 않으면 학점이 깎일 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Sueobi sijakagi jeone sukjereul jechulhaeya haeyo. Geureohji anheumyeon hakjeomi kkakkil su isseoyo.
examples.en: You need to submit your homework before class starts; otherwise, your grade might be lowered.

examples.kr: 먹기 전에 손을 꼭 씻어야 해요. 그렇지 않으면 병균에 감염될 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Meokgi jeone soneul kkok ssiseoya haeyo. Geureohji anheumyeon byeonggyune gamyeomdoel su isseoyo.
examples.en: You must wash your hands before eating; otherwise, you can get infected by germs.

title: ~나 보다 [na boda] (Seems like, guess)
short_explanation: Used to express an assumption or supposition (e.g., 'it seems that...').
long_explanation: '~나 보다 [na boda]' is used when the speaker draws a guess or conclusion from evidence, often translated as 'it seems...', 'I guess...', or 'looks like...'. It can be used with both verbs and adjectives: '하나 보다' (I guess one does it), '크나 보다' (I guess it's big), etc.
formation: Verb or adjective stem + 나 보다

examples.kr: 피곤하나 봐요, 학교에 와서 계속 잤어요.
examples.romaji: Pigonhana bwayo, hakgyoe waseo gyesok jasseoyo.
examples.en: I guess he’s tired. He kept sleeping after he arrived at school.

examples.kr: 이 풍경을 보면 행복해지나 봐요. 그림을 그리면서 눈물을 흘렸어요.
examples.romaji: I punggyeongeul bomyeon haengbokhaejina bwayo. Geurimeul geurimyeonseo nunmureul heullyeosseoyo.
examples.en: I guess I feel happy when I see this scenery. I even shed tears while painting.

examples.kr: 비가 오나 봐요. 밖에 사람들이 우산을 들고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Biga ona bwayo. Bakke saramdeuri usaneul deulgo isseoyo.
examples.en: It seems to be raining. People outside are carrying umbrellas.

examples.kr: 그녀가 감기에 걸렸나 봐요. 계속 헛기침을 하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga gamgie geollyeotna bwayo. Gyesok heotgicheumeul hago isseoyo.
examples.en: I guess she caught a cold. She keeps clearing her throat.

title: ~나다 [nada] (End up doing, come to do)
short_explanation: Expresses that an action happened unexpectedly or wasn’t originally intended.
long_explanation: The verb “나다” can appear in certain compound forms like ‘결정이 나다’ (‘a decision is made’), ‘끝나다’ (‘to end’), or ‘결론이 나다’ (‘a conclusion is reached’). In these contexts, it often carries the nuance of something happening or being completed somewhat beyond one’s direct intention. It can be translated as ‘end up ~ing’ or ‘come to ~.’
formation: Commonly in fixed expressions (e.g., 결정이 나다, 끝나다).

examples.kr: 그녀는 고민을 하다가 결국 친구의 조언을 따르기로 결정이 났어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun gomineul hadaga gyeolguk chinguui joeoneul ttarugiro gyeoljeongi natseoyo.
examples.en: After much consideration, she ended up deciding to follow her friend’s advice.

examples.kr: 저는 간단히 쇼핑하러 갔다가 결국 많은 돈을 쓰는 것으로 끝났어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun gandanhi syopinghareo gatdaga gyeolguk manheun doneul sseuneun geoseuro kkeutnasseoyo.
examples.en: I went out for just a little shopping but ended up spending a lot of money.

examples.kr: 어제 집에 일찍 돌아가려 했지만, 늦게까지 일하다가 결국 늦게 돌아가게 됐어요.
examples.romaji: Eoje jibe iljjik doragaryeo haetjiman, neutgekkaji ilhadaga gyeolguk neutge doragage dwaesseoyo.
examples.en: I intended to go home early yesterday, but I kept working until late and ended up going home much later.

examples.kr: 학교에 가려고 했는데, 결국 비가 너무 많이 내려서 집에 있게 됐어요.
examples.romaji: Hakgyoe garyeogo haetneunde, gyeolguk biga neomu manhi naeryeoseo jibe itge dwaesseoyo.
examples.en: I intended to go to school, but it rained so much that I ended up staying at home.

title: ~나요? [nayo?] (Isn't it?)
short_explanation: Used to form tag questions or to express doubt (like 'isn't it?' or 'don't you?').
long_explanation: '~나요? [nayo?]' is a question ending that often seeks confirmation or agreement. It can mean 'isn’t it?', 'don’t you?', or 'right?' in English. The speaker is fairly polite but is also expressing some uncertainty or asking for the listener’s opinion/confirmation.

examples.kr: 오늘 날씨가 좋지 않나요? 비가 계속 오고 있어서요.
examples.romaji: Oneul nalssiga johji annayo? Biga gyesok ogo isseoseoyo.
examples.en: The weather isn’t too good today, is it? It's been raining continuously.

examples.kr: 당신은 저와 같이 저녁 식사를 할 거예요, 그렇지 않나요?
examples.romaji: Dangsineun jeowa gachi jeonyeok siksareul hal geoyeyo, geureochi annayo?
examples.en: You’re going to have dinner with me, aren’t you?

examples.kr: 저는 요즘 너무 바빠서 주말에 휴식이 필요하지 않나요?
examples.romaji: Jeoneun yojeum neomu bappaseo jumare hyusigi pilyohaji annayo?
examples.en: I’ve been really busy these days; I need some rest on the weekend, don't I?

examples.kr: 우리 모두 코로나 백신을 맞아야 합니다, 그렇지 않나요?
examples.romaji: Uri modu korona baeksineul maj-aya hamnida, geureochi annayo?
examples.en: We all need to get the COVID vaccine, shouldn’t we?

title: ~는 대로 [neun daero] (As it is)
short_explanation: Expresses 'just as', 'according to', or 'in the same way as'.
long_explanation: '~는 대로 [neun daero]' is used to mean 'exactly as' or 'according to.' It can be attached to verbs (e.g., '하는 대로') or nouns (with particles, e.g., '예측대로'). It emphasizes following instructions, patterns, or facts precisely as stated or observed.
formation: Verb stem + 는 대로 / Noun + 대로

examples.kr: 그림은 그림을 그리는 대로, 노래는 노래를 부르는 대로 배우는 게 좋아요.
examples.romaji: Geurimeun geurimeul geurineun daero, noraeneun noraereul bureuneun daero baeuneun ge johayo.
examples.en: It’s best to learn drawing by actually drawing, and learn singing by actually singing.

examples.kr: 그녀의 예측대로, 비가 정말 많이 왔어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoui yecheukdaero, biga jeongmal manhi wasseoyo.
examples.en: Just as she predicted, it really rained a lot.

examples.kr: 요리는 레시피대로, 선생님의 지시대로 따라하세요.
examples.romaji: Yorineun resipidaero, seonsaengnimui jisidaero ttarahaseyo.
examples.en: Cook according to the recipe and follow exactly what your teacher instructs.

examples.kr: 우리는 지도대로, 오늘 계획된 대로 여행할 거예요.
examples.romaji: Urineun jidodaero, oneul gyehoegdoen daero yeohaenghal geoyeyo.
examples.en: We will travel according to the map and as planned today.

title: ~는 도중에 [neun dojunge] (While doing)
short_explanation: Used to indicate that something happens in the midst of an ongoing action.
long_explanation: '~는 도중에 [neun dojunge]' literally means 'in the middle of (doing something).' It shows that an event occurs while another action is still in progress. It is similar to 'while (verb)-ing' or 'in the midst of' in English.

examples.kr: 나는 책을 읽는 도중에 잠이 들었어요. 그래서 내용을 다 기억하지 못하겠어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun chaekeul ilgneun dojunge jami deureosseoyo. Geuraeseo naeyongeul da gieokhaji motagesseoyo.
examples.en: I fell asleep while reading the book, so I don’t think I remember all of its contents.

examples.kr: 그녀는 음악을 듣는 도중에 갑자기 춤을 추기 시작했어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun eumageul deunneun dojunge gabjagi chumeul chugi sijakhaesseoyo.
examples.en: She suddenly started dancing while listening to music.

examples.kr: 타이핑을 하는 도중에 컴퓨터가 갑자기 꺼져서 작업을 다시 시작해야 했어요.
examples.romaji: Taiping-eul haneun dojunge keompyuteoga gabjagi kkeojyeoseo jageobeul dasi sijakhaeya haesseoyo.
examples.en: The computer suddenly turned off while I was typing, so I had to start my work over.

examples.kr: 친구들과 캠핑을 하는 도중에 갑자기 비가 내려서 텐트 안으로 들어갔어요.
examples.romaji: Chingudeulgwa kaemping-eul haneun dojunge gabjagi biga naeryeoseo tenteu aneuro deureogasseoyo.
examples.en: It suddenly began to rain while we were camping with friends, so we went inside the tent.

title: ~는 방향으로 [neun banghyangeuro] (Toward)
short_explanation: Indicates movement or orientation 'toward' a certain direction.
long_explanation: '~는 방향으로 [neun banghyangeuro]' is used to describe movement or orientation toward some direction or goal. It is often translated as 'in the direction of.' For instance, '학교 있는 방향으로 가다' means to walk or move toward where the school is located.

examples.kr: 나는 학교가 있는 방향으로 가고 있어요. 그게 가장 빠른 길이에요.
examples.romaji: Naneun hakgyoga itneun banghyangeuro gago isseoyo. Geuge gajang ppareun girieyo.
examples.en: I’m heading in the direction of the school. That’s the quickest way.

examples.kr: 그는 집이 있는 방향으로 달려갔어요. 엄청 빨리 돌아가고 싶어 했어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun jibi itneun banghyangeuro dallyeogasseoyo. Eomcheong ppalli doragago sipeo haesseoyo.
examples.en: He ran toward where his house is. He really wanted to get back quickly.

examples.kr: 그 여자는 나 있는 쪽 방향으로 자리를 옮겼어요. 그래서 조금 설렜어요.
examples.romaji: Geu yeojaneun na itneun jjok banghyangeuro jarireul olmgyeosseoyo. Geuraeseo jogeum seolleosseoyo.
examples.en: That woman moved her seat toward where I was, so I felt a bit fluttered.

examples.kr: 우리는 비가 오는 방향으로 계속 걸어가서 옷이 다 젖었어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun biga oneun banghyangeuro gyesok georeogaseo osi da jeojeosseoyo.
examples.en: We kept walking toward where it was raining, so we got completely wet.

title: ~는 법이다 [neun beopida] (Usually, always)
short_explanation: This expression is used to describe a general rule or habit that always tends to happen.
long_explanation: The phrase '~는 법이다 [neun beopida]' is a grammar structure used to say that something usually or always happens in a certain way, almost like a rule or law. It describes general truths, habits, or principles that tend not to change.

examples.kr: 우리 가족은 매일 밤 같이 저녁을 먹는 법이다.
examples.romaji: Uri gajogeun maeil bam gachi jeonyeogeul meokneun beopida.
examples.en: It's our family's rule to eat dinner together every night.

examples.kr: 그는 항상 일찍 일어나서 책을 읽는 법이다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun hangsang iljjik ileonaseo chaegeul ilgneun beopida.
examples.en: He always gets up early to read books.

examples.kr: 커피를 마신 후에는 항상 입을 헹구는 법이다.
examples.romaji: Keopireul masin hueneun hangsang ibeul hengguneun beopida.
examples.en: It's always the case that I rinse my mouth after drinking coffee.

examples.kr: 나는 항상 집에서 공부하면서 음악을 듣는 법이다.
examples.romaji: Naneun hangsang jibeseo gongbuhamyeonseo eumageul deudneun beopida.
examples.en: I always make a habit of listening to music while studying at home.

title: ~는데다 [neunde-da] (Furthermore, and)
short_explanation: Used to add additional information or to emphasize a situation; 'furthermore', 'in addition'.
long_explanation: '~는데다 [neunde-da]' is used to add another fact or condition that strengthens or expands upon the previous statement. It often translates to 'in addition to that...' or 'furthermore...' in English. It can be attached to verbs or adjectives to connect reasons or circumstances.

examples.kr: 그 카페는 커피가 맛있는데다 분위기도 참 좋아요.
examples.romaji: Geu kapeeneun keopiga masitneunde-da bunwigido cham joayo.
examples.en: The café serves delicious coffee, and in addition, the atmosphere is really nice.

examples.kr: 이 호텔은 위치도 좋은데다 직원들의 서비스도 훌륭해요.
examples.romaji: I hoteleun wichido joheunde-da jigweondeurui seobiseudo hullyunghaeyo.
examples.en: This hotel has a great location, and furthermore, the staff service is excellent.

examples.kr: 책을 읽는 것은 지식을 쌓는데다 스트레스 해소에도 도움이 돼요.
examples.romaji: Chaekeul ilgneun geoseun jisigeul ssanneunde-da seuteureseu haesoeedo doumi dwaeyo.
examples.en: Reading books not only builds up your knowledge, but it also helps relieve stress.

examples.kr: 그는 학점이 높은데다 학교 활동에도 적극적으로 참여하니 대학 생활이 많이 바쁠 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun hakjeomi nopneunde-da hakgyo hwaldong-edo jeokgeukjeogeuro chamyeohani daehak saenghwali manhi bappeul geot gatayo.
examples.en: He has high grades, and on top of that, he actively participates in school activities, so it seems his university life is quite busy.

title: ~는데도 [neundedo] (Even though, but still)
short_explanation: Used to express a contrasting or contradictory situation: 'even though', 'but still'.
long_explanation: '~는데도 [neundedo]' is a conjunctive particle that describes a surprising or unexpected result, given some situation or fact. It is similar to 'even though,' 'despite,' or 'but still' in English.

examples.kr: 아기인데도 많이 잠을 자지 않아요. 하루 종일 놀기만 해요.
examples.romaji: Agineundedo mani jameul jaji anhayo. Haru jongil nolgiman haeyo.
examples.en: Even though he is a baby, he doesn’t sleep much. He just plays all day long.

examples.kr: 많이 공부해서 잘 볼 줄 알았는데도 시험 점수가 낮게 나왔어요.
examples.romaji: Mani gongbuhaeseo jal bol jul aratneundedo siheom jeomsuga najge nawasseoyo.
examples.en: Even though I studied a lot and expected a good result, I got a low score on the test.

examples.kr: 많이 먹는데도 그녀는 늘 날씬해 보여요.
examples.romaji: Mani meokneundedo geunyeoneun neul nalssinhae boyeoyo.
examples.en: Even though she eats a lot, she always appears slim.

examples.kr: 이런 일을 여러 번 경험했는데도 저는 계속 같은 실수를 반복하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Ireon ireul yeoreo beon gyeongheomhaetneundedo jeoneun gyesok gateun silsureul banbokhago isseoyo.
examples.en: Even though I have gone through this many times, I keep making the same mistakes.

title: ~는지 [neunji] (Whether or not)
short_explanation: Used to express doubt or to inquire about a certain fact: 'whether or not'.
long_explanation: '~는지 [neunji]' is attached to a verb or adjective stem to indicate uncertainty or to form an indirect question. It can be translated as 'whether (or not)...' in English, and it’s often used when one is unsure or curious about some information.

examples.kr: 그는 내가 사랑하는지 알고 있을까요?
examples.romaji: Geuneun naega saranghaneunji algo isseulkkayo?
examples.en: I wonder if he knows that I love him.

examples.kr: 우리는 내일 회사에 갈 수 있는지 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun naeil hoesae gal su inneunji moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: We don't know if we can go into the office tomorrow.

examples.kr: 그녀가 어디에 있는지 알아낼 수 있을까요?
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga eodie itneunji aranael su isseulkkayo?
examples.en: Can we find out where she is?

examples.kr: 그 영화가 재미있는지 아닌지 알아보기 위해 평을 읽어보세요.
examples.romaji: Geu yeonghwaga jaemiinneunji aninji arabogi wihae pyeongeul ilgeoboseyo.
examples.en: Read some reviews to find out whether or not that movie is interesting.

title: ~는지 모르겠다 [neunji moreugessda] (I'm not sure if)
short_explanation: Used to express uncertainty: 'I'm not sure if...', 'I don't know whether...'.
long_explanation: '~는지 모르겠다 [neunji moreugessda]' expresses doubt or uncertainty about a certain fact or outcome. It roughly corresponds to 'I’m not sure if...' or 'I don’t know whether...' in English.

examples.kr: 그가 어떻게 반응할지 모르겠어요, 그래서 조금 긴장되네요.
examples.romaji: Geuga eotteohge baneunghalji moreugesseoyo, geuraeseo jogeum ginjangdeneyo.
examples.en: I'm not sure how he will react, so I'm a bit nervous.

examples.kr: 비가 오는지 안 오는지 모르겠어요. 날씨가 너무 흐려서요.
examples.romaji: Biga oneunji an oneunji moreugesseoyo. Nalssiga neomu heuryeoseoyo.
examples.en: I'm not sure if it's raining or not because it's so overcast.

examples.kr: 내일 시험을 잘 볼 수 있는지 모르겠어요. 아직 공부가 많이 남았거든요.
examples.romaji: Naeil siheomeul jal bol su inneunji moreugesseoyo. Ajik gongbuga manhi namatgeodeunyo.
examples.en: I'm not sure if I'll do well on tomorrow’s test. I still have a lot to study.

examples.kr: 회사에서 프로모션을 받을 수 있는지 모르겠어요. 경쟁이 무척 치열해서요.
examples.romaji: Hoesaeseo peulomosyeoneul badeul su inneunji moreugesseoyo. Gyeongjaengi mucheok chiyeolhaeseoyo.
examples.en: I'm not sure if I can get a promotion at work. The competition is really fierce.

title: ~는지라 [neunjira] (Because, since)
short_explanation: Used to provide a reason or cause for something: 'because', 'since'.
long_explanation: '~는지라 [neunjira]' is a connective ending in Korean that provides a reason or cause. It is often used in relatively formal or written contexts and means 'because' or 'since' in English. It generally implies that the stated reason is decisive for the outcome in the main clause.

examples.kr: 그가 매우 똑똑한데다가 성실한지라, 누구든지 그를 존경합니다.
examples.romaji: Geuga maeu ttokttokhandae-daga seongsilhanjira, nugudeunji geureul jong-gyeonghamnida.
examples.en: Because he’s very smart and also diligent, everyone respects him.

examples.kr: 이 일이 너무 절실한지라, 제가 최선을 다해 해결해야 했습니다.
examples.romaji: I iri neomu jeolsilhanjira, jega choeseoneul dahae haegyeolhaeya haetseumnida.
examples.en: Since this matter was very urgent, I had to do my best to solve it.

examples.kr: 그녀가 너무 예쁜지라, 사람들이 자주 그녀를 보고 미소 지어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga neomu yeppeunjira, saramdeuri jaju geunyeoreul bogo miso jieoyo.
examples.en: Because she is so pretty, people often look at her and smile.

examples.kr: 라면이 너무 매운지라, 제가 물을 여러 잔 마셔야 했습니다.
examples.romaji: Ramyeoni neomu maeunjira, jega mureul yeoreo jan masyeoya haetseumnida.
examples.en: Since the ramen was too spicy, I had to drink several glasses of water.

title: ~다가 [daga] (While, and then)
short_explanation: Used to express 'in the middle of something, when suddenly...' or 'and then'.
long_explanation: '~다가 [daga]' indicates that one action was in progress, and then another action or event occurred. It can imply an interruption ('while doing X, suddenly Y happened') or a sequence ('I was doing X and then moved on to Y').

examples.kr: 제가 소풍 가는 길에 빨간불을 기다리다가 휴대전화가 울렸어요.
examples.romaji: Jega sopung ganeun gire ppalganbureul gidaridaga hyudaejeonhwaga ulryeosseoyo.
examples.en: While I was waiting at a red light on my way to a picnic, my phone rang.

examples.kr: 장미가 음악을 듣다가 잠이 들어버렸어요.
examples.romaji: Jangmi-ga eumageul deuddaga jami deureobeoryeosseoyo.
examples.en: Jangmi was listening to music and then suddenly fell asleep.

examples.kr: 나는 저녁을 먹다가 갑자기 배가 아팠어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun jeonyeogeul meokdaga gapjagi baega apasseoyo.
examples.en: I was eating dinner when suddenly I got a stomachache.

examples.kr: 그는 책을 읽다가 피곤해서 잠들었습니다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun chaekeul ilgdaga pigonhaeseo jamdeureosseumnida.
examples.en: He was reading a book and then dozed off because he was tired.

title: ~다가는 [daganeun] (If keep doing)
short_explanation: Expresses a negative consequence if the current action continues.
long_explanation: '~다가는 [daganeun]' warns that if one keeps doing something (or if the current situation persists), a negative or undesired outcome will result. It translates roughly as 'if you keep doing this, then...' in English.

examples.kr: 숙제를 계속 미루다가는 결국 시험에 실패할 거예요.
examples.romaji: Sukjereul gyesok mirudaganeun gyeolguk siheome silpaehal geoyeyo.
examples.en: If you keep putting off your homework, you'll end up failing the test in the end.

examples.kr: 항상 늦게 자다가는 건강에 문제가 생길 거예요.
examples.romaji: Hangsang neutge jadaganeun geongange munjega saenggil geoyeyo.
examples.en: If you always go to bed late, you're likely to develop health problems.

examples.kr: 언제나 그렇게 게임만 하다가는 눈이 나빠질 거예요.
examples.romaji: Eonjena geureohge geimman hadaganeun nuni nappajil geoyeyo.
examples.en: If you keep playing games like that all the time, your eyesight will get worse.

examples.kr: 너무 고민만 하다가는 결정할 시간이 없어질 거예요.
examples.romaji: Neomu gominman hadaganeun gyeoljeonghal sigani eopseojil geoyeyo.
examples.en: If you keep worrying too much, you won't have any time left to make a decision.

title: ~다가도 [dagado] (Even though was doing)
short_explanation: Used when an unexpected event occurs while another action is in progress.
long_explanation: '~다가도 [dagado]' describes a scenario where the speaker was in the midst of doing something, yet an unexpected or contrasting outcome occurred. It can be interpreted as 'even though I was doing X, it turned out Y.'

examples.kr: 저는 열심히 공부하다가도 시험에서 떨어질 때가 있어요. 그래도 다음엔 꼭 합격하고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun yeolsimhi gongbuhadagado siheomeseo tteoreojil ttaega isseoyo. Geuraedo daeumen kkok hapgyeokhago sipeoyo.
examples.en: Even though I study hard, sometimes I still fail exams. But I really want to pass next time.

examples.kr: 카페에서 커피를 마시다가도 비가 갑자기 내려서 우산을 쓰고도 조금 젖었어요.
examples.romaji: Ka페eseo keopireul mashidagado biga gapjagi naeryeoseo usaneul sseugodo jogeum jeojeosseoyo.
examples.en: Even though I was just drinking coffee at the cafe, it suddenly started raining, and I got a bit wet even with an umbrella.

examples.kr: 요리를 만드는 동안 주의를 기울이다가도 결국 끓는 물에 그릇을 떨어뜨려서 손을 데었어요.
examples.romaji: Yorireul mandeuneun dongan juuieul giulyeodagado gyeolguk kkeulneun mure geureuteul tteoreotteuryeoseo soneul deyeosseoyo.
examples.en: Even though I was being careful while cooking, I ended up dropping the bowl into boiling water and burned my hand.

examples.kr: 강의를 듣다가도 중요한 부분을 놓치곤 해요. 다시 들어보려 해도 찾기가 어렵네요.
examples.romaji: Gangireul deuddagado jungyohan bubuneul nohchigon haeyo. Dasi deureoboryeo haedo chajgiga eoryeopneyo.
examples.en: Even though I'm listening to the lecture, I sometimes miss important parts. It’s hard to find them again even if I try to re-listen.

title: ~다는 것 [daneun geot] (The fact that)
short_explanation: Used to express 'the fact that' or 'the idea that' when referring to specific information.
long_explanation: '~다는 것 [daneun geot]' is a Korean grammar construct used to convey or emphasize the idea or concept of something, similar to 'the fact that' or 'the idea that' in English. It can also carry a nuance of 'it is said that,' but is most often used to highlight certain information the speaker has come to understand or wishes to point out.

examples.kr: 저는 그녀가 한국에서 온다는 것을 전혀 몰랐어요. 그래서 그녀의 한국어 실력에 깜짝 놀랐어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun geunyeoga hanguk-eseo on-daneun geoseul jeonhyeo mollasseoyo. Geuraeseo geunyeoui hangugeo sillyeoge kkamjjak nollasseoyo.
examples.en: I didn’t know the fact that she came from Korea, so I was really surprised by her Korean skills.

examples.kr: 나는 내가 이길 것이라는 것을 확실히 믿고 있어요. 그래서 모든 준비를 철저히 해서 오늘 경기를 치를 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Naneun naega igil georaneun geoseul hwaksilhage midgo isseoyo. Geuraeseo modeun junbireul cheoljeohi haeseo oneul gyeonggireul chireul geosimnida.
examples.en: I firmly believe in the fact that I will win, so I'm thoroughly preparing for today’s match.

examples.kr: 당신이 그만두었다는 것을 들었을 때, 저는 정말로 허탈해졌습니다. 왜냐하면 당신이 이 프로젝트에 중요한 부분이었기 때문입니다.
examples.romaji: Dangshini geumandueot-daneun geoseul deureosseul ttae, jeoneun jeongmallo heotalhaejyeosseumnida. Waenyahamyeon dangshini i peulojekteu-e jungyohan bubunieotgi ttaemunimnida.
examples.en: When I heard the fact that you quit, I felt truly devastated because you were a crucial part of this project.

examples.kr: 나는 그녀가 나를 좋아한다는 것을 알게 되었을 때 정말 행복했습니다. 왜냐하면 나도 그녀를 좋아하고 있었기 때문입니다.
examples.romaji: Naneun geunyeoga nareul joahandaneun geoseul alge doeeosseul ttae jeongmal haengbokhaesseumnida. Waenyahamyeon nado geunyeoreul joahago isseotgi ttaemunimnida.
examples.en: When I found out the fact that she likes me, I was really happy because I also liked her.

title: ~다며 [damyeo] (Saying that)
short_explanation: Used to relay an action or state that the speaker (or someone else) says, thinks, or feels.
long_explanation: '~다며 [damyeo]' is used in Korean when the speaker is quoting or restating something that was said or thought. It often appears when reporting direct speech or personal thoughts, indicating a subjective viewpoint. Tense is indicated by the overall sentence rather than by '다며' itself.

examples.kr: 모두가 하늘이 정말 파랗다며 말했을 때, 저는 그냥 당연하다고 생각했어요.
examples.romaji: Moduga haneuri jeongmal paratdamyeo malhaesseul ttae, jeoneun geunyang dangyeonhadago saenggakhaesseoyo.
examples.en: When everyone was saying that the sky was really blue, I just thought it was obvious.

examples.kr: 그녀는 자신이 더 이상 참을 수 없다며 그만두기로 결정했어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun jasini deo isang chameul su eopdamyeo geumandugiro gyeoljeonghaesseoyo.
examples.en: She decided to quit, saying that she couldn't stand it anymore.

examples.kr: 제 친구는 밤새 공부한다며 이야기했지만, 저는 그것이 거짓말이라고 생각했어요.
examples.romaji: Je chinguneun bamsae gongbuhandamyeo iyagihaetjiman, jeoneun geugeosi geojitmarirago saenggakhaesseoyo.
examples.en: My friend said that he studies all night, but I thought he was lying.

examples.kr: 엄마는 올해는 반드시 다이어트를 해야 한다며 스스로에게 약속했어요.
examples.romaji: Eommaneun olhaeneun bandeusi daieoteureul haeya handamyeo seuseuroege yaksokhaesseoyo.
examples.en: Mom promised herself that she must go on a diet this year, saying so herself.

title: ~대로 [daero] (According to, as)
short_explanation: Used to indicate actions performed according to a certain method, rule, or manner.
long_explanation: '~대로 [daero]' expresses that something is done 'according to' or 'in the same manner as' a previously mentioned instruction, plan, or situation. It can also mean 'just as it is.'

examples.kr: 선생님이 가르쳐 준 대로 문제를 풀어 보았지만, 아직 이해가 잘 안 돼요.
examples.romaji: Seonsaengnimi gareuchyeo jun daero munjeleul pureo boassjiman, ajik ihaega jal andwaeyo.
examples.en: I tried to solve the problem as the teacher taught me, but I still don’t really understand.

examples.kr: 언니가 추천해 준 대로 책을 읽어봤더니 깊은 뜻이 담긴 재미있는 책이었어요.
examples.romaji: Eonniga chucheonhae jun daero chaegeul ilgeobwatdeoni gipeun tteusi damgin jaemiinneun chaegieosseoyo.
examples.en: I read the book as my older sister recommended and found it to be quite interesting with a deep message.

examples.kr: 우리가 계획한 대로 여행을 계속하면서 여러 랜드마크를 볼 수 있었어요.
examples.romaji: Uriga gyehoekhan daero yeohaengeul gyesokhamyeonseo yeoreo raendeu-makeureul bol su isseosseoyo.
examples.en: We continued our trip according to our plan and got to see various landmarks.

examples.kr: 사진에 보이는 경치대로 실제로 보니까 너무 아름다워서 기분이 좋아졌어요.
examples.romaji: Sajine boineun gyeongchidaero siljero bonikka neomu areumdawoseo gibuni joajyeosseoyo.
examples.en: Seeing the scenery just as it appeared in the photo was so beautiful that it made me feel good.

title: ~대로 하다 [daero hada] (Do as instructed/said)
short_explanation: Used to express doing something exactly as was stated or instructed.
long_explanation: The expression '~대로 하다 [daero hada]' means to carry out an action 'according to' or 'as' someone said or as indicated by some rule, instruction, or pattern. It emphasizes following instructions or advice exactly.

examples.kr: 엄마는 아침에 일어나서 꼭 밥을 먹으라고 했어요. 그래서 저는 엄마가 말씀하신 대로 하고 학교에 가요.
examples.romaji: Eommaneun achime ileonaseo kkok babeul meogeurago haesseoyo. Geuraeseo jeoneun eommaga malsseumhasin daero hago hakgyoe gayo.
examples.en: Mom told me to be sure to have breakfast in the morning, so I do as she said and then head to school.

examples.kr: 요리책의 레시피대로 음식을 만들면 언제나 맛있게 완성할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Yorichaeg-ui resipi daero eumsigeul mandeulmyeon eonjena masitge wanseonghal su isseoyo.
examples.en: If you cook according to the recipe in the cookbook, you can always make it delicious.

examples.kr: 선생님이 강조하신 대로 공부하면 시험에서 좋은 점수를 받을 수 있을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Seonsaengnimi gangjohasin daero gongbuhamyeon siheom-eseo joheun jeomsureul badeul su isseul geoyeyo.
examples.en: If you study as the teacher emphasized, you’ll be able to get good scores on the test.

examples.kr: 부모님이 말씀하신 대로 매일 운동하고, 영양가 있는 음식을 먹으니까 건강이 훨씬 좋아졌어요.
examples.romaji: Bumonimi malsseumhasin daero maeil undonghago, yeongyangga itneun eumsigeul meogeunikka geongangi hwolssin joajyeosseoyo.
examples.en: By exercising every day and eating nutritious food just as my parents told me, my health improved a lot.

title: ~대로이면 [daeroimyeon] (If it’s as ... said)
short_explanation: Used to express the condition ‘if it is according to ...’ or ‘if it is as stated’.
long_explanation: '~대로이면 [daeroimyeon]' is a conditional phrase meaning 'if it indeed is as stated or as told.' Often used when talking about a plan, rumor, or instruction that might or might not be accurate.

examples.kr: 치킨집 사장님이 말한 대로이면, 여기서 가장 인기 있는 메뉴는 양념치킨이래요.
examples.romaji: Chikinjip sajangnimi malhan daeroimyeon, yeogiseo gajang ingi inneun menyuneun yangnyeom-chikiniraeyo.
examples.en: If what the chicken shop owner said is true, then the most popular item here is the seasoned fried chicken.

examples.kr: 네 계획대로이면, 오늘 밤에 영화를 볼 수 있겠네요.
examples.romaji: Ne gyehoek daeroimyeon, oneul bame yeonghwareul bol su itgenneyo.
examples.en: If it goes according to your plan, we can watch a movie tonight.

examples.kr: 민수가 말한 대로이면, 이 시험은 아주 어렵다고 해요.
examples.romaji: Minsuga malhan daeroimyeon, i siheomeun aju eoryeopdago haeyo.
examples.en: If it’s as Minsu said, this exam is supposed to be very difficult.

examples.kr: 흥민이가 모든 것을 솔직하게 말한 대로이면, 그는 앞으로 이런 실수를 하지 않을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Heungminiga modeun geoseul soljikhage malhan daeroimyeon, geuneun apeuro ireon silsureul haji anheul geoyeyo.
examples.en: If everything Heungmin said is true, he won’t make such mistakes again.

title: ~도록 [dorok] (So that)
short_explanation: Used to express ‘so that’ or ‘in order to’.
long_explanation: '~도록 [dorok]' is a grammatical form used in Korean to express an intended purpose or result, similar to 'so that' or 'in order to' in English. It can also indicate cause-and-effect relationships or give instructions for achieving a particular outcome.
formation: Verb stem + 도록 / Noun + 이/가 + Adjective + 도록

examples.kr: 야행성 동물들을 보도록 야간 사파리에 가기로 했어요.
examples.romaji: Ya-haengseong dongmuldeureul bodorok yagan saparie gagiro haesseoyo.
examples.en: We decided to go to a night safari so that we could see nocturnal animals.

examples.kr: 우리 모두가 이해할 수 있도록 강의를 천천히 해 주세요.
examples.romaji: Uri moduga ihaehal su itdorok ganguireul cheoncheonhi hae juseyo.
examples.en: Please give the lecture slowly so that we can all understand.

examples.kr: 낙엽이 빨리 치워지도록 주기적으로 마당을 쓸었어요.
examples.romaji: Nagyeobi ppalli chiwojidoroк jugijeogeuro madangeul sseureosseoyo.
examples.en: I swept the yard periodically so that the leaves would be cleared away quickly.

examples.kr: 비바람이 들어오지 않도록 창문을 꼭 닫아 두었어요.
examples.romaji: Bibarami deureo-oji antorok changmuneul kkok dada dueosseoyo.
examples.en: I shut the windows tightly so that the storm wouldn’t blow in.

title: ~도록 하다 [dorok hada] (Make/ensure that)
short_explanation: Used to express making someone do something or ensuring that something happens.
long_explanation: '~도록 하다 [dorok hada]' is often used in Korean to mean 'make sure to...' or 'have/let someone do something.' It can also mean you are ensuring a certain condition or outcome occurs.

examples.kr: 저는 항상 학생들이 성실하게 수업을 듣도록 해요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangsang haksaengdeuri seongsilhage sueobeul deuddorok haeyo.
examples.en: I always make sure the students listen attentively in class.

examples.kr: 회사에서는 직원들이 일찍 퇴근하도록 하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Hoesaeseoneun jigweondeuri iljjik toegunhadorok hago isseoyo.
examples.en: The company is ensuring that employees leave work early.

examples.kr: 그녀는 아이들이 안전하게 집에 도착하도록 했어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun aideuri anjeonhage jibe dochakhadorok haesseoyo.
examples.en: She made sure the children arrived home safely.

examples.kr: 엄마는 우리가 매일 채소를 먹도록 했어요.
examples.romaji: Eommaneun uriga maeil chaesoreul meokdorok haesseoyo.
examples.en: Mom made us eat vegetables every day.

title: ~도록이면 [dorogimyeon] (If possible)
short_explanation: Used to express a wish or desire for something to be done if possible.
long_explanation: '~도록이면 [dorogimyeon]' is used to indicate the speaker's preference or hope that something be done, assuming it’s possible. It can be interpreted as 'if possible...' or 'if you can help it...'.

examples.kr: 도록이면 건강에 좋은 음식을 먹으려고 노력하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Dorogimyeon geongange joeun eumsigeul meogeuryeogo noryeokhago isseoyo.
examples.en: I’m trying to eat healthy food if possible.

examples.kr: 도록이면 빨리 답장해 주세요.
examples.romaji: Dorogimyeon ppalli dapjanghae juseyo.
examples.en: Please reply as soon as possible if you can.

examples.kr: 도록이면 매일 운동을 해야 건강을 유지할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Dorogimyeon maeil undongeul haeya geongangeul yuji hal su isseoyo.
examples.en: If possible, you should exercise daily to maintain your health.

examples.kr: 도록이면 숙제를 미루지 않고 바로 하는 게 좋아요.
examples.romaji: Dorogimyeon sukjereul miruji anhgo baro haneun ge joayo.
examples.en: It’s best to do your homework right away, if possible, rather than postponing it.

title: ~든지 [deunji] (Whether ... or)
short_explanation: Used to present multiple possibilities or choices: 'whether ... or'.
long_explanation: '~든지 [deunji]' is used to offer two or more choices, similar to 'whether ... or' in English. It indicates that any of the mentioned options is acceptable or possible. It can be attached to nouns, verbs, or phrases in a flexible way.

examples.kr: 단체여행이든지 개인여행이든지, 저는 어떤 형태의 여행이든 좋아해요.
examples.romaji: Danche-yeohaengideunji gaein-yeohaengideunji, jeoneun eotteon hyeongtaeui yeohaeng-ideun joahaeyo.
examples.en: Whether it’s group travel or solo travel, I like any type of trip.

examples.kr: 이 문제를 해결하기 위해 많은 시간을 들였든지 많은 돈을 썼든지, 그 모든 노력은 가치가 있었어요.
examples.romaji: I munjeleul haegyeolhagi wihae manheun siganeul deuryeotdeunji manheun doneul sseotdeunji, geu modeun noryeok-eun gachi-ga isseosseoyo.
examples.en: Whether we spent a lot of time or a lot of money to solve this problem, all that effort was worthwhile.

examples.kr: 그가 만약 서울에 산다든지 부산에 산다든지, 그는 어디서든 행복할 거예요.
examples.romaji: Geuga manyak Seoul-e sandae-deunji Busan-e sandae-deunji, geuneun eodiseodeun haengbokhal geoyeyo.
examples.en: Whether he lives in Seoul or Busan, he’ll be happy anywhere.

examples.kr: 이 회사에서 근무한다든지 다른 회사에서 근무한다든지, 저는 어디서든지 최선을 다하겠습니다.
examples.romaji: I hoesaeseo geunmuhanda-deunji dareun hoesaeseo geunmuhanda-deunji, jeoneun eodiseodeunji choeseoneul dahagetseumnida.
examples.en: Whether I work at this company or another one, I will always do my best.

title: ~든지 ~든지 [deunji deunji] (Either ... or)
short_explanation: Used to enumerate alternatives or choices; 'either ... or'.
long_explanation: '~든지 ~든지 [deunji deunji]' is a conjunctive expression in Korean used to convey multiple choices or alternatives. Similar to 'either ... or' in English, it indicates that any of the mentioned options is acceptable, leaving the final decision to the listener or speaker.

examples.kr: 이번 주말에는 영화를 보러 가든지, 아니면 집에서 쉬든지 할 계획이에요.
examples.romaji: Ibeon jumal-eneun yeonghwareul boreo gadeunji, animyeon jibeseo swideunji hal gyehoeg-ieyo.
examples.en: This weekend, I plan to either go see a movie or rest at home.

examples.kr: 저녁 메뉴로 피자를 먹을 든지, 아니면 치킨을 먹을 든지 아직 결정하지 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Jeonyeok menyuro pijareul meogeul deunji, animyeon chikineul meogeul deunji ajik gyeoljeonghaji mothaesseoyo.
examples.en: I haven't decided yet whether to eat pizza or chicken for dinner.

examples.kr: 지금 집에 가든지, 아니면 조금 더 머무르든지 마음대로 해도 괜찮아요.
examples.romaji: Jigeum jibe gadeunji, animyeon jogeum deo meomureudeunji maeumdaero haedo gwaenchanhayo.
examples.en: You can either go home now or stay a bit longer—do whatever you like.

examples.kr: 그녀에게 전화하든지 아니면 메시지를 보내든지, 반드시 연락을 해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoege jeonhwahadeunji animyeon mesijireul bonaedeunji, bandeusi yeollageul haeya haeyo.
examples.en: You must contact her either by calling or sending a message.

title: ~라도 [rado] (At least, even if)
short_explanation: Used to express the minimum action or condition; 'at least', 'even if'.
long_explanation: '~라도 [rado]' indicates a minimal or lesser option that is still better than nothing. It carries the sense of 'at least' or 'even if,' showing that although the condition might not be ideal, it satisfies some minimum requirement or concession.

examples.kr: 이 일을 할 수 없다면, 도움이라도 주세요.
examples.romaji: I ireul hal su eopdamyeon, doumirado juseyo.
examples.en: If you can't do this job, at least give me some help.

examples.kr: 그는 수업에 참여하지 않았지만, 책이라도 읽었어야 했습니다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun sueobe chamyeohaji anhassjiman, chaegirado ilgeosseo-ya haetsseumnida.
examples.en: He didn't participate in class, but he should have at least read the book.

examples.kr: 시험에 떨어졌지만, 다시 시도라도 해보겠습니다.
examples.romaji: Siheome tteoreojyeotjiman, dasi sidorado haebogessseumnida.
examples.en: I failed the exam, but I will at least try again.

examples.kr: 영화를 보러 가고 싶지 않아도, 친구들이 영화를 좋아한다면 함께라도 갈게요.
examples.romaji: Yeonghwareul boreo gago sipji anhado, chingudeuri yeonghwareul joahandamyeon hamkkerado galgeyo.
examples.en: Even if I don’t want to see a movie, I'll at least go with them if my friends really like it.

title: ~라든지 [radeunji] (Or something)
short_explanation: Used to indicate alternatives or options; 'or something', 'for example'.
long_explanation: '~라든지 [radeunji]' is a Korean conjunctive particle used to suggest various examples or possibilities. It’s often used when the speaker is unsure or when only offering sample options among many, much like 'or something like that' or 'for example' in English.

examples.kr: 커피라든지 차라든지, 어떤 음료라도 마시겠어요?
examples.romaji: Keopiradeunji charadeunji, eotteon eumryorado masigesseoyo?
examples.en: Would you like something to drink, like coffee or tea or anything else?

examples.kr: 도서관에서 공부하라든지 집에서 책을 읽으라든지, 저는 항상 많이 배우고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Doseogwaneseo gongbuharadeunji jibeseo chaegeul ilgeuradeunji, jeoneun hangsang manhi baeugo isseoyo.
examples.en: Whether I'm studying in the library or reading books at home or something else, I'm always learning a lot.

examples.kr: 여행하라든지 새로운 취미를 찾아보라든지, 즐거움을 찾기 위해 해 볼 수 있는 일이 많아요.
examples.romaji: Yeohaengharadeunji saeroun chwimireul chajaboradeunji, jeulgeoumeul chatgi wihae haebolsu itneun iri manhayo.
examples.en: There are plenty of things you can do to find enjoyment, like traveling or finding a new hobby.

examples.kr: 사과라든지 배라든지, 과일 중에서 어떤 것을 제일 좋아하세요?
examples.romaji: Sagwaradeunji baeradeunji, gwail jungeseo eotteon geoseul jeil joahaseyo?
examples.en: Among fruits, which do you like best—apples, pears, or something else?

title: ~라면 [ramyeon] (If it's the case that)
short_explanation: Used to express the hypothetical condition 'if it's the case that'.
long_explanation: '~라면 [ramyeon]' is a conditional suffix in Korean that corresponds to 'if' or 'if it's the case that' in English. It’s commonly used for hypothetical or conjectural statements.

examples.kr: 당신이 그 사실을 먼저 알았다면, 왜 저에게 말해주지 않았어요?
examples.romaji: Dangshini geu sasireul meonjeo aratdamyeon, wae jeoege malhaejugi anhasseoyo?
examples.en: If you knew that fact earlier, why didn't you tell me?

examples.kr: 내일 비가 오라면 우산을 챙겨야겠어요.
examples.romaji: Naeil biga oramyeon usaneul chaenggyeoyagesseoyo.
examples.en: If it’s going to rain tomorrow, I'd better take an umbrella.

examples.kr: 내가 천재라면 이 문제를 쉽게 해결할 수 있을 텐데요.
examples.romaji: Naega cheonjaeramyeon i munjeleul swipge haegyeolhal su isseul tende-yo.
examples.en: If I were a genius, I could solve this problem easily.

examples.kr: 영화를 보러 가고 싶다면 저녁에 같이 갈까요?
examples.romaji: Yeonghwareul boreo gago sipdamyeon jeonyeoge gachi galkkayo?
examples.en: If you want to see a movie, shall we go together in the evening?

title: ~라면서 [ramyeonseo] (While saying that)
short_explanation: Used when an action or state contradicts a previously stated intention or claim.
long_explanation: '~라면서 [ramyeonseo]' is used to indicate that someone acts in a way that goes against what they have said. It can also be used in contexts where you quote someone else’s words and then show a discrepancy. It loosely translates to 'while (he/she) said that...' in English.

examples.kr: 그가 공부를 하겠다면서 계속 게임을 하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geuga gongbureul hagetdamyeonseo gyesok geimeul hago isseoyo.
examples.en: He keeps playing games while saying he will study.

examples.kr: 그녀는 돈을 절약하겠다면서 지금 쇼핑을 하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun doneul jeol-yakhagetdamyeonseo jigeum syopingeul hago isseoyo.
examples.en: She said she'd save money, but she's out shopping now.

examples.kr: 나는 다이어트를 해야 한다면서 매일 달콤한 음식을 먹고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun daieoteureul haeya handamyeonseo maeil dalkomhan eumsigeul meokgo isseoyo.
examples.en: I say I have to diet, yet I'm eating sweet food every day.

examples.kr: 우리 아버지는 흡연을 그만두겠다면서 아직도 담배를 피우고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Uri abeojineun heubyeoneul geumandugessdamyeonseo ajikdo dambaereul piugo isseoyo.
examples.en: My father said he would quit smoking, but he’s still smoking.

title: ~려고 [ryeogo] (In order to)
short_explanation: Used to show the intent or purpose of an action; 'in order to', 'to'.
long_explanation: '~려고 [ryeogo]' is used in Korean to express the intention or purpose for doing something. It is often translated as 'in order to' or simply 'to' in English, indicating the reason or goal behind an action.

examples.kr: 한국어를 잘하려고 매일 한국어를 공부하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Hangugeoreul jal-haryeogo maeil hangugeoreul gongbuhago isseoyo.
examples.en: I'm studying Korean every day in order to speak it well.

examples.kr: 다이어트를 하려고 운동하고, 칼로리를 줄이려고 노력했어요.
examples.romaji: Daieoteureul haryeogo undonghago, kallorireul juriryeogo noryeokhaesseoyo.
examples.en: I'm exercising to go on a diet and trying to reduce my calorie intake.

examples.kr: 이번 시험을 잘 보려고 많이 공부했고, 일찍 자려고 노력했습니다.
examples.romaji: Ibeon siheomeul jal boryeogo manhi gongbuhaetgo, iljjik jaryeogo noryeokhaetsseumnida.
examples.en: I studied a lot to do well on this exam and tried to go to bed early.

examples.kr: 엄마를 기쁘게 해드리려고 매일 방을 치우고, 맛있는 음식을 만들어 드렸어요.
examples.romaji: Eommareul gippeuge haedeuryeogo maeil bang-eul chiugo, masinneun eumsigeul mandeureo deuryeosseoyo.
examples.en: I tidied my room every day and made tasty food in order to make my mom happy.

title: ~려고 하다 [ryeogo hada] (Try to)
short_explanation: Used to express one's intention or attempt to do something; 'try to', 'plan to'.
long_explanation: '~려고 하다' indicates the speaker’s intention or plan to perform an action. It can be translated as 'try to...' or 'plan to...' in English. It’s a common structure for talking about near-future actions or goals.

examples.kr: 저는 오늘 학교에 가려고 했는데, 비가 와서 갈 수 없었어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun oneul hakgyoe garyeogo haetneunde, biga waseo gal su eopseosseoyo.
examples.en: I intended to go to school today, but I couldn't because it was raining.

examples.kr: 삼촌은 내일 우리 집에 오려고 했지만, 차가 고장 나서 오지 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Samchoneun naeil uri jibe oryeogo haetjiman, chaga gojang naseo oji moshaesseoyo.
examples.en: My uncle planned to come to our house tomorrow, but he couldn't because his car broke down.

examples.kr: 나는 당신에게 전화를 하려고 했어요, 하지만 배터리가 다 되어서 전화를 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun dangsinege jeonhwareul haryeogo haesseoyo, hajiman baeteoriga da doeeoseo jeonhwareul mothaesseoyo.
examples.en: I tried to call you, but I couldn't because my phone battery died.

examples.kr: 친구들과 함께 영화를 보려고 했지만 표가 매진되어 보지 못했습니다.
examples.romaji: Chingudeulgwa hamkke yeonghwareul boryeogo haetjiman pyoga maejindoeeo boji mothaesseumnida.
examples.en: My friends and I tried to watch a movie together, but we couldn't because the tickets were sold out.

title: ~려는데 [ryeonde] (I'm planning to, I want to)
short_explanation: Used to express a plan or intention that has not yet been carried out.
long_explanation: '~려는데 [ryeonde]' is used when the speaker has a plan or a certain inclination to do something in the future. It often carries the nuance that the plan could be affected by circumstances, or that it’s still in the preliminary stage.

examples.kr: 책을 사러 서점에 가려는데 비가 너무 많이 와서 아마 못 갈 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Chaekeul sareo seojeome garyeoneunde biga neomu manhi waseo ama mot gal geot gatayo.
examples.en: I’m planning to go to the bookstore to buy a book, but it's raining so hard that I probably can't go.

examples.kr: 디너를 준비하려는데 필요한 재료가 부족해서 장을 보러 가야 할 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Dineoreul junbiharyeoneunde pilyohan jaeryoga bujokhaeseo jangeul boreo gaya hal geot gatayo.
examples.en: I want to prepare dinner, but I’m short on ingredients, so I'll probably have to go grocery shopping.

examples.kr: 친구에게 선물을 주려는데 무슨 선물을 줄지 아직 고민 중이에요.
examples.romaji: Chingu-ege seonmureul juryeoneunde museun seonmureul julji ajik gomin jungieyo.
examples.en: I plan to give a gift to my friend, but I'm still figuring out which gift to give.

examples.kr: 이번 주말에 영화를 보러 가려는데 모든 표가 예약돼서 못 볼 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Ibeon jumale yeonghwareul boreo garyeoneunde modeun pyoga yeyakdoe-seo mot bol geot gatayo.
examples.en: I’m planning to go see a movie this weekend, but all the tickets are booked, so I probably won’t be able to go.

title: ~마다 [mada] (Every)
short_explanation: Used to express 'every' or 'each'.
long_explanation: '~마다 [mada]' is a postposition in Korean used to mean 'every' or 'each,' emphasizing the recurring nature of events or items. It can apply to time expressions (e.g., 매일마다), location (집집마다), or other contexts where the idea of ‘every’ or ‘each’ is relevant.

examples.kr: 나는 주마다 도서관에 가서 책을 빌려 읽어요. 그래서 계속 새 지식을 쌓아 가고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun jumada doseogwane gaseo chaeg-eul billyeo ilgeoyo. Geuraeseo gyesok sae jisigeul ssaha gago isseoyo.
examples.en: I go to the library every week to borrow books and read, so I’m constantly learning new things.

examples.kr: 매일 아침마다 기분 좋게 하루를 시작하자. 그러면 좋은 일이 생길 거예요.
examples.romaji: Maeil achimmada gibun johge harureul sijakhaja. Geureomyeon joheun iri saenggil geoyeyo.
examples.en: Let’s start each day in a good mood every morning. Then good things will happen.

examples.kr: 저는 친구와 매달 말마다 영화를 보러 가요. 그래서 항상 새로운 영화를 볼 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun chinguwa maedal malmada yeonghwareul boreo gayo. Geuraeseo hangsang saeroun yeonghwareul bol su isseoyo.
examples.en: At the end of each month, I go see a movie with my friend, so I always get to watch a new release.

examples.kr: 우리는 여름마다 해변에 가서 신나는 시간을 보내려고 해요. 그래서 매년 여름이 기다려져요.
examples.romaji: Urineun yeoreummada haebyeone gaseo sinnaneun siganeul bonaeryeogo haeyo. Geuraeseo maenyeon yeoreumi gidaryeojyeoyo.
examples.en: Every summer, we go to the beach to have a great time, so we look forward to summer every year.

title: ~만큼 [mankeum] (As much as)
short_explanation: This pattern is used to show the extent or degree of something, or to compare two things.
long_explanation: '~만큼 [mankeum]' is a grammar structure used to express 'as much as' or 'equivalent to' in English. It lets you denote that something has the same extent or degree as another thing. It’s often used to talk about comparisons, equivalences, or proportional relationships.

examples.kr: 당신이 좋아하면 그만큼 저도 좋아합니다. 감정은 항상 상호적인 것이니까요.
examples.romaji: Dangsini joahamyeon geu mankeum jeodo joahamnida. Gamjeongeun hangsang sanghojeokin geosinikka.
examples.en: As much as you like it, I like it too, because emotions are always reciprocal.

examples.kr: 우리 아버지는 젊을 때만큼 빨리 달리지는 못하지만, 여전히 체력이 좋아요.
examples.romaji: Uri abeojineun jeolmeul ttaemankeum ppareuge dallijineun motajiman, yeojeonhi cheryeogi joayo.
examples.en: My father can't run as fast as he did when he was young, but he still has good stamina.

examples.kr: 이 책은 읽을수록 좋아요. 책의 뒷부분을 보면 앞부분만큼 흥미로워요.
examples.romaji: I chaegeun ilgeulsurok joayo. Chaegui dwit bubeuneul bomyeon ap bubeun mankeum heungmirowoyo.
examples.en: The more you read this book, the better it gets. The latter part is as interesting as the beginning.

examples.kr: 당신이 얼마나 노력하느냐에 따라 성공 가능성이 그만큼 높아집니다.
examples.romaji: Dangsini eolmana noryeokhaneunyaye ttara seonggong ganeungseongi geu mankeum nopajimnida.
examples.en: The more effort you put in, the higher your chance of success.

title: ~면 [myeon] (If, when)
short_explanation: Used to express a conditional 'if' or to describe 'when' something happens.
long_explanation: '~면 [myeon]' is a suffix attached to a verb stem to mean 'if' or sometimes 'when' in English. It describes a hypothetical or future condition. The action or state in the main clause will naturally occur once the condition in the dependent clause is met.

examples.kr: 저는 밥을 먹으면 행복해지는 기분이에요. 마치 배고픔을 해결하는 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun babeul meogeumyeon haengbokhaejineun gibunieyo. Machi baegopeumeul haegyeolhaneun geot gatayo.
examples.en: I feel happy when I eat. It’s like solving hunger.

examples.kr: 수업이 끝나면 바로 집에 가려고 해요. 너무 피곤해서 공부할 의욕이 없어요.
examples.romaji: Sueobi kkeutnamyeon baro jibe garyeogo haeyo. Neomu pigonhaeseo gongbuhal uiyogi eopseoyo.
examples.en: If class ends, I plan to go home right away. I'm too tired to have the will to study.

examples.kr: 시험에 합격하면 친구들과 함께 파티를 열려고 생각하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Siheome hapgyeokhamyeon chingudeulgwa hamkke patireul yeollyeogo saenggakago isseoyo.
examples.en: If I pass the exam, I'm thinking of throwing a party with my friends.

examples.kr: 저를 더 이상 짓누르면, 결국 저는 앞으로 나아갈 용기를 잃을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Jeoreul deo isang jitnureumyeon, gyeolguk jeoneun apeuro naagal yonggireul ilheul geot gatayo.
examples.en: If you keep pressing me down, I think I’ll eventually lose the courage to move forward.

title: ~면서 [myeonseo] (While)
short_explanation: A conjunction used to connect two actions happening at the same time.
long_explanation: '~면서 [myeonseo]' indicates two actions or states occurring simultaneously with the same subject. It often translates to 'while' or 'as' in English. It’s used when both actions happen concurrently rather than in sequence.

examples.kr: 나는 음악을 들으면서 공부를 해요. 그러면 훨씬 더 집중이 잘 돼요.
examples.romaji: Naneun eumageul deuleumyeonseo gongbureul haeyo. Geureomyeon hwolssin deo jipjungi jal dwaeyo.
examples.en: I study while listening to music. It helps me concentrate much better.

examples.kr: 우리 엄마는 요리를 하면서 노래를 불러요. 그 모습이 너무 사랑스러워요.
examples.romaji: Uri eommaneun yorireul hamyeonseo noraereul bulleoyo. Geu moseubi neomu sarangseureowoyo.
examples.en: My mom cooks while singing, and it’s so lovely to see.

examples.kr: 저는 자전거를 타면서 책을 읽을 수는 없어요. 너무 위험하니까요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun jajeongeoreul tamyeonseo chaegeul ilgeul suneun eopseoyo. Neomu wiheomhani kkayo.
examples.en: I can't read a book while riding a bike because it’s too dangerous.

examples.kr: 친구와 이야기하면서 커피를 마셔요. 그래서 카페를 자주 가요.
examples.romaji: Chinguwa iyagihamyeonseo keopireul masyeoyo. Geuraeseo kape-reul jaju gayo.
examples.en: I chat with my friend while having coffee. That’s why I often go to cafés.

title: ~밖에 [bakke] (Nothing but, only)
short_explanation: Expresses 'nothing but' or 'only', indicating limited choices or possibilities (usually in negative sentences).
long_explanation: '~밖에 [bakke]' is a particle that emphasizes the exclusivity of something—only that item or option exists or applies. It generally appears in negative sentences to highlight that there is nothing else but whatever is mentioned.

examples.kr: 나는 한국어밖에 몰라서 다른 나라에서 생활하기가 너무 어려워요.
examples.romaji: Naneun hangugeo bakke mollaseo dareun naraseo saenghwalhagiga neomu eoryeowoyo.
examples.en: It’s hard for me to live in other countries because I know nothing but Korean.

examples.kr: 이 가게에서는 감자튀김밖에 팔지 않아서 선택의 폭이 좁아요.
examples.romaji: I gagee-seoneun gamjatwigim bakke palji anhaseo seontaekui pogi jobayo.
examples.en: This shop only sells French fries, so there aren't many options.

examples.kr: 그녀는 카페에서 머핀밖에 사지 않아서 다른 메뉴는 전혀 몰라요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun kape-eseo meopin bakke saji anhaseo dareun menyuneun jeonhyeo mollayo.
examples.en: She buys nothing but muffins at the café, so she doesn’t know any other menu items.

examples.kr: 이번 주말은 집에서 쉬는 것밖에 할 수 없어요. 친구들이 모두 바빠서 만날 수가 없어요.
examples.romaji: Ibeon jumareun jibeseo swineun geot bakke hal su eopseoyo. Chingudeuri modu bappaseo mannal suga eopseoyo.
examples.en: I can’t do anything except rest at home this weekend, because all my friends are too busy to meet.

title: ~보다 [boda] (More than)
short_explanation: Used to form comparative expressions equivalent to 'more than' in English.
long_explanation: '~보다 [boda]' is a particle that marks what something is being compared to, functioning like 'than' in English. The item before '보다' is the reference of comparison, indicating that something else is bigger, better, or more than it.

examples.kr: 저는 커피보다 차를 더 좋아해요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun keopiboda chareul deo joahaeyo.
examples.en: I like tea more than coffee.

examples.kr: 이번 여름은 작년 여름보다 더 더웠어요.
examples.romaji: Ibeon yeoreumeun jaknyeon yeoreumboda deo deowosseoyo.
examples.en: This summer was hotter than last summer.

examples.kr: 나는 평소보다 더 많이 밥을 먹었어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun pyeongso-boda deo manhi babeul meogeosseoyo.
examples.en: I ate more rice than I usually do.

examples.kr: 지금 시간은 밤 10시보다 더 늦었어요.
examples.romaji: Jigeum siganeun bam yeolshi-shiboda deo neujeosseoyo.
examples.en: The current time is later than 10 p.m.

title: ~부터 [buteo] (From, starting from)
short_explanation: Indicates the starting point of an action, location, or time.
long_explanation: '~부터 [buteo]' is a common grammar particle used to show when or where something begins. It corresponds to 'from' in English, marking the starting moment, place, or status for an event or situation.

examples.kr: 내일은 아침 일곱 시부터 수업이 시작되니까 늦지 않게 준비해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Naeireun achim ilgop si-buteo sueobi sijakdoenikka neutji anke junbihaeya haeyo.
examples.en: Class starts from 7 a.m. tomorrow, so we need to prepare to avoid being late.

examples.kr: 여행 가방을 정리할 때 옷부터 꺼냈고, 그 다음에 액세서리를 챙겼어요.
examples.romaji: Yeohaeng gabangeul jeongrihal ttae ot-buteo kkeonaetgo, geu daume aeksesarireul chaenggyeosseoyo.
examples.en: When I organized my travel bag, I took out my clothes first, then packed my accessories.

examples.kr: 이 식당에서는 점심을 열두 시부터 오후 세 시까지 판매해요.
examples.romaji: I sikdang-eseoneun jeomsimeul yeoldu si-buteo ohu se si-kkaji panmaehaeyo.
examples.en: At this restaurant, they serve lunch from 12 p.m. to 3 p.m.

examples.kr: 이번 달부터 다음 해 초까지 이 프로젝트를 완성해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Ibeon dal-buteo daeum hae cho-kkaji i peurojekteureul wanseonghaeya haeyo.
examples.en: We need to finish this project from this month until early next year.

title: ~서는 [seoneun] (But in)
short_explanation: Used to indicate contrast or contradiction in two different contexts.
long_explanation: '~서는 [seoneun]' can appear in contexts where there is a mismatch between an expectation or statement and the actual situation. It's somewhat similar to saying 'but in (that regard)' or 'but as for...' in English. It often conveys disappointment, contradiction, or surprise.

examples.kr: 그 친구는 일본어도 잘하고 중국어도 잘하는데, 한국어는 전혀 못해서는 좀 아쉽더라고요.
