examples.romaji: Geu chinguneun ilboneodo jalhago junggugeodo jalhaneunde, hangugeoneun jeonhyeo mothaeseoneun jom aswittdoragoyo.
examples.en: That friend speaks Japanese and Chinese well, but in Korean, he can’t speak at all, which is a bit unfortunate.

examples.kr: 저는 요리를 꽤 잘하지만, 디저트를 만드는 데서는 자신이 없어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun yorireul kkwae jalhajiman, dijeoteureul mandeuneun deseo-neun jasini eopseoyo.
examples.en: I cook pretty well, but in making desserts, I’m not confident.

examples.kr: 그는 시험을 잘 봤다고 했는데, 결과에서는 정말 망해서 놀랐어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun siheomeul jal bwattdago haetneunde, gyeolgwa-eseoneun jeongmal manghaeseo nollaesseoyo.
examples.en: He said he did well on the test, but in the actual results, he failed badly, so I was surprised.

examples.kr: 동생은 항상 방을 잘 정리한다고 했는데, 막상 보면 방 청소에서는 완전히 엉망이라 실망했어요.
examples.romaji: Dongsaeng-eun hangsang bang-eul jal jeongrihandago haetneunde, makssang bomyeon bang cheongso-eseoneun wanjeonhi eongmangira shilmanghaesseoyo.
examples.en: My younger sibling always says they keep their room tidy, but when I actually look, in terms of cleaning the room, it’s a total mess, so I was disappointed.

title: ~아/어 보이다 [a/eo boida] (Looks/seems like)
short_explanation: Used to make a subjective judgment about someone or something based on appearance or situation.
long_explanation: '~아/어 보이다 [a/eo boida]' is used to convey that something or someone ‘looks like’ or ‘seems like’ a certain way, based on the speaker's subjective perspective. It can express guesses or first impressions about a person’s feelings, health, weather, etc.

examples.kr: 내일은 날씨가 좋아 보이네요. 외출하면 좋을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Naeireun nalssiga joa boineyo. Oechulhamyeon joeul geot gatayo.
examples.en: It looks like the weather will be nice tomorrow; going out might be good.

examples.kr: 그 친구는 종종 외로워 보이더라고요. 도와주면 좋을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Geu chinguneun jongjong oerowo boideoragoyo. Dowajumyeon joeul geot gatayo.
examples.en: That friend often seems lonely; I think it’d be good to help them.

examples.kr: 진희 씨는 요즘 정말 바빠 보여요. 부지런히 일하는 모습에 장래가 기대돼요.
examples.romaji: Jinhee-ssineun yojeum jeongmal bappa boyeoyo. Bujireonhi ilhaneun moseube jangnaega gidae dwaeyo.
examples.en: Jinhee seems really busy these days; seeing her work so diligently makes me look forward to her future.

examples.kr: 이렇게 많이 먹었는데도 배가 고파 보이는 건 어떻게 설명할 수 있을까요?
examples.romaji: Ireoke manhi meogeotneundedo baega gopa boineun geon eotteoke seolmyeonghal su isseulkkayo?
examples.en: How can we explain that you still look hungry, even after eating so much?

title: ~아/어 버리다 [a/eo beorida] (Completely do, or unfortunately do)
short_explanation: Used to indicate completing an action fully, or doing something that leads to an unfortunate result.
long_explanation: The structure '~아/어 버리다 [a/eo beorida]' attaches to a verb stem to emphasize that the action is done completely or that the outcome is regrettable/unwanted. It can imply relief at finishing something, or express the speaker’s sense of regret or finality about the action.

examples.kr: 처음 만나는 여자친구를 기다리다가 너무 늦어서 잠이 들어 버렸어요.
examples.romaji: Cheoeum mannaneun yeoja chingureul gidaridaga neomu neujeoseo jami deureo beoryeosseoyo.
examples.en: I was waiting for my girlfriend (who I was meeting for the first time), but it got so late that I ended up falling asleep.

examples.kr: 과제가 너무 어려워서 그냥 포기해 버렸어요.
examples.romaji: Gwajega neomu eoryeowoseo geunyang pogihae beoryeosseoyo.
examples.en: The assignment was so difficult that I just gave up completely.

examples.kr: 가방을 버스에 두고 내려서 깜빡 잊어버렸어요.
examples.romaji: Gabangeul beoseue dugo naeryeoseo kkambak ijeobeoryeosseoyo.
examples.en: I left my bag on the bus when I got off and forgot about it.

examples.kr: 야구 경기에서 우리 팀이 너무 안 좋아서 점수를 다 잃어버렸어요.
examples.romaji: Yagu gyeonggieseo uri timi neomu an joaseo jeomsureul da ilheobeoryeosseoyo.
examples.en: Our team played so poorly in the baseball game that we ended up losing all our points.

title: ~아/어 두다 [a/eo duda] (Keep, leave)
short_explanation: Used to express leaving or keeping something in a certain state or condition.
long_explanation: '~아/어 두다 [a/eo duda]' is used in Korean to indicate that one is leaving something in a particular state or maintaining it for a future use or reference. It implies an intentional act of preservation or preparation. Depending on the verb’s final vowel/consonant, use '아 두다' or '어 두다'.

examples.kr: 사랑하는 사람을 위해 좋은 추억을 만들어 두는 것이 중요해요.
examples.romaji: Saranghaneun sarameul wihae joheun chueogeul mandeureo duneun geosi jungyohaeyo.
examples.en: It's important to create and keep good memories for the person you love.

examples.kr: 요리를 너무 많이 만들었어요. 나중에 먹기 위해 냉장고에 저장해 두었어요.
examples.romaji: Yorireul neomu manhi mandeureosseoyo. Najunge meokgi wihae naengjanggoe jeojanghae dueosseoyo.
examples.en: I made too much food, so I stored it in the refrigerator for later.

examples.kr: 공부하다가 모르는 단어를 찾으면 노트에 적어 두는 것이 좋아요.
examples.romaji: Gongbuhadaga moreuneun daneoreul chajeumyeon note-e jeogeo duneun geosi joayo.
examples.en: When studying, if you come across a word you don't know, it's good to write it down and keep it.

examples.kr: 나는 나의 꿈을 이루기 위해 항상 여러 계획을 세워 두었어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun naye kkumeul irugi wihae hangsang yeoreo gyaehoeg-eul seewo dueosseoyo.
examples.en: I always mapped out several plans in advance to achieve my dream.

title: ~아/어 가다 [a/eo gada] (Go on doing)
short_explanation: Expresses the continuous or ongoing nature of an action over time.
long_explanation: '~아/어 가다 [a/eo gada]' is used to show that an action continues steadily or gradually forward, often implying persistence or progress. It can be similar to 'go on doing something' in English.

examples.kr: 그는 매일 아침 운동을 해 가면서 건강을 유지하려고 노력합니다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun maeil achim undongeul hae gamyeonseo geongangeul yuji-haryeogo noryeokhamnida.
examples.en: He goes on exercising every morning to maintain his health.

examples.kr: 그녀는 학교에 다니면서 일을 해 가고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun hakgyoe danimyeonseo ireul hae gago isseoyo.
examples.en: She keeps on working while attending school.

examples.kr: 우리는 큰 어려움에도 불구하고 프로젝트를 계속 해 가고 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Urineun keun eoryeoumedo bulguhago peurojekteureul gyesok hae gago itsseumnida.
examples.en: Despite great difficulties, we continue on with the project.

examples.kr: 친구들이 포기했음에도 불구하고, 저는 연습을 계속 해 가고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Chingudeuri pogihaesseumedo bulguhago, jeoneun yeonseubeul gyesok hae gago isseoyo.
examples.en: Even though my friends gave up, I keep on practicing.

title: ~아/어 오다 [a/eo oda] (Come to do)
short_explanation: Expresses an action developing over time or a gradual change leading up to the present.
long_explanation: '~아/어 오다 [a/eo oda]' is used to show that an action has been in progress or gradually developed until now. It can translate to 'have been doing' or 'come to do' in English, depending on context.

examples.kr: 그는 한 달 동안 매일 한국어를 공부해 오다 보니 이제 유창하게 말할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun han dal dongan maeil hangugeoreul gongbuhae oda boni ije yuchanghage malhal su isseoyo.
examples.en: He has been studying Korean every day for a month, so now he can speak it fluently.

examples.kr: 우리는 같이 매일 운동해 오다 보니 어느새 체력이 많이 좋아졌어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun gachi maeil undonghae oda boni eoneusae cheryeogi manhi joajeosseoyo.
examples.en: We have been working out together daily, and before we knew it, our stamina improved a lot.

examples.kr: 미나는 그림을 꾸준히 그려 오다 보니 점점 더 잘 그리게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Mina-neun geurimeul kkujunhi geuryeo oda boni jeomjeom deo jal geurigedoeosseoyo.
examples.en: Since Mina has steadily been drawing, she has gradually gotten better at it.

examples.kr: 해가 저물어 오다 보니 금세 어두워졌어요.
examples.romaji: Haega jeomureo oda boni geumse eoduwanjeosseoyo.
examples.en: As the sun set, it quickly became dark.

title: ~아/어야 하다 [a/eoya hada] (Have to, must)
short_explanation: Expresses obligation or necessity: 'have to,' 'must'.
long_explanation: '~아/어야 하다 [a/eoya hada]' indicates that something needs to be done or is mandatory. It corresponds to 'have to' or 'must' in English. '아야 하다' is used if the verb ends in ㅏ/ㅗ, and '어야 하다' is used otherwise.

examples.kr: 내일 시험이 있으니까 오늘 밤에 공부해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Naeil siheomi isseunikka oneul bame gongbuhaeya haeyo.
examples.en: I must study tonight because I have an exam tomorrow.

examples.kr: 회사에 늦지 않으려면 7시에 집을 나가야 해요.
examples.romaji: Hoesae neujji an-euryeomyeon chil si-e jibeul nagaya haeyo.
examples.en: I must leave the house at 7 if I don’t want to be late for work.

examples.kr: 야외 활동할 때는 태양으로부터 피부를 보호해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Yawoe hwaldonghal ttaeneun taeyangeurobuteo pibureul bohohaeya haeyo.
examples.en: You must protect your skin from the sun when doing outdoor activities.

examples.kr: 좋은 점수를 받으려면 더 열심히 공부해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Joeun jeomsureul badeuryeomyeon deo yeolsimhi gongbuhaeya haeyo.
examples.en: I must study harder if I want a good grade.

title: ~아/어야지 [a/eoyaji] (I'm going to)
short_explanation: Expresses the speaker's strong intention or determination to do something.
long_explanation: The grammar '~아/어야지 [a/eoyaji]' conveys a strong resolve or plan to carry out an action, much like saying 'I really should...' or 'I’m definitely going to...' in English. It’s often used in first-person contexts.

examples.kr: 진짜 공부를 더 열심히 해야지. 이번에는 꼭 성적을 올릴 거예요.
examples.romaji: Jinjja gongbureul deo yeolsimhi haeyaji. Ibeoneneun kkok seongjeogeul ollil geoyeyo.
examples.en: I really should study harder. This time, I'm definitely going to raise my grades.

examples.kr: 내일 아침에 일어나서 운동해야지. 건강을 위해 더 신경 써야겠어.
examples.romaji: Naeil achime ireonaseo undonghaeyaji. Geongangeul wihae deo singyeong sseoyagesseo.
examples.en: I’m going to wake up tomorrow morning and exercise. I need to take better care of my health.

examples.kr: 이제는 진짜로 담배를 끊어야지. 건강이 너무 걱정돼서 결심했어요.
examples.romaji: Ijeneun jinjjaro dambaereul kkeuneoyaji. Geongangi neomu geokjeongdoe-seo gyeolsimhaesseoyo.
examples.en: Now I really have to quit smoking. I decided because I’m worried about my health.

examples.kr: 엄마에게 전화를 해야지. 꽤 오래 연락하지 못했네.
examples.romaji: Eommaege jeonhwareul haeyaji. Kkwae oraee yeollak-haji mothaetne.
examples.en: I should call my mom. It’s been quite a while since we last talked.

title: ~아/어도 [a/eodo] (Even if)
short_explanation: Used to express 'even if' or 'although'.
long_explanation: '~아/어도 [a/eodo]' conveys a condition that won’t change the outcome or the speaker's viewpoint. Similar to 'even if' or 'no matter how' in English, it shows that whatever happens in the first clause does not alter the second clause.

examples.kr: 여기 음식은 아무리 비싸도 맛있어서 자주 먹어요.
examples.romaji: Yeogi eumsigeun amuri bissado masisseoseo jaju meogeoyo.
examples.en: No matter how expensive the food here is, it's delicious, so I eat it often.

examples.kr: 아무리 빨리 달려도 학교에 늦을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Amuri ppalli dallyeodo hakgyoe neujeul geot gatayo.
examples.en: Even if I run as fast as I can, I think I'll still be late for school.

examples.kr: 내가 아무리 노력해도 그 프로젝트를 끝내기 힘들 것 같아.
examples.romaji: Naega amuri noryeokhaedo geu peurojekteureul kkeutnaegi himdeul geot gata.
examples.en: No matter how much I try, I don’t think I can finish that project.

examples.kr: 운동을 아무리 해도 제 몸에 만족이 안 돼요.
examples.romaji: Undongeul amuri haedo je mome manjoki an dwaeyo.
examples.en: No matter how much I exercise, I'm not satisfied with my body.

title: ~아/어서 [a/eoseo] (Because, so)
short_explanation: Used to express reason or cause: 'because', 'so'.
long_explanation: '~아/어서 [a/eoseo]' is a common conjunctive ending indicating that the first clause is the reason or cause for the second clause. It corresponds to 'because' or 'so' in English and is used in everyday speech and writing.

examples.kr: 머리가 아파서 학교에 갈 수 없었어요.
examples.romaji: Meoriga apaseo hakgyoe gal su eopseosseoyo.
examples.en: I couldn't go to school because I had a headache.

examples.kr: 오늘 날씨가 좋아서 산책하러 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Oneul nalssiga johaseo sanchaekhareo gasseoyo.
examples.en: I went for a walk because the weather was nice today.

examples.kr: 이 영화가 재미있어서 두 번 봤어요.
examples.romaji: I yeonghwaga jaemiisseoseo du beon bwasseoyo.
examples.en: I watched this movie twice because it was interesting.

examples.kr: 그녀는 책을 잃어버려서 슬퍼하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun chaegeul ilheobeoryeoseo seulpeohago isseoyo.
examples.en: She’s sad because she lost her book.

title: ~았/었던 [ass/eossdeon] (Was)
short_explanation: Used to express a past state or condition: 'was'.
long_explanation: The past modifier '~았/었던 [ass/eossdeon]' is used to describe a noun that had a certain state or performed an action in the past. It's similar to saying 'that was...' or 'who was...' in English. The choice of 았/었 depends on the final vowel of the verb stem.

examples.kr: 저는 학교에서 천재였던 학생이었어요. 국어, 수학, 과학, 사회에서 모두 최고 성적을 받았어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hakgyoeseo cheonjaeyeossdeon hagsaengieosseoyo. Gugeo, suhag, gwahak, sahoe-eseo modu choego seongjeogeul badasseoyo.
examples.en: I was a genius student at school, receiving top marks in Korean, math, science, and social studies.

examples.kr: 내가 어릴 때 좋아했던 가수는 신화였어요. 그들의 음악은 항상 제 기억에 남아요.
examples.romaji: Naega eoril ttae johahaessdeon gasuneun Sinhwayeosseoyo. Geudeurui eumageun hangsang je gieoge namayo.
examples.en: The singer I liked when I was young was Shinhwa; their music always remains in my memory.

examples.kr: 우리 아버지는 어렸을 때 가난했던 사람이었는데, 지금은 잘 살고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Uri abeojineun eoryeosseul ttae gananhaessdeon saramieonneunde, jigeumeun jal salgo isseoyo.
examples.en: My father was poor when he was young, but now he is doing well.

examples.kr: 그녀는 학교 시절에는 조용했던 사람이었는데, 지금은 아주 활발해졌어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun hakgyo sijeol-eneun joyonghaessdeon saramieonneunde, jigeumeun aju hwalbalhaejyeosseoyo.
examples.en: She used to be very quiet in school, but now she's become really outgoing.

title: ~았/었어야 했다 [ass/eosseoya haessda] (Should have done)
short_explanation: Used to express regret about something that should have been done in the past but was not.
long_explanation: '~았/었어야 했다 [ass/eosseoya haessda]' shows regret for not doing something that one should have done in the past. It translates to 'should have done' in English. It highlights a missed obligation or opportunity.

examples.kr: 저는 어제 그 일을 했어야 했는데 시간이 없어서 못 했어요. 많이 후회하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun eoje geu ireul haesseoya haenneunde sigani eopseoseo mot haesseoyo. Manhi huhoehago isseoyo.
examples.en: I should have done that work yesterday, but I couldn't because I didn’t have time. I really regret it.

examples.kr: 오늘 아침에 운동을 했어야 했지만 게을러서 안 했어요.
examples.romaji: Oneul achime undongeul haesseoya haetjiman geeulleoseo an haesseoyo.
examples.en: I should have exercised this morning, but I was too lazy and didn't do it.

examples.kr: 당신은 그런 상황에서 따뜻하게 대했어야 했는데 차갑게 굴더군요.
examples.romaji: Dangsineun geureon sanghwangeseo ttatteuthage daehaesseoya haenneunde chagapge guldeogunyo.
examples.en: You should have responded warmly in that situation, but you acted coldly.

examples.kr: 저는 그날 싸움을 어떻게든 피했어야 했는데 결국 못 피했어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun geunal ssaumeul eotteokedeun pihaesseoya haenneunde gyeolguk mot pihaesseoyo.
examples.en: I should have avoided the fight that day somehow, but I ended up not being able to.

title: ~았/었으면 [ass/eosseumyeon] (I wish it were)
short_explanation: '~았/었으면' is used to express a wish or desire for a situation to be different from what it is now.
long_explanation: '~았/었으면 [ass/eosseumyeon]' is a grammar point commonly used to express hypothetical or unreal situations, much like 'I wish...' or 'if only...' in English. It conveys regret or unfulfilled wishes. Formally, it’s the past tense stem plus ‘(으)면’, indicating a desire for something that did not happen.

examples.kr: 저는 어릴 때부터 음악가가 되고 싶었어요. 진짜 음악가가 되었으면 좋겠어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun eoril ttaebuteo eumakga-ga doego sipeosseoyo. Jinjja eumakgaga doeeosseumyeon jokesseoyo.
examples.en: Since I was young, I wanted to become a musician. I wish I really became a musician.

examples.kr: 날씨가 좋았으면 좋겠어요. 그럼 우리가 함께 산책하러 갈 수 있을 텐데요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga johasseumyeon jokesseoyo. Geureom uriga hamkke sanchaekhareo gal su isseul tende-yo.
examples.en: I wish the weather was good. Then, we could go for a walk together.

examples.kr: 마지막으로 그와 만났을 때 좋은 이야기를 들려줬으면 좋겠어요.
examples.romaji: Majimakeuro geuwa mannasseul ttae joheun iyagireul deullyeojwosseumyeon jokesseoyo.
examples.en: I wish I had told him something good when I met him last time.

examples.kr: 약속을 지켰으면 좋겠어요. 그럼 다른 사람들이 저를 더 신뢰할 수 있었을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Yagsogeul jikyeosseumyeon jokesseoyo. Geureom dareun saramdeuri jeoreul deo sinroehal su isseosseul geoyeyo.
examples.en: I wish I had kept my promise. Then other people could have trusted me more.

title: ~았/었을 텐데 [ass/eosseul tende] (I assume it must have been)
short_explanation: Used to express assumption or expectation based on past events.
long_explanation: '~았/었을 텐데 [ass/eosseul tende]' expresses the speaker's speculation or presumption about a past situation. It combines the past tense marker '~았/었' with '을 텐데,' which shows the speaker’s expectation or guess about what must have happened.

examples.kr: 너무 바빴을 텐데 그 일을 다 하지 못했을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Neomu bappasseul tende geu ireul da haji mothaesseul geot gatayo.
examples.en: You must have been really busy, so I assume you didn't manage to finish all that work.

examples.kr: 당신이 그렇게 많이 공부했을 텐데 문제를 풀 수 있었나요?
examples.romaji: Dangsini geureohge manhi gongbuhaesseul tende munjereul pul su isseonnayo?
examples.en: Considering you studied so much, I assume you were able to solve the problems?

examples.kr: 그녀가 너무 행복했을 텐데 왜 눈물을 흘렸을까요?
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga neomu haengbokhaesseul tende wae nunmureul heullyeosseulkkayo?
examples.en: She must have been so happy—why do you think she shed tears?

examples.kr: 날씨가 화창했을 텐데 여행이 재미있었을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga hwachanghaesseul tende yeohaengi jaemiisseosseul geot gatayo.
examples.en: Given the nice weather, I assume the trip was fun.

title: ~았/었다가 [ass/eossdaga] (Was and then)
short_explanation: Expresses that a past situation happened and then changed or was followed by another occurrence.
long_explanation: '~았/었다가 [ass/eossdaga]' denotes a change in state or a sequence of events in the past. It’s often used with action verbs to show one event happened and then a subsequent action followed.

examples.kr: 저는 학교에 갔다가 도서관에서 공부하러 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hakgyoe gassdaga doseogwaneseo gongbuhareo gasseoyo.
examples.en: I went to school, then I headed to the library to study.

examples.kr: 그는 일을 했다가 집으로 돌아갔어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun ireul haessdaga jibeuro doragasseoyo.
examples.en: He worked, and then he went home.

examples.kr: 나는 친구를 만났다가 영화를 보러 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun chingureul mannassdaga yeonghwareul boreo gasseoyo.
examples.en: I met a friend, and then went to see a movie.

examples.kr: 우리는 점심을 먹었다가 공원에서 산책을 했어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun jeomsimeul meogeossdaga gongwoneseo sanchaekeul haesseoyo.
examples.en: We ate lunch, and then took a walk in the park.

title: ~았/었다면 [ass/eossdamyeon] (If it had been)
short_explanation: Used for hypothetical past situations: 'If it had been'.
long_explanation: '~았/었다면' imagines a different outcome for a past situation. '다면' after the past tense indicates an unreal or counterfactual condition, often expressing regret or speculation about what could have happened.

examples.kr: 그때 그의 조언을 들었다면 지금 상황이 달라졌을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Geuttae geuui jo-eoneul deureossdamyeon jigeum sanghwangi dallajyeosseul geoyeyo.
examples.en: If I had listened to his advice then, the situation now would be different.

examples.kr: 자기의 실수를 인정했다면 큰 난관에 봉착하지 않았을 텐데.
examples.romaji: Jagiui silsureul injeonghaessdamyeon keun nangwane bongchak-haji anhasseul tende.
examples.en: If he had acknowledged his mistake, he wouldn't have ended up facing such a big difficulty.

examples.kr: 어제 비가 왔다면 축구 경기가 취소되었을까요?
examples.romaji: Eoje biga watdamyeon chukgu gyeonggiga chwisodoeeosseulkkayo?
examples.en: If it had rained yesterday, would the soccer match have been cancelled?

examples.kr: 더 빨리 도착했다면 그녀를 만날 수 있었을 텐데.
examples.romaji: Deo ppalli dochakhaessdamyeon geunyeoreul mannal su isseosseul tende.
examples.en: If I had arrived earlier, I could've met her.

title: ~으면 좋겠다 [eumyeon joketda] (I hope, it would be good if)
short_explanation: Expresses a wish or hope for a certain situation or result.
long_explanation: '~으면 좋겠다 [eumyeon joketda]' is a common structure for stating what the speaker hopes will happen or would be nice if it happened. It often translates to 'I hope...' or 'It would be good if...' in English.

examples.kr: 날씨가 좋으면 좋겠다. 그래야 꽃놀이가 더 즐거울 것 같아.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga joeumyeon joketda. Geuraeya kkotnoliga deo jeulgeoul geot gata.
examples.en: I hope the weather is good, so that the flower viewing will be more enjoyable.

examples.kr: 시험을 잘 보면 좋겠다. 그럼 학기가 끝나면 여행을 갈 수 있을 것 같아.
examples.romaji: Siheomeul jal bomyeon joketda. Geureom hakgiga kkeutnamyeon yeohaengeul gal su isseul geot gata.
examples.en: I hope I do well on the exam, so I can take a trip when the semester ends.

examples.kr: 아픈 친구가 빨리 나으면 좋겠다. 그럼 같이 놀러 갈 수 있겠지.
examples.romaji: Apeun chinguga ppalli naeumyeon joketda. Geureom gachi nolreo gal su igetji.
examples.en: I hope my friend recovers quickly, then we can go out together.

examples.kr: 코로나가 끝나면 좋겠다. 그럼 다시 일상으로 돌아갈 수 있을 것 같아.
examples.romaji: Koronaga kkeutnamyeon joketda. Geureom dasi ilsangeuro doragal su isseul geot gata.
examples.en: I hope COVID ends soon, so we can return to normal life.

title: ~으면서도 [eumyeonseodo] (While, but still)
short_explanation: Expresses a contradiction: 'while', 'but still', 'even though'.
long_explanation: '~으면서도 [eumyeonseodo]' is used to link two contrasting facts. It shows that although the first situation is true, there is another fact that runs counter to it, akin to 'even though' or 'but still' in English.

examples.kr: 그는 건강에 좋지 않으면서도 매일 패스트푸드를 먹어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun geongange jotji anheumyeonseodo maeil paeseuteu-pudeureul meogoyo.
examples.en: He keeps eating fast food every day, while knowing it's not good for his health.

examples.kr: 너무 바쁘면서도 친구들과 시간을 내서 만나곤 해요.
examples.romaji: Neomu bappeumyeonseodo chingudeulgwa siganeul naeseo mannagon haeyo.
examples.en: She’s extremely busy, yet she still manages to make time to meet her friends.

examples.kr: 아파트 값이 비싸면서도 계속 오르고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Apateu gabs-i bissamyeonseodo gyesok orago isseoyo.
examples.en: Apartment prices keep rising even though they're already expensive.

examples.kr: 인터넷이 느리면서도 필요한 정보는 얻을 수 있어서 잘 이용하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Inteonesi neurimyeonseodo pilyohan jeongboneun eodeul su isseoseo jal iyonghago isseoyo.
examples.en: Even though the internet is slow, I can still get the information I need, so I keep using it.

title: ~을/ㄹ 거예요 [eul/l geoyeyo] (Going to, will)
short_explanation: Expresses a future plan or intention—similar to 'going to' or 'will' in English.
long_explanation: '~을/ㄹ 거예요 [eul/l geoyeyo]' is used to indicate that something will happen or that the speaker plans or expects something in the future. It can also express the speaker's assumption about the future. If the verb stem ends in a consonant, use '을 거예요'; if it ends in a vowel, use 'ㄹ 거예요.'
formation: Verb stem + 을 거예요 (consonant-ending) / ㄹ 거예요 (vowel-ending)

examples.kr: 저는 이번 주말에 쇼핑을 갈 거예요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun ibeon jumale syopingeul gal geoyeyo.
examples.en: I'm going to go shopping this weekend.

examples.kr: 내일 비가 올 거예요.
examples.romaji: Naeil biga ol geoyeyo.
examples.en: It will probably rain tomorrow.

examples.kr: 엄마는 저녁으로 김치찌개를 만들 거예요.
examples.romaji: Eommaneun jeonyeogeuro gimchijjigaereul mandeul geoyeyo.
examples.en: Mom will make kimchi stew for dinner.

examples.kr: 우리 팀은 다음 대회에서 반드시 이길 거예요.
examples.romaji: Uri timeun daeum daehwoeseo bandeusi igil geoyeyo.
examples.en: Our team will definitely win at the next competition.

title: ~을/ㄹ게요 [eul/l geyo] (I will)
short_explanation: Used to express a future intention, promise, or decision (often more immediate/personal than '~을/ㄹ 거예요').
long_explanation: '~을/ㄹ게요 [eul/l geyo]' is a verb ending in Korean that conveys the speaker’s **willingness**, **promise**, or **decision** to do something (often in response to the listener or a situation). Compared to '~을/ㄹ 거예요,' which can simply state a future plan, '~을/ㄹ게요' more strongly implies the speaker’s **own resolve** or reaction to the listener. The form '을게요' is used after stems ending in a **consonant**, and 'ㄹ게요' is used after stems ending in a **vowel**.
formation: Verb stem + 을게요 (after consonant) / ㄹ게요 (after vowel)

examples.kr: 저는 내일 학교에 가서 친구를 만날게요. 오랜만에 보는 친구라 정말 기대돼요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun naeil hakgyoe gaseo chingureul mannalgeyo. Oranmane boneun chingura jeongmal gidadwaeyo.
examples.en: I will go to school tomorrow and meet my friend. I’m really looking forward to seeing them after so long.

examples.kr: 매일 밤 10시에 자러 갈게요. 건강을 위해 더 일찍 자야 할 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Maeil bam yeolshi-si-e jareo galgeyo. Geongangeul wihae deo iljjik jaya hal geot gatayo.
examples.en: I’ll go to bed at 10 p.m. every night. I think I need to sleep earlier for my health.

examples.kr: 주말에는 운동을 할게요. 운동하면 확실히 몸이 좋아지니까요.
examples.romaji: Jumalen undongeul halgeyo. Undonghamyeon hwaksilhi momi joajinikayo.
examples.en: I’ll exercise on the weekend. Working out definitely makes my body healthier.

examples.kr: 내일 밥을 사러 갈게요. 집에 먹을 게 별로 없네요.
examples.romaji: Naeil babeul sareo galgeyo. Jibe meogeul ge byeollo eopneyo.
examples.en: I’ll go buy some food tomorrow. There’s hardly anything to eat at home.

examples.kr: 음악에 푹 빠져서 피아노 배울게요. 시간이 좀 걸려도 열심히 해 보려고요.
examples.romaji: Eumage pook ppajyeoseo piano baeulgeyo. Sigani jom geollyeodo yeolsimhi hae boryeogoyeyo.
examples.en: I’m really into music, so I’ll learn piano. It might take some time, but I plan to work hard at it.

examples.kr: 새로운 언어 공부할게요. 시간이 걸리겠지만 꼭 도전해 보고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Saeroun eoneo gongbuhalgeyo. Sigani geolligetjiman kkok dojeonhae bogo sipeoyo.
examples.en: I’ll study a new language. It might take a while, but I really want to try.

examples.kr: 맛있는 음식을 만들고 싶어서 요리 클래스를 들을게요.
examples.romaji: Masinneun eumsigeul mandeulgo sip-eoseo yori keullaeseureul deureulgeyo.
examples.en: I want to make delicious food, so I’ll take a cooking class.

examples.kr: 다음 주 시간 내서 친구들이랑 영화 볼게요.
examples.romaji: Da-eum ju sigan naeseo chingudeul-irang yeonghwa bolgeyo.
examples.en: I’ll make time next week to watch a movie with my friends.

title: ~을/ㄹ까요? [eul/l kkayo?] (Shall we?)
short_explanation: Used to suggest or propose an action to do together or to ask for the listener's opinion.
long_explanation: '~을/ㄹ까요? [eul/l kkayo?]' is a Korean ending used to propose an activity (often including the listener) or to ask for the listener's suggestion. It translates roughly as 'Shall we...?' or 'Should we...?' in English. It is typically used in polite, but not extremely formal, conversations.
formation:
If the verb stem ends in a consonant: Verb stem + 을까요?
If the verb stem ends in a vowel: Verb stem + ㄹ까요?

examples.kr: 함께 저녁을 먹을까요? 맛있는 음식을 파는 식당을 알아요.
examples.romaji: Hamkke jeonyeogeul meogeulkkayo? Masinneun eumsigeul paneun sikdangeul arayo.
examples.en: Shall we have dinner together? I know a restaurant that serves delicious food.

examples.kr: 영화를 볼까요? 오늘 좋은 영화가 상영 중이래요.
examples.romaji: Yeonghwareul bolkkayo? Oneul joheun yeonghwaga sangyeong jungiraeyo.
examples.en: Shall we watch a movie? A good one is showing today.

examples.kr: 주말에 여행을 갈까요? 분위기 전환이 필요해 보이는데요.
examples.romaji: Jumale yeohaengeul galkkayo? Bunwigi jeonhwani piryohae boineundeyo.
examples.en: Shall we go on a trip this weekend? It seems we need a change of scene.

examples.kr: 우리 산책할까요? 날씨가 정말 좋아 보이네요.
examples.romaji: Uri sanchaekhalkkayo? Nalssiga jeongmal joa boineyo.
examples.en: Shall we go for a walk? The weather looks really nice.

title: ~을/ㄹ 때 [eul/l ttae] (When)
short_explanation: Used to indicate the point in time or occasion when something occurs.
long_explanation: '~을/ㄹ 때 [eul/l ttae]' means 'when' in English. You attach it to a verb stem to specify the time or context in which an action happens. '을 때' is used after a consonant-ending stem; 'ㄹ 때' after a vowel-ending stem.
formation: Verb stem + 을 때 (if ending in consonant) / Verb stem + ㄹ 때 (if ending in vowel)

examples.kr: 책을 읽을 때는 조용한 곳에서 읽는 게 좋아요.
examples.romaji: Chaekeul ilgeul ttaeneun joyonghan gos-eseo ilgneun ge johayo.
examples.en: When reading a book, I prefer a quiet place.

examples.kr: 친구를 만날 때 항상 많이 웃어요.
examples.romaji: Chingureul mannal ttae hangsang manhi useoyo.
examples.en: I always laugh a lot when I meet my friend.

examples.kr: 시험 볼 때 늘 긴장돼요.
examples.romaji: Siheom bol ttae neul ginjangdwaeyo.
examples.en: I always get nervous when I take a test.

examples.kr: 비가 올 때는 우산을 꼭 챙기세요.
examples.romaji: Biga ol ttaeneun usaneul kkok chaenggiseyo.
examples.en: Take an umbrella when it rains.

title: ~을/ㄹ 듯하다 [eul/l deuthada] (Seems like)
short_explanation: Used to express the idea that something appears or feels like something else, or that one is guessing based on observation.
long_explanation: '~을/ㄹ 듯하다 [eul/l deuthada]' is used to convey that something seems or feels a certain way, based on the speaker’s inference or impression. It's similar to 'it seems that...' or 'it looks like...' in English.

examples.kr: 그는 변한 것 같아 보이지만, 사실 옛날 그대로인 듯해요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun byeonhan geot gata boijiman, sashil yetnal geudaeroin deuthaeyo.
examples.en: He seems to have changed, but in fact, he appears just the same as before.

examples.kr: 오늘은 겨울인 것처럼 춥네요. 가을이라고 해도 겨울 같은 느낌이 드는 듯해요.
examples.romaji: Oneureun gyeoulin geotcheoreom chumneyo. Gaeurirago haedo gyeoul gateun neukkimi deuneun deuthaeyo.
examples.en: It's cold today like winter. Even though it's autumn, it feels like winter.

examples.kr: 그의 표정을 보니 깊은 생각에 잠긴 듯해요.
examples.romaji: Geuui pyojeongeul boni gip-eun saenggage jamgin deuthaeyo.
examples.en: Judging by his expression, it seems he’s deep in thought.

examples.kr: 그녀는 웃을 것처럼 보였지만, 뭔가 고민이 있는 듯했어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun useul geotcheoreom boyeotjiman, mwonga gomini inneun deuthaesseoyo.
examples.en: She looked like she was about to smile, but it seemed like something was on her mind.

title: ~을/ㄹ 만하다 [eul/l manhada] (Worth doing)
short_explanation: Expresses that something is worthwhile or justifiable to do or experience.
long_explanation: '~을/ㄹ 만하다' is used to say that a certain action or experience is valuable enough to be done, or 'worth it.' It implies the speaker's judgment that the effort, cost, or time involved is justified.

examples.kr: 이 케이크는 비싸지만 맛있어서 사 먹을 만해요.
examples.romaji: I keikeuneun bissajiman masisseoseo sa meogeul manhaeyo.
examples.en: This cake is expensive, but it's so delicious that it's worth buying.

examples.kr: 이 영화는 상영 시간이 길지만 정말 재미있어서 볼 만해요.
examples.romaji: I yeonghwaneun sangyeong sigani giljiman jeongmal jaemiisseoseo bol manhaeyo.
examples.en: This movie has a long running time, but it's really fun, so it's worth watching.

examples.kr: 그 밴드 공연 티켓은 비싸지만 그들의 음악은 꼭 들어볼 만해요.
examples.romaji: Geu baendeu gongyeon tikeseun bissajiman geudeurui eumageun kkok deureobol manhaeyo.
examples.en: The band’s concert tickets are expensive, but their music is definitely worth hearing.

examples.kr: 이 게임은 설치하는 데 오래 걸려도 해볼 만해요.
examples.romaji: I geimeun seolchihaneun de orae geollyeodo haebol manhaeyo.
examples.en: Even though this game takes a long time to install, it's worth trying.

title: ~을/ㄹ 수록 [eul/l surok] (The more...)
short_explanation: Shows that as one condition increases or continues, another condition also changes proportionally.
long_explanation: '~을/ㄹ 수록 [eul/l surok]' is used to express the idea that the more the first action or state intensifies, the more the second action or state does too. It corresponds to 'the more... the more...' in English.

examples.kr: 한국어를 많이 공부할수록 한국 문화를 더 잘 이해하게 돼요.
examples.romaji: Hangukeoreul manhi gongbuhalsurok hanguk munhwareul deo jal ihaehage dwaeyo.
examples.en: The more you study Korean, the better you understand Korean culture.

examples.kr: 여기에 오래 있을수록 이 도시가 점점 더 좋아져요.
examples.romaji: Yeogie orae isseulsurok i dosiga jeomjeom deo joajyeoyo.
examples.en: The longer I stay here, the more I like this city.

examples.kr: 매일 걸을수록 건강이 좋아져요.
examples.romaji: Maeil georeulsurok geongangi joajyeoyo.
examples.en: The more I walk every day, the healthier I become.

examples.kr: 커피를 많이 마실수록 잠이 덜 오는 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Keopireul manhi masilsurok jami deol oneun geot gatayo.
examples.en: The more coffee I drink, the less sleepy I feel.

title: ~을/ㄹ 줄 알다 [eul/l jul alda] (Know how to)
short_explanation: Used to indicate that someone knows how to perform an action or is aware of a fact.
long_explanation: '~을/ㄹ 줄 알다 [eul/l jul alda]' often translates to 'know how to do something' or 'know that...' in English. It indicates knowledge, skill, or awareness of a particular action or fact.
formation: Verb in dictionary form + 을/ㄹ 줄 알다

examples.kr: 저는 한글을 읽을 줄 알아서 한국 드라마를 자막 없이 볼 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangeureul ilgeul jul araseo hanguk deuramareul jamak eopsi bol su isseoyo.
examples.en: I know how to read Hangul, so I can watch Korean dramas without subtitles.

examples.kr: 아빠가 요리를 잘할 줄 알았는데 어제 저녁 준비할 때 많은 문제가 생겼어요.
examples.romaji: Appaga yorireul jalhal jul aratneunde eoje jeonyeok junbihal ttae manheun munjega saenggyeosseoyo.
examples.en: I thought Dad knew how to cook well, but there were many problems when he made dinner last night.

examples.kr: 저는 그녀가 한국인인 줄 알고 한국어로 말했어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun geunyeoga hangugin-in jul algo hangugeoro malhaesseoyo.
examples.en: I knew she was Korean, so I spoke to her in Korean.

examples.kr: 우리 강아지는 명령을 따를 줄 알아서 아주 잘 훈련되어 있어요.
examples.romaji: Uri gangajineun myeongnyeongeul ttareul jul araseo aju jal hunryeondoeeo isseoyo.
examples.en: Our puppy knows how to follow commands, so it's well trained.

title: ~을/ㄹ지 [eul/lji] (Whether or not)
short_explanation: Used to express uncertainty or doubt: 'whether or not'.
long_explanation: '~을/ㄹ지 [eul/lji]' indicates the speaker is unsure about an event or outcome, similar to 'whether' or 'whether or not' in English. It often appears in indirect questions or conditional statements involving doubt or possibility.

examples.kr: 아빠가 오늘 저녁에 집에 올지 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Appaga oneul jeonyeoge jibe olji moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: I’m not sure whether Dad will come home tonight.

examples.kr: 그녀가 내일 파티에 올지 안 올지 궁금해요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga naeil patie olji an olji gunggeumhaeyo.
examples.en: I’m curious whether she’ll come to the party tomorrow or not.

examples.kr: 날이 따뜻해질지 아직 확신이 없어요.
examples.romaji: Nari ttatteuthaejilji ajik hwaksini eopseoyo.
examples.en: I’m not sure yet whether it’ll get warmer.

examples.kr: 당신이 제안을 받아들일지 안 받아들일지 알 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: Dangsini jean-eul badadeurilji an badadeurilji al su eopseoyo.
examples.en: I don’t know whether you will accept the proposal or not.

title: ~을/ㄹ지도 모르다 [eul/ljido moreuda] (Might)
short_explanation: This is used to express uncertainty or possibility.
long_explanation: '~을/ㄹ지도 모르다 [eul/ljido moreuda]', or simply 'might' in English, is a grammar pattern used to represent the speaker's uncertainty or to express the possibility of a future event or condition. Depending on context, it can imply that something might or might not happen. The verb is conjugated according to the level of formality and respect required.

examples.kr: 내일 비가 올지도 모르니까 우산을 가져가세요.
examples.romaji: Naeil biga oljido moreunikka usaneul gajyeogaseyo.
examples.en: It might rain tomorrow, so take an umbrella.

examples.kr: 그는 다음 회의에 참석할지도 모릅니다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun daeum hoeuie chamseokhaljido moreumnida.
examples.en: He might attend the next meeting.

examples.kr: 저는 아마 내년에 한국으로 이사할지도 몰라요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun ama naenyeon-e hangug-euro isahaljido mollayo.
examples.en: I might move to Korea next year.

examples.kr: 그녀가 그 소식을 알고 있을지도 모르죠.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga geu sosigeul algo isseuljido moreujyo.
examples.en: She might know that news.

title: ~을/ㄹ지라도 [eul/ljirado] (Even if)
short_explanation: Used to say 'even if'; 'no matter how/if'; nonetheless.
long_explanation: '~을/ㄹ지라도 [eul/ljirado]' is a conditional form used in Korean to express the meaning of 'even if', 'no matter how', or 'nonetheless'. It indicates that the expected result will remain unchanged regardless of the given condition.

examples.kr: 문제가 어렵지라도 포기하지 않고 계속 풀어볼게요.
examples.romaji: Munjega eoryeobjirado pogihaji anhgo gyesok pulleobolgeyo.
examples.en: Even if the problem is difficult, I won't give up and I'll keep trying to solve it.

examples.kr: 비가 오지라도 갈 생각이에요, 제가 중요한 미팅이 있어요.
examples.romaji: Biga ojirado gal saenggakieyo, jaega jungyohan mitingi isseoyo.
examples.en: Even if it's raining, I'm planning to go because I have an important meeting.

examples.kr: 버스가 빨리 오지라도, 무리해서 뛰지 않을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Beoseuga pparei ojirado, murihaseo ttwiji aneul geoyeyo.
examples.en: Even if the bus comes quickly, I won't run excessively.

examples.kr: 비용이 많이 들지라도 좋은 품질의 제품을 만들고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Biyongi manhi deuljirado joheun pumjilui jepumeul mandeulgo sippeoyo.
examples.en: Even if it costs a lot, I want to make a product of good quality.

title: ~을/ㄹ지 몰라 [eul/lji molla] (Maybe)
short_explanation: Used to express uncertainty or doubt; 'maybe', 'might', 'I don't know if'.
long_explanation: '~을/ㄹ지 몰라 [eul/lji molla]' is a grammar form used to indicate doubts, uncertainties, or suppositions. It can be translated as 'maybe', 'might', or 'I don’t know if' in English. This form is typically used when the speaker is unsure of something or wishes to present a speculative premise.

examples.kr: 그녀가 내일 학교에 올지 몰라, 요즘 아프다니까.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga naeil haggyoe olji molla, yojeum apeudanikka.
examples.en: Maybe she will come to school tomorrow; she said she's been sick lately.

examples.kr: 이 물건을 사려고 했는데, 아직 돈이 충분할지 몰라요.
examples.romaji: I mulgeoneul saryeogo haetneunde, ajik doni chungbunhalji mollayo.
examples.en: I was planning to buy this item, but I don't know if I have enough money.

examples.kr: 내일 비가 올지 몰라서 우산을 준비해야겠어요.
examples.romaji: Naeil biga olji mollaseo usaneul junbihaeyagesseoyo.
examples.en: I should prepare an umbrella because it might rain tomorrow.

examples.kr: 어떤 옷을 입을지 몰라서 세 가지를 준비했어요.
examples.romaji: Eoddeon oseul ibeulji mollaseo se gajireul junbihaesseoyo.
examples.en: I prepared three different options because I'm not sure which clothes to wear.

title: ~을래요 [eullaeyo] (Want to)
short_explanation: Used to express the speaker's desire or intention to do something.
long_explanation: '~을래요 [eullaeyo]' is a verb ending used in Korean to express an intention, suggestion, or polite proposal from the speaker's perspective. It denotes that the speaker wants or would like to do something and is often used when making plans or suggestions. Note that it is typically used for the speaker’s own actions.

examples.kr: 저는 오늘 집에서 영화를 볼래요, 밖으로 나가기는 너무 추워요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun oneul jibeseo yeonghwareul bollae, bakkeuro nagagineun neomu chuwoyo.
examples.en: I want to watch a movie at home today because it's too cold to go out.

examples.kr: 우리 이번 주말에 캠핑장에 가서 텐트를 칠래요, 어떻게 생각해요?
examples.romaji: Uri ibeon jumal-e keampingjang-e gaseo tent-eul chillae, eotteoke saengkaekhae?
examples.en: How about we go to the campground this weekend and pitch a tent?

examples.kr: 나는 저녁으로 한 끼만 먹을래요, 이미 배가 불러서 더 먹지 않을래요.
examples.romaji: Naneun jeonyeoge han kkiman meogeullae, imi baega bulleoseo deo meokji anheullae.
examples.en: I want to have just one meal for dinner because I'm already full and don't want to eat more.

examples.kr: 나는 이번 주말에 연극 보러 갈래요, 한국 문화를 좋아해서 결심했어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun ibeon jumal-e yeongeuk boreo gallae, hanguk munhwareul joahaseo gyeolsimhaesseoyo.
examples.en: I've decided to go see a play this weekend because I like Korean culture.

title: ~을 리가 없다 [eulliga eopda] (It's unlikely that)
short_explanation: This expression is used to indicate that a certain situation is unlikely or impossible to happen.
long_explanation: '~을 리가 없다 [eulliga eopda]' is a speculative expression used in Korean to indicate that something is improbable or implausible based on the speaker's judgment. It expresses disbelief or doubt about the possibility of an event occurring and is often used to contrast a hypothetical situation with reality.

examples.kr: 이것이 사실일 리가 없어요, 그가 그런 일을 저지를 사람이 아니에요.
examples.romaji: Igeosi sasilliga eobs-eoyo, geuga geuleon il-eul jeojileul salam-i ani-eyo.
examples.en: It's unlikely that this is true; he's not the type of person to do such a thing.

examples.kr: 그녀가 날 잊어버릴 리가 없어요, 우리 너무 오래 같이 지냈거든요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga nal ijeobeoriliga eobs-eoyo, uli neomu olae gati jinaessgeodeunyo.
examples.en: It's unlikely that she would forget me; we've been together for so long.

examples.kr: 저는 이 계약서를 사인할 리가 없어요, 제가 아직 조건들을 모두 이해하지 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun i gyeagseoreul sainhal liga eobseoyo, jega ajik jogeondeul-eul modu ihaehaji moshaesseoyo.
examples.en: It's unlikely that I will sign this contract because I still do not fully understand the terms.

examples.kr: 그가 오늘 올 리가 없어요, 그거 알고 있어요, 그가 아픈 걸.
examples.romaji: Geuga oneul ol riga eopseoyo, geugeo algo isseoyo, geuga apeun geol.
examples.en: It's unlikely that he will come today; everyone knows that he's sick.

title: ~을수록 [eulsurok] (The more)
short_explanation: Used to express 'the more...the more', indicating an increasing degree or intensity.
long_explanation: The grammar point '~을수록 [eulsurok]' is used in Korean to indicate that as one condition intensifies, another condition increases proportionately. It is equivalent to the English phrase 'the more...the more', showing a direct proportional relationship between two events or states.

examples.kr: 한국어를 공부할수록, 한국 문화에 대해 더 많이 이해할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Hanguk-eoreul gongbu halsurok, hanguk munhwa-e daehae deo mani ihaehal su isseoyo.
examples.en: The more I study Korean, the more I can understand Korean culture.

examples.kr: 이 노래를 많이 들을수록, 더 좋아지는 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: I noraereul mani deureulsurok, deo joajineun geot gatayo.
examples.en: The more I listen to this song, the more I seem to like it.

examples.kr: 날이 점점 더워질수록, 아이스크림이 더 많이 팔려요.
examples.romaji: Nal-i jeomjeom deoweojilsurok, aiseukeurimi deo manhi pallyeoyo.
examples.en: The hotter the day gets, the more ice cream is sold.

examples.kr: 사람들이 친환경 제품을 사용할수록, 환경보호에 더 많은 기여를 할 수 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Saramdeuri chinhwangyeong jepumeul sayonghalsurok, hwangyeong bohoe deo manheun giyeoreul hal su itsseumnida.
examples.en: The more people use eco-friendly products, the more they can contribute to environmental protection.

title: ~을지언정 [euljieonjeong] (Even though)
short_explanation: This phrase is used to indicate 'even though' or 'despite'.
long_explanation: '~을지언정 [euljieonjeong]' is a conjunction in Korean that conveys the meaning of 'even though', 'even if', or 'despite'. It is used to present a contrasting situation or fact that exists despite the previous condition. While more common in formal or written language, it is also useful in everyday contexts and for tests like TOPIK.

examples.kr: 그것이 그에게 굉장히 중요한 일일지언정, 그는 결코 그것에 손을 대지 않았다.
examples.romaji: Geugeosi geuege goengjanghi jungyohan iriljieonjeong, geuneun gyeolko geugeos-e son-eul daeji anh-assda.
examples.en: Even though that was very important to him, he never laid a hand on it.

examples.kr: 그가 부자일지언정, 평소에 아주 절약하는 습관이 있다.
examples.romaji: Geuga bujailjieonjeong, pyeongso-e aju jeolyaghamyeon seubgwan-i issda.
examples.en: Even though he is rich, he has a habit of being very thrifty.

examples.kr: 시험이 어려울지언정, 학생들은 열심히 공부했어요.
examples.romaji: Siheom-i eoryeouljieonjeong, haksaengdeureun yeolshimhi gongbuhaesseoyo.
examples.en: Even though the exam was difficult, the students studied hard.

examples.kr: 그 공원이 아름다울지언정, 저녁에는 위험이 많으니 조심하세요.
examples.romaji: Geu gong-woni aleumdauljieonjeong, jeonyeogeneun wihemi manh-euni joshimhaseyo.
examples.en: Even though that park is beautiful, it becomes dangerous in the evening, so be careful.

title: ~이나 [ina] (Or, whether)
short_explanation: Used to indicate choice or alternatives, typically attached to nouns.
long_explanation: '~이나 [ina]' is a particle in Korean attached to nouns to indicate alternatives or choices. It functions similarly to 'or' in English and is used to present different options or possibilities. The proper formation is with a noun followed by (이)나.

examples.kr: 사과나 오렌지, 그 중 하나만 골라주세요.
examples.romaji: Sagwana orenji, geu jung hanaman gollajuseyo.
examples.en: Please choose either an apple or an orange.

examples.kr: 영화나 드라마를 볼까요?
examples.romaji: Yeonghwa na deuramareul bolkkayo?
examples.en: Shall we watch a movie or a drama?

examples.kr: 버스나 택시를 타세요.
examples.romaji: Beoseu na taegsi-reul taseyo.
examples.en: Take either a bus or a taxi.

title: ~이든 [ideun] (Either or)
short_explanation: Used to present two or more choices; 'either', 'or'.
long_explanation: '~이든 [ideun]' is a connecting ending used in Korean to present two or more alternatives or choices. It is analogous to 'either' or 'or' in English and is commonly used when the speaker considers all options equally acceptable.

examples.kr: 피자든 파스타든 무엇을 먹어도 좋아요, 둘 다 맛있으니까요.
examples.romaji: Pijadeun pasteudeun mueoseul meogeodo joayo, dul da masisseunikka yo.
examples.en: Whether it's pizza or pasta, either is fine because both are delicious.

examples.kr: 운동이든 요가든 모든 활동이 건강에 좋아요.
examples.romaji: Undongideun yogadeun modeun hwaldongi geongang-e joayo.
examples.en: Whether it’s exercise or yoga, all activities are good for your health.

examples.kr: 친구들하고 영화보기이든, 책을 읽는 것이든 저는 행복해요.
examples.romaji: Chingudeulhago yeonghwabogideun, chaeg-eul ilgneun geosideun jeoneun haengbokhaeyo.
examples.en: Whether it's watching movies with friends or reading a book, I am happy.

examples.kr: 떡볶이이든, 부대찌개든 저는 둘 다 좋아하는 음식입니다.
examples.romaji: Tteokbokkiideun, budaejjigaedeun jeoneun dul da joahaneun eumsigibnida.
examples.en: Whether it's tteokbokki or budae jjigae, I like both foods.

title: ~이라도 [irado] (At least, even if)
short_explanation: Used to express 'at least' or 'even if'; refers to a minimum or lesser expectation.
long_explanation: The '~이라도 [irado]' grammar point is used in Korean to express a minimum expectation or to settle for a lesser alternative when the preferred option isn’t available. It conveys the idea of conceding to a less ideal scenario and is often used when faced with challenges or limited choices.

examples.kr: 이 작은 선물이라도 받아주세요. 저는 더 좋은 선물을 줄 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: I jageun seonmurirado badajuseyo. Jeoneun deo joheun seonmureul jul su eobseoyo.
examples.en: Please accept this small gift at least. I can’t give a better gift.

examples.kr: 미안하다고 말이라도 해 줬으면 좋겠어요.
examples.romaji: Mianhadago marirado hae jwosseumyeon johgesseoyo.
examples.en: I wish you would at least say you’re sorry.

examples.kr: 비록 그녀가 나를 싫어한다고 해도, 친구로서라도 계속 만나고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Birok geunyeoga nareul sirheohanda고 haedo, chinguroseorado gyesok mannago sippeoyo.
examples.en: Even if she dislikes me, I want to keep seeing her, at least as friends.

examples.kr: 신발은 원하는 색깔이 없으니까, 흰색이라도 사겠어요.
examples.romaji: Sinbal-eun wonhaneun saekkkal-i eobseunikka, huinsaekirado sa gesseoyo.
examples.en: Since the shoes don’t come in the color I want, I’ll buy the white ones at least.

title: ~이라는 것 [iraneun geot] (The thing called)
short_explanation: This phrase is used to refer to or define something that was mentioned earlier.
long_explanation: '~이라는 것 [iraneun geot]' is a sentence structure used in Korean to refer to or define a particular thing or idea. It is often used in explanations to elaborate on a concept or to highlight specific characteristics.

examples.kr: 사랑이라는 것이 어떤 것인지, 많은 사람들이 꼭 알고 싶어 하는 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Sarangiraneun geosi eotteon geotinji, maneun saramdeul-i kkok algo sip-eo haneun geot gatayo.
examples.en: It seems like many people really want to know what this thing called love is.

examples.kr: 성공이라는 것은 많은 노력과 헌신 없이는 이루어질 수 없는 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Seonggongiraneun geoseun maneun noryeokgwa heonsin eobsineun irueojil su eobseun geosibnida.
examples.en: Success cannot be achieved without a lot of effort and dedication.

examples.kr: 행복이라는 것은 개인마다 다른 의미를 갖고 있기 때문에 정의하기가 어렵습니다.
examples.romaji: Haengbogiraneun geoseun gaenmada dareun uimireul gajgo issgie ttaemune jeonguihagiga eoryeopseumnida.
examples.en: It’s difficult to define happiness because it holds different meanings for each person.

examples.kr: 배려라는 것은 자신의 행동이 다른 사람에게 어떤 영향을 미치는지 고려하는 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Baerylaneun geoseun jasinui haengdong-i daleun saram-ege eotteon yeonghyang-eul michineunji golyeohaneun geosibnida.
examples.en: Consideration means taking into account how one’s actions affect others.

title: ~이라면 [iramyeon] (If it’s the case that)
short_explanation: Used to imagine a certain situation; 'if it’s the case that'.
long_explanation: '~이라면 [iramyeon]' is used in Korean to pose a hypothetical scenario or situation. It is akin to saying 'if it’s the case that' in English and is used to speculate about consequences or outcomes.

examples.kr: 여기가 정말로 유명한 관광 명소라면, 왜 이렇게 사람이 없나요?
examples.romaji: Yeogiga jeongmallo yumyeonghan gwangwangmyeongso-iramyeon, wae ireohge saram-i eomnayo?
examples.en: If this is really a famous tourist spot, why are there so few people?

examples.kr: 정말로 그런 일이 있다면, 어떻게 대처해야 할지 고민해봐야겠어요.
examples.romaji: Jeongmallo geureon iri itdamyeon, eotteohge daecheohaeya halji gominhae bwayagesseoyo.
examples.en: If such a thing really happens, I’ll have to think about how to deal with it.

examples.kr: 학교를 그만두고 싶다면, 미래를 어떻게 설계할지 생각해봐야 할 거예요.
examples.romaji: Hakgyoreul geumandugo sipdamyeon, miraereul eotteohge seolgyehalji saenggakhae bwayahal geoyeyo.
examples.en: If you want to quit school, you should think about how to plan your future.

examples.kr: 니가 내 친구라면, 왜 나를 배신하고 다른 친구들에게 나쁜 이야기를 퍼뜨렸나요?
examples.romaji: Niga nae chingura myeon, wae nareul baesinhago dareun chingudeul-ege nappeun iyagireul peotteuryeossnayo?
examples.en: If you are my friend, why did you betray me and spread bad stories about me to other friends?

title: ~이래 [irae] (Like this, in this manner)
short_explanation: Used to express 'like this' or 'in this manner', referring to a current state or condition.
long_explanation: '~이래 [irae]' is used in Korean to describe the state, condition, or manner in which something exists or is done. It emphasizes the way in which a situation is and is often used when commenting on the current status or behavior.

examples.kr: 날씨가 이래서는 놀러갈 수가 없어요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga iraeseoneun nolleogal suga eobseoyo.
examples.en: We can’t go out to play when the weather is like this.

examples.kr: 내가 이래 있으면, 유명해질 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Naega irae isseumyeon, yumyeonghaejil geot gatayo.
examples.en: If I remain like this, I think I’ll become famous.

examples.kr: 이 집이 이래서는 팔 수가 없어.
examples.romaji: I jibi iraeseoneun pal suga eobseo.
examples.en: We can’t sell the house when it’s like this.

examples.kr: 자네가 이래서는 운동선수로 출중한 성과를 이룰 수 있을 것 같군.
examples.romaji: Janaega iraeseoneun undongseonsu-ro chuljunghan seonggwareul irul su isseul geot gatgun.
examples.en: If you keep it up like this, you can achieve outstanding results as an athlete.

title: ~이랑 [irang] (And, with)
short_explanation: Used to connect two nouns, expressing 'and' or 'with'.
long_explanation: '~이랑 [irang]' is a common connector in Korean that joins two nouns together to show a relationship or connection. It is used informally in various sentence types regardless of the politeness level.

examples.kr: 저는 친구이랑 같이 영화를 보러 갈 계획이에요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun chinguirang gachi yeonghwaleul boreo gal gyehoegieyo.
examples.en: I plan to go see a movie with my friend.

examples.kr: 우리는 피자이랑 치킨을 주문했어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun pijairang chikin-eul jumunhaesseoyo.
examples.en: We ordered pizza and chicken.

examples.kr: 저는 언니이랑 쇼핑몰에서 옷을 샀어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun eonniirang syopingmol-eseo oseul sasseoyo.
examples.en: I bought clothes at the shopping mall with my sister.

examples.kr: 나는 고양이랑 개랑 키우고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun goyangi-rang gae-rang kiugo isseoyo.
examples.en: I am raising both a cat and a dog.

title: ~이러하다 [ireohada] (Like this)
short_explanation: Used to describe the state or condition of a subject as 'like this'.
long_explanation: '~이러하다 [ireohada]' is a descriptive verb used in Korean to indicate that someone or something is in a particular state or condition. It emphasizes the current manner or appearance of the subject.

examples.kr: 친구의 태도가 너무 이러하더니, 모두가 당황했어요.
examples.romaji: Chingui taedoga neomu ireohadeoni, moduga danghwanghaesseoyo.
examples.en: My friend’s attitude was like this, so everyone was taken aback.

examples.kr: 요즘 세상이 이러하다니, 믿기 어렵네요.
examples.romaji: Yojum sesangi ireohadani, midgi eoryeobneyo.
examples.en: It’s hard to believe that the world is like this these days.

examples.kr: 그녀의 행동이 이러하다 보니, 사람들의 신뢰를 잃었어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoui haengdong-i ireohada boni, saramdeul-ui sinroereul ilheosseoyo.
examples.en: Because her behavior was like this, she lost people’s trust.

examples.kr: 그가 이러하다고 하니, 정말 실망스러워요.
examples.romaji: Geuga ireohadago hani, jeongmal silmangseureowoyo.
examples.en: When he says he’s like this, it’s really disappointing.

title: ~이런/그런/저런 [ireon/geureon/jeoreon] (This kind of/That kind of/That kind over there)
short_explanation: Used to describe the type or category of something; 'this kind of', 'that kind of', or 'that kind over there'.
long_explanation: ~이런/그런/저런 [ireon/geureon/jeoreon] are demonstrative adjectives used in Korean to classify or describe things by their type or category. '이런' refers to something near the speaker, '그런' to something near the listener or already mentioned, and '저런' to something distant.

examples.kr: 이런 상황에서는 어떻게 대처해야 할 지 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Ireon sanghwang-eseoneun eotteohge daecheohaeya halji moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: I don’t know how to deal with this kind of situation.

examples.kr: 그런 분위기를 좋아하지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Geureon bunwigireul johahaji anhayo.
examples.en: I don’t like that kind of atmosphere.

examples.kr: 저런 옷을 입으면 어떻게 생각할까요?
examples.romaji: Jeoreon ot-eul ib-eumyeon eotteohge saenggakhalkkayo?
examples.en: What would you think if I wore that kind of clothes over there?

examples.kr: 이런 생각을 하지 말아야겠어요.
examples.romaji: Ireon saenggageul haji marayagesseoyo.
examples.en: I shouldn’t have such thoughts.

title: ~이므로 [imuro] (Because, since)
short_explanation: Used to express a reason or cause; 'because', 'since'.
long_explanation: '~이므로 [imuro]' is a conjunction used in Korean to indicate a reason or cause, corresponding to 'because' or 'since' in English. It typically introduces the cause for a conclusion or result. This form is formal and is often used in written Korean, such as in official documents, academic writing, or news reports.

examples.kr: 내일은 월요일이므로, 오늘 밤에 일찍 잠에 들어야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Naeil-eun woryoil-imuro, oneul bam-e iljjik jam-e deul-eoya hamnida.
examples.en: Because tomorrow is Monday, we have to go to bed early tonight.

examples.kr: 그는 학점이 낮아서 교수님께 장학금을 받을 수 없었기 때문에 금전적인 문제가 있었어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun hakjeom-i naj-aseo gyosunimkke janghakgeum-eul bad-eul su eobs-eossgi ttaemune geumjeonjeog-in munje-ga iss-eoss-eoyo.
examples.en: He had financial difficulties because his grades were low and he couldn’t receive a scholarship from his professor.

examples.kr: 우리는 시간이 없기 때문에, 저녁 식사를 축소해야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Urineun sigan-i eobs-gi ttaemune, jeonyeog siksa-reul chugsohaeya hamnida.
examples.en: Because we are short on time, we have to cut down on dinner.

examples.kr: 그 직원은 업무능력이 매우 불량이므로, 우리는 그에게 경고를 발했습니다.
examples.romaji: Geu jigwon-eun eobmu neunglyeog-i maeu bullyang-imuro, urineun geu-ege gyeonggo-reul balhaessseubnida.
examples.en: We issued a warning to the employee because his job performance was very poor.

title: ~이야 [iya] (Is, informal declaration)
short_explanation: '~이야' is used as an informal, casual way to state or declare something.
long_explanation: '~이야' is a verb modifier in Korean used to assert, declare, or express a fact, situation, or feeling in an informal context. It attaches to the stem of a noun, verb, or adjective and is common in daily conversation among close friends or people of similar age. It is not recommended to use this form with elders or superiors as it may sound rude.

examples.kr: 나는 배가 고프다고 생각했더니 아니었어, 김밥을 사 왔어, 이제 배가 고프지 않아.
examples.romaji: Naneun baega gopeudago saenggakhaetdeoni anieosseo, gimbabeul sa wass-eo, ije baega gopeuji anha.
examples.en: I thought I was hungry, but I wasn’t—I bought gimbap, and now I’m not hungry.

examples.kr: 오늘 날씨가 참 좋아, 하늘이 맑고 파란 하늘이 보여.
examples.romaji: Oneul nalssiga cham joa, haneul-i malgo paran haneul-i boyeo.
examples.en: The weather is really nice today; you can see the clear, blue sky.

examples.kr: 여기가 내 집이야, 조금 작지만 아늑하고 편안해.
examples.romaji: Yeogiga nae jib-iya, jogeum jagjiman aneugago pyeonanhae.
examples.en: This is my house—it's small but cozy and comfortable.

examples.kr: 너가 진짜로 좋아하는 거야, 말해 줘서 고마워.
examples.romaji: Neoga jinjja-ro joahaneun geoya, malhae jwoseo gomawo.
examples.en: You really like it, thanks for telling me.

title: ~이지만 [ijiman] (But, although)
short_explanation: Used to convey a contrast or contradiction; 'but', 'although'.
long_explanation: '~이지만 [ijiman]' is used in Korean to indicate a contrast or contradiction between two statements or facts. It is similar to 'but' or 'although' in English: despite what is stated in the first clause, the information in the second clause still holds true. In casual contexts, the shortened form '-지만' may be used on its own.

examples.kr: 평소에 드라마를 잘 안 보는 편이지만 이 드라마는 흥미로워서 꼭 봐야겠어요.
examples.romaji: Pyeongsoe deurameureul jal an boneun pyeonijiman i deurameuneun heungmirowoseo ggok bwayagesseoyo.
examples.en: I usually don’t watch dramas, but this drama is so interesting that I must watch it.

examples.kr: 오늘 날씨가 좋지만 바빠서 나가지 못할 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Oneul nalssiga joijiman bappa-seo nagaji mothael geot gatayo.
examples.en: The weather is good today, but I don’t think I can go out because I’m busy.

examples.kr: 당신은 젊지만 이미 많은 경험을 가지고 있네요.
examples.romaji: Dangsineun jeolmjiman imi maneun gyeongheom-eul gajigo itneyo.
examples.en: You are young, but you already have a lot of experience.

examples.kr: 제가 팀장이지만 모든 결정을 혼자서 하지는 않아요.
examples.romaji: Jega timjangijiman modeun gyeoljeongeul honjaseo hajineun anhayo.
examples.en: I am the team leader, but I don’t make all the decisions by myself.

title: ~이후 [ihu] (After, since)
short_explanation: Used to express the meaning of 'after' or 'since'.
long_explanation: '~이후 [ihu]' is a postposition used in Korean to indicate the time after a specific point or event. It corresponds to 'after' or 'since' in English and is often used to refer to the period following a particular event.

examples.kr: 중학교 졸업 이후로 처음으로 친구들과 모였어요.
examples.romaji: Jung hakgyo joreop ihu-ro cheoeum-euro chingu-deul gwa moyeosseoyo.
examples.en: I got together with my friends for the first time since graduating from middle school.

examples.kr: 그녀가 도시에 이사 간 이후로 그녀를 본 적이 없어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga dosi-e isa gan ihu-ro, geunyeoreul bon jeok-i eobs-eoyo.
examples.en: I haven’t seen her since she moved to the city.

examples.kr: 아침 식사 이후로 아무것도 먹지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Achim siksa ihu-ro amugeosdo meogeoss-eoyo.
examples.en: I haven’t eaten anything since breakfast.

examples.kr: 회의 이후로 사무실에서 일을 계속하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Hoeui ihu-ro samusil-eseo ireul gyesokhago isseoyo.
examples.en: I’ve been continuing my work in the office since the meeting.

title: ~인즉 [injeuk] (In other words, that is to say)
short_explanation: Used to rephrase or further explain a preceding statement; 'in other words', 'that is to say'.
long_explanation: '~인즉 [injeuk]' is a connective ending used in Korean to rephrase or further explain a preceding statement or idea. It is similar to saying 'in other words' or 'that is to say' in English, and it helps the speaker clarify their point.

examples.kr: 이 작업이 정말 어려워요, 인즉, 전문가가 아니면 제대로 해낼 수 없습니다.
examples.romaji: I jak-eob-i jeongmal eoryeowoyo, injeuk, jeonmunga-ga animyeon jedaelo hael su eobs-eossseubnida.
examples.en: This task is really hard—in other words, if you’re not an expert, you can’t do it properly.

examples.kr: 그녀는 내일 결혼합니다, 인즉, 그녀는 더 이상 독신이 아닙니다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun naeil gyeolhonhamnida, injeuk, geunyeoneun deo isang dokshin-i anida.
examples.en: She is getting married tomorrow; that is to say, she is no longer single.

examples.kr: 박물관 직원은 저를 입장하게 허락하지 않았습니다. 인즉, 저는 규정을 위반했습니다.
examples.romaji: Bakmulgwan jigwon-eun jeoreul ipjanghage heorak haji anhassseubnida. injeuk, jeoneun gyujeong-eul wibanhaessseubnida.
examples.en: The museum staff did not allow me to enter—in other words, I violated the rules.

examples.kr: 우리는 연구에 참여하였습니다, 인즉, 우리는 어떤 학문적인 기여를 했습니다.
examples.romaji: Ulineun yeongu-e chamyeohayeossseubnida, injeuk, ulineun eotteon hakmunjeog-in giyeoleul hayeossseubnida.
examples.en: We participated in the research—in other words, we made an academic contribution.

title: ~자 [ja] (Let's)
short_explanation: Used to propose doing something; 'Let's'.
long_explanation: '~자 [ja]' is an ending particle in Korean used to suggest or propose doing an action together. It corresponds loosely to 'Let's' in English and is used in informal or casual contexts among friends, colleagues, or family members. The subject is usually omitted, and the verb appears in its dictionary (base) form.

examples.kr: 날씨가 너무 좋으니까, 우리 산에 등산하러 가자.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga neomu jo-eunikka, uri sane deungsanhareo gaja.
examples.en: The weather is so good, let's go mountain climbing.

examples.kr: 오늘이 일요일이므로, 교회에 가서 기도하자.
examples.romaji: Oneul-i illyoil-imyeo, gyohoe-e gaseo gidohaja.
examples.en: Since today is Sunday, let's go to church and pray.

examples.kr: 밥은 다 먹었으니, 이제 커피 한 잔 마시러 카페에 가자.
examples.romaji: Babeun dameogeoss-euni, ije keopi han jan masireo kape-e gaja.
examples.en: Now that we’ve finished eating, let's go to the cafe and have a cup of coffee.

examples.kr: 길고 지루한 하루였으니, 이제 보드게임 하나 플레이하며 편히 쉬자.
examples.romaji: Gilgo jiruhan haru-yeoss-euni, ije bodeugeim hana peulleihamyeo pyeonhi swija.
examples.en: It’s been a long and boring day; let's relax by playing a board game.

title: ~자마자 [jamaja] (As soon as)
short_explanation: Used to express that one action occurs immediately after another.
long_explanation: The '~자마자 [jamaja]' grammar point emphasizes that an action or event occurs immediately after a preceding one. It is equivalent to 'as soon as' in English and implies a very short time gap between the two actions.

examples.kr: 저는 집에 돌아오자마자 식사를 준비했어요, 왜냐하면 너무 배고파서 바로 음식을 먹고 싶었기 때문이에요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun jibe doraojamaja siksa-reul junbihaesseoyo, waenyahamyeon neomu baegopaseo baro eumsigeul meokgo sipheossgi ttaemunieyo.
examples.en: As soon as I returned home, I prepared a meal because I was so hungry and wanted to eat right away.

examples.kr: 엄마가 전화를 끊자마자 잠을 청하러 갔어요, 어제는 너무 늦게 잠들었기 때문에 기분이 피곤했어요.
examples.romaji: Eommaga jeonhwareul kkeunjamaja jameul cheonghareo gasseoyo, eojeoneun neomu neutge jamdeureossgi ttaemunieyo, gibun-i pigonhaesseoyo.
examples.en: As soon as Mom hung up the phone, I went to sleep because I was tired from going to bed too late yesterday.

examples.kr: 그는 일어나자마자 커피를 마셔요, 그는 아침에 커피 없이 일을 시작할 수 없다고 말해요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun ireonajamaja keopireul masyeoyo, geuneun achime keopi eobsi ireul sijakhal su eobsdago malhaeyo.
examples.en: As soon as he wakes up, he drinks coffee—he says he can’t start work without it in the morning.

examples.kr: 비가 오자마자 우산을 들고 도서관에 갔어요, 왜냐하면 수업 자료를 찾기로 결정했기 때문이에요.
examples.romaji: Biga ojamaja usaneul deulgo doseogwan-e gasseoyo, waenyahamyeon sueop jaryoreul chajgiro gyeoljeonghaetgi ttaemunieyo.
examples.en: As soon as it started raining, I grabbed an umbrella and went to the library because I decided to look for class materials.

title: ~전에/전까지 [jeone/jeonkkaji] (Before/by the time of)
short_explanation: Used to indicate that an action or state is completed or occurs before a specific time.
long_explanation: '~전에 [jeone]' and '전까지 [jeonkkaji]' are used to denote that an action or state is completed before a certain time or event. '~전에' is used when the action stops before that time, while '전까지' indicates that the action continues up to that point.

examples.kr: 저는 학교에 가기 전에 아침을 먹어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hakgyo-e gagi jeone achimeul meogeoyo.
examples.en: I eat breakfast before going to school.

examples.kr: 그녀는 출근하기 전까지 연락할게요. 아마 연락 올 때까지 기다리세요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun chulgeunhagi jeonkkaji yeollakhalgeyo. Ama yeollak ol ttaekkaji gidariseyo.
examples.en: She will contact you before going to work. Please wait until she contacts you.

examples.kr: 기차가 도착하기 전에 짐을 싸야 해요.
examples.romaji: Gichaga dochakhagi jeone jimeul ssayahae.
examples.en: We have to pack our luggage before the train arrives.

examples.kr: 우리가 집에 돌아오기 전까지 조심하세요.
examples.romaji: Uriga jibe doraogi jeonkkaji josimhaseyo.
examples.en: Take care until we return home.

title: ~정도 [jeongdo] (About, Approximately)
short_explanation: Used to express an approximate quantity, degree, or extent; 'about', 'approximately'.
long_explanation: '~정도 [jeongdo]' is a particle used in Korean to indicate an approximation of a quantity, amount, degree, or level. It conveys a sense of estimation similar to 'about' or 'approximately' in English, and it is commonly used when the exact figure is unknown or when giving a rough idea.

examples.kr: 이 문제를 해결하는 데는 한 시간쯤 정도 걸릴 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: I munje-reul haegyeolhaneun de-neun han sigan jjeum jeongdo geollil geot gatayo.
examples.en: It will probably take about an hour or so to solve this problem.

examples.kr: 진짜로 영화를 봤다면 네 시간 정도가 걸렸을 것이에요.
examples.romaji: Jinjja-ro yeonghwaleul bwatdamyeon ne sigan jeongdo-ga geollyeosseul geosieyo.
examples.en: If you really watched the movie, it would have taken about four hours.

examples.kr: 이 과제를 완료하려면 한 달 정도의 시간이 필요합니다.
examples.romaji: I gwaje-reul wanlyohamyeon han dal jeongdoeui sigan-i pilyohabnida.
examples.en: Completing this assignment requires about a month’s time.

examples.kr: 그의 성과를 평가하려면 최소한 10가지 이상의 요소를 고려해야 하고, 이것은 대략 한 시간 정도의 시간을 요구합니다.
examples.romaji: Geuui seonggwareul pyeonggahamyen choesohan 10gaji isang-ui yosoreul goreohaya hago, igeoseun daerak han sigan jeongdoeui sigan-eul yoguhabnida.
examples.en: Evaluating his performance requires considering at least 10 or more factors, and this takes approximately an hour.

title: ~제 [je] (Although, even if)
short_explanation: Used to express 'although' or 'even if'. It signifies that despite the preceding condition, the outcome differs from what is expected.
long_explanation: '~제 [je]' is a conjunction used in Korean to express contrasting or unexpected outcomes. It is similar in meaning to 'although,' 'even if,' or 'even though' in English and functions much like '-지만' but is used in more formal or polite contexts.

examples.kr: 그녀가 아프제 일을 계속했어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga apeuje ireul gyesokhaesseoyo.
examples.en: Although she was sick, she continued to work.

examples.kr: 동생이 어리제 그에게 맡길 수 있는 일이 많아요.
examples.romaji: Dongsaengi eorije geuege matgil su issneun iri manhayo.
examples.en: Even though my younger sibling is young, there are many tasks that can be entrusted to him.

examples.kr: 비가 내리제 나는 외출했어요.
examples.romaji: Biga naerije naneun weochulhaesseoyo.
examples.en: Even though it was raining, I went out.

examples.kr: 시험 문제가 어렵제, 제가 좋아하는 과목이었기 때문에 재미있게 풀었어요.
examples.romaji: Siheom munjega eoryeopje, jega joahaneun gwamogiyeotgi ttaemune jaemiissge pulleosseoyo.
examples.en: Even though the test questions were difficult, I enjoyed solving them because it was a subject I liked.

title: ~조차 [jocha] (Even)
short_explanation: Expresses 'even' or 'to the extent that', reinforcing a strong emphasis or unexpected inclusion.
long_explanation: '~조차 [jocha]' is used in Korean to stress that something is included to an extreme degree or under surprising circumstances. It often conveys a sense of unexpectedness or limits reached.

examples.kr: 그는 돈조차 너무 좋아해서 친구들에게 돈을 빌려주지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun donjocha neomu joahaseo chingudeurege doneul billyeojugi anhayo.
examples.en: He likes money so much that he doesn't even lend money to his friends.

examples.kr: 저는 이번 주말에는 집에서 나가는 것조차 귀찮아요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun ibeon jumaleneun jibeseo naganeun geotjocha gwicheonhayo.
examples.en: This weekend, I even find going out of the house annoying.

examples.kr: 이번 시험은 너무 어려워서 문제를 읽는 것조차 어려웠어요.
examples.romaji: Ibeon siheomeun neomu eoryeowoseo munjeleul ilgneun geotjocha eoryeowosseoyo.
examples.en: This exam was so hard that even reading the problems was difficult.

examples.kr: 가게에 사람이 너무 많아서 메뉴를 선택하는 것조차 힘들었어요.
examples.romaji: Gagee sarami neomu manaseo menyureul seontaekhaneun geotjocha himdeureosseoyo.
examples.en: There were so many people in the store that even choosing the menu was difficult.

title: ~존재하다 [jonjaehada] (To exist)
short_explanation: '존재하다' is used to express the existence or presence of someone or something.
long_explanation: '존재하다 [jonjaehada]' is a Korean verb that indicates that someone or something exists or is present. It can be used for concrete objects, people, or even abstract concepts like hope, ideas, or problems. In its present form, it becomes '존재해요.'

examples.kr: 영화 속에 존재하는 그런 판타지 세계가 현실에서도 존재하길 바래요.
examples.romaji: Yeonghwa soge jonjaehaneun geureon pantaji segye-ga hyeonsil-eseodo jonjaehagil baraeyo.
examples.en: I hope that such a fantasy world that exists in the movie also exists in reality.

examples.kr: 사랑이 과연 영원히 존재하는 건지 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Sarangi gwayeon yeongwonhi jonjaehaneun geonji moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: I am not sure if love really exists forever.

examples.kr: 이 세상에 완벽한 사람이 존재하는지 의심스러워요.
examples.romaji: I sesang-e wanbyeokhan sarami jonjaehaneunji uisimseureowoyo.
examples.en: I doubt that a perfect person exists in this world.

examples.kr: 이 방에는 저 말고 다른 사람들이 존재하지 않아요.
examples.romaji: I bange-neun jeo malgo dareun saramdeuri jonjaehaji anhayo.
examples.en: Except for me, no other people exist in this room.

title: ~줄 알다 [jul alda] (Thought that)
short_explanation: '~줄 알다' is used to express an assumption or expectation that turns out to be incorrect.
long_explanation: '~줄 알다' is a Korean grammar pattern used when the speaker assumed or expected something to be a certain way, only to find that the reality was different. It is often translated as 'I thought that...' and conveys a sense of surprise or disappointment when the expectation does not match the outcome.

examples.kr: 날씨가 좋을 줄 알았는데, 갑자기 비가 와서 실망했어요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga joheul jul alatneunde, gapjagi biga waseo silmanghaesseoyo.
examples.en: I thought the weather would be nice, but it suddenly started raining and I was disappointed.

examples.kr: 그 사람이 나를 좋아할 줄 알았는데, 아니었어요.
examples.romaji: Geu sarami nareul joahal jul alatneunde, anieosseoyo.
examples.en: I thought that person liked me, but that was not the case.

examples.kr: 시험 문제가 어려울 줄 알았는데, 생각보다 쉬웠어요.
examples.romaji: Siheom munjega eoryeoul jul alatneunde, saenggakboda swiweosseoyo.
examples.en: I thought the test questions would be difficult, but they were easier than I expected.

examples.kr: 진행이 늦을 줄 알았는데, 빨리 끝났어요.
examples.romaji: Jinhaengi neujeul jul alatneunde, ppalli kkeutnasseoyo.
examples.en: I thought the proceedings would be slow, but they ended quickly.

title: ~즉시 [jeukshi] (Immediately, at once)
short_explanation: Used to indicate that something happens immediately or without delay.
long_explanation: '~즉시 [jeukshi]' is an adverb in Korean used to express that an action occurs immediately after a preceding event. It emphasizes the immediacy of the subsequent action, similar to 'as soon as' or 'the moment' in English.

examples.kr: 그녀가 방에 들어온 즉시, 저는 선물을 주려고 했어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga bange deureoon jeukshi, jeoneun seonmureul juryeogo haesseoyo.
examples.en: As soon as she entered the room, I intended to give her a gift.

examples.kr: 메시지를 받으면 즉시 반응해야 합니다, 그렇지 않으면 그 사람은 기다리게 됩니다.
examples.romaji: Mesijireul bateumyeon jeukshi baneunghaeya hamnida, geureohji anheumyeon geu sarameun gidarige doebnida.
examples.en: You should respond immediately upon receiving a message, otherwise that person will be left waiting.

examples.kr: 그날 밤, 그녀가 보고서를 완료할 즉시 확인했어요.
examples.romaji: Geunal bam, geunyeoga bogoseoreul wanryohal jeukshi hwaginhaesseoyo.
examples.en: That night, I confirmed it as soon as she finished her report.

examples.kr: 회의가 끝난 즉시, 사진을 찍으러 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Hoeuiga kkeutnan jeukshi, sajineul jjigeureo gasseoyo.
examples.en: I went to take a picture immediately as soon as the meeting ended.

title: ~지 않다 [ji anta] (Negative form)
short_explanation: Negates the action implied by the verb; equivalent to 'not' in English.
long_explanation: The grammar point '~지 않다 [ji anta]' is the standard and polite way to convert a verb into its negative form in Korean. By attaching '지 않다' to the verb stem, it changes the meaning to indicate that the action is not performed. This form is commonly used in both formal and casual contexts.

examples.kr: 나는 오늘 학교에 가지 않았어요, 왜냐하면 비가 너무 많이 와서 출근이 불가능했어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun oneul hakgyo-e gaji anhasseoyo, waenyahamyeon biga neomu mani wasseo chulgeuni bulganeunghaesseoyo.
examples.en: I did not go to school today because it rained so much that going was impossible.

examples.kr: 저는 일반적으로 고기를 먹지 않아요, 왜냐하면 나는 채식주의자이기 때문입니다.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun ilbanjeogeuro gogireul meokji anhayo, waenyahamyeon naneun chaesikjuuijaigi ttaemunibnida.
examples.en: I generally do not eat meat because I am a vegetarian.

examples.kr: 민지는 그 영화를 보지 않았어요, 왜냐하면 그녀는 그것이 너무 무서워하기 때문입니다.
examples.romaji: Minjineun geu yeonghwareul boji anhasseoyo, waenyahamyeon geunyeoneun geugeosi neomu museowohagi ttaemunibnida.
examples.en: Minji did not watch that movie because she finds it too scary.

examples.kr: 그들은 내 생일 파티에 오지 않았어요, 왜냐하면 그들은 바빴기 때문입니다.
examples.romaji: Geudeureun nae saengil patie oji anhasseoyo, waenyahamyeon geudeureun bappatgi ttaemunibnida.
examples.en: They did not come to my birthday party because they were busy.

title: ~지 않아도 되다 [ji anado dweda] (Do not have to)
short_explanation: Indicates that something does not have to be done or is not necessary.
long_explanation: '~지 않아도 되다 [ji anado dweda]' is used when you want to express that there is no obligation or necessity to do something. It emphasizes the optional nature of an action or state.

examples.kr: 너무 걱정하지 않아도 돼, 모든 것이 잘 될 거야.
examples.romaji: Neomu geokjeonghaji anado dwae, modeun geosi jal doel geoya.
examples.en: You don't have to worry too much; everything will be fine.

examples.kr: 지금 당장 먹지 않아도 돼, 나중에 먹어도 괜찮아.
examples.romaji: Jigeum dangjang meokji anado dwae, najunge meogeodo gwaenchanha.
examples.en: You don't have to eat right now; you can eat later.

examples.kr: 다른 사람들이 하는 것을 따라하지 않아도 돼, 너 자신을 믿어.
examples.romaji: Dareun saramdeuli haneun geoseul ttarahaji anado dwae, neo jasineul mideo.
examples.en: You don't have to follow what others are doing; believe in yourself.

examples.kr: 어디로 가지 않아도 돼, 집에서 편하게 쉬어.
examples.romaji: Eodiro gaji anado dwae, jibeseo pyeonhage swieo.
examples.en: You don't have to go anywhere; just rest comfortably at home.

title: ~지 않을까 [ji anheulkka] (Perhaps)
short_explanation: Used to express a guess, supposition, or conjecture; 'perhaps', 'maybe'.
long_explanation: '~지 않을까 [ji anheulkka]' is a common ending in Korean used to express an educated guess or prediction. It is similar to saying 'perhaps,' 'maybe,' or 'I wonder if...' in English, based on the speaker's available information.

examples.kr: 오늘 밤에 비가 오지 않을까 싶어요, 하늘이 완전히 회색이니까.
examples.romaji: Oneul bame biga oji anheulkka sip-eoyo, haneul-i wanjeonhi hoesaeg-inikka.
examples.en: I think it might rain tonight since the sky is completely gray.

examples.kr: 그녀가 내 생각을 하고 있지 않을까 궁금해요, 오랜만에 만났으니까.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga nae saenggag-eul hago itji anheulkka gung-geumhaeyo, oraenman-e mannat-eunikka.
examples.en: I wonder if she is thinking about me since we met after a long time.

examples.kr: 내일 시험이 취소되지 않을까 기대해요, 어제는 너무 늦게 공부했으니까.
examples.romaji: Naeil siheom-i chwisodoejji anh-eulkka gidaehaeyo, eojeneun neomu neutge gongbuhaess-eunikka.
examples.en: I wonder if tomorrow's exam might get canceled because I stayed up too late studying yesterday.

examples.kr: 지금 집에 가면 아빠가 저녁을 만들어 놓지 않을까 생각해요, 오늘은 제 생일이니까.
examples.romaji: Jigeum jib-e gamyeon appa-ga jeonyeog-eul mandeul-eo nohji anheulkka saenggaghaeyo, oneul-eun je saeng-il-inikka.
examples.en: I wonder if my dad might have prepared dinner if I go home now, since it's my birthday today.

title: ~지만 [jimyeon] (But, however)
short_explanation: Used to express contrast or contradiction; 'but', 'however'.
long_explanation: '~지만 [jimyeon]' is a conjunction used in Korean to connect two clauses where the second clause presents a contrast or unexpected result compared to the first. It is similar to 'but' or 'however' in English.

examples.kr: 오늘의 날씨는 흐리지만, 기분은 매우 좋아요.
examples.romaji: Oneul-ui nalssineun heulijiman, gibuneun maeu joayo.
examples.en: Even though today's weather is cloudy, I feel very good.

examples.kr: 그 영화는 재미없었지만, 그 배우의 연기는 훌륭했어요.
examples.romaji: Geu yeonghwaneun jaemiopseotjiman, geu baeuui yeongineun hulryunghaesseoyo.
examples.en: Although the movie wasn't interesting, the actor's performance was great.

examples.kr: 고기를 좋아하지만, 가끔 비건 음식을 먹습니다.
examples.romaji: Gogireul johahajiman, gaggeum bigeon eumsigeul meogseumnida.
examples.en: I like meat, but sometimes I eat vegan food.

examples.kr: 아들은 친절하지만, 때때로 소심해집니다.
examples.romaji: Adeureun chinjeolhajiman, ttaettaero sosimhaejibnida.
examples.en: My son is kind, but sometimes he becomes timid.

title: ~지요 [jiyo] (~right?, isn't it?)
short_explanation: Used to echo or affirm the argument; '~right?', 'isn't it?'.
long_explanation: The ending '~지요 [jiyo]' is used in Korean to echo or affirm the statement preceding it. This is similar to English phrases like 'right?' or 'isn't it?'. The speaker uses this ending to seek agreement or affirmation from the listener. It is usually used in declarative or interrogative sentences and can be used in both formal and informal contexts.

examples.kr: 오늘 날씨가 정말 좋지요, 태양이 환하게 빛나고, 바람도 시원하니까요.
examples.romaji: Oneul nalssiga jeongmal jotjiyo, taeyangi hwanhage bitnago, baramdo siwonhanikkayo.
examples.en: The weather today is really nice, right? The sun is shining brightly, and the wind is refreshing.

examples.kr: 새로 오픈한 그 카페의 커피가 맛있지요, 한 번 가 볼 만하다고 생각해요.
examples.romaji: Saero openhan geu kapeui keopi-ga matitjiyo, hanbeon ga bol mandahago saenggakhaeyo.
examples.en: The coffee at the newly opened café is delicious, right? I think it's worth a visit.

examples.kr: 강아지가 정말 귀엽지요, 매일 보고 싶어져요.
examples.romaji: Gangajiga jeongmal gwiyeopjiyo, maeil bogo sipheojyeoyo.
examples.en: The puppy is really cute, right? I want to see it every day.

examples.kr: 우리 아이가 키가 크지요, 아빠를 닮아서 그런 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Uri aiga kiga keutjiyo, appa-reul dalma-seo geureon geot gatayo.
examples.en: Our child is really tall, right? I think it is because he looks like his father.

title: ~진 않다 [jin anta] (Not really)
short_explanation: This pattern is used when something is not exactly or not demonstrably true.
