long_explanation: The ~진 않다 [jin anta] form is used when describing a condition or situation that is not fully or exactly as described by the preceding adjective or verb. It is equivalent to the English expressions 'not really', 'not quite', 'not necessarily', or 'not exactly'. The level of negation is softer than the standard negative form and is often used when the speaker does not want to fully agree or disagree.

examples.kr: 그 곳은 많이 더워지진 않지만, 여름에는 항상 습해요.
examples.romaji: Geu goseun mani deowojijin antjiman, yeoreumeun hangsang seubhaeyo.
examples.en: It doesn't get very hot there, but it is always humid in summer.

examples.kr: 나는 그녀를 좋아하진 않아도 그녀의 사고 방식을 존경해요.
examples.romaji: Naneun geunyeoreul johahajin anado, geunyeoui sago bangsigeul jongyeonghaeyo.
examples.en: I don't particularly like her, but I respect her way of thinking.

examples.kr: 요즘 너무 바빠서 체육관에 자주 가지 않아도, 집에서 운동은 해요.
examples.romaji: Yojeum neomu bappaseo cheyukgane jaju gaji anado, jibeseo undongeun haeyo.
examples.en: I am too busy these days to go to the gym regularly, but I do exercise at home.

examples.kr: 이 식당은 꼭 기억에 남을 정도는 아니지만, 음식은 맛있어요.
examples.romaji: I sikdangeun kkok gieoge nameul jeongdoneun anijiman, eumsigeun masisseoyo.
examples.en: This restaurant may not be particularly memorable, but the food is delicious.

title: ~처럼 [cheoreom] (Like, as if)
short_explanation: Used to express similarities or comparisons; 'like', 'as if'.
long_explanation: '~처럼 [cheoreom]' is a postposition used to indicate that something is similar to or behaves in the same manner as the mentioned subject or object. It conveys a sense of comparison or simile, similar to 'like' or 'as if' in English.

examples.kr: 그녀는 나비처럼 춤을 춰요, 그녀의 리듬감과 움직임은 정말 아름다워요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun nabicheoreom chumeul chwoyo, geunyeoui rideumgamgwa umjigimeun jeongmal areumdawoyo.
examples.en: She dances like a butterfly; her sense of rhythm and movements are really beautiful.

examples.kr: 아버지는 항상 든든한 나무처럼 가족을 지켜줘요.
examples.romaji: Abeojineun hangsang deundeunhan namucheoreom gajogeul jikyeojwoyo.
examples.en: My father always protects the family like a sturdy tree.

examples.kr: 그는 배가 고파서 사자처럼 고기를 먹었어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun baega gopaseo sajacheoreom gogireul meogeosseoyo.
examples.en: He was so hungry, he ate the meat like a lion.

examples.kr: 진실이 들키자, 그가 마치 쥐를 잡은 고양이처럼 미소를 지었어.
examples.romaji: Jinsili deultkija, geuga machi jwireul jabeun goyangicheoreom misoreul jieosseo.
examples.en: When the truth was exposed, he smiled as if he were a cat that had caught a mouse.

title: ~아서/어서 [aseo/eoseo] (So, therefore)
short_explanation: Used to connect two clauses and show that the second clause is the result of the first; 'so', 'therefore'.
long_explanation: The ending '-아서/어서' is used in Korean to express cause and effect. It connects two clauses in a sentence where the second clause is the result or effect of what is described in the first clause. It is often translated as 'so' or 'therefore' in English, conveying a sense of consequence or reason.

examples.kr: 저는 배가 너무 고파서 밥을 두 그릇이나 먹었어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun baega neomu gopaseo babeul du geureusina meogeosseoyo.
examples.en: I was so hungry that I ate two bowls of rice.

examples.kr: 친구가 너무 늦게 와서 영화가 이미 시작했어요.
examples.romaji: Chinguga neomu neutge wasseo, yeonghwaga imi sijakhaesseoyo.
examples.en: Because my friend came too late, the movie had already started.

examples.kr: 수업이 너무 어려워서 공부를 많이 했어요.
examples.romaji: Sueobi neomu eoryeowoseo, gongbureul mani haesseoyo.
examples.en: The class was so difficult that I studied a lot.

examples.kr: 날씨가 너무 추워서 집에만 있었어요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga neomu chuweoseo, jibeoman isseosseoyo.
examples.en: The weather was so cold that I just stayed at home.

title: ~것 같다 [geot gatda] (Seems like)
short_explanation: Expresses the speaker's guess or inference about a situation based on some evidence.
long_explanation: The construction '~것 같다' is used in Korean to express a guess or inference about a situation. The speaker uses it when they have some evidence or basis for their inference, even if the situation is not directly observable. It is equivalent to saying 'seems like' or 'appears to be' in English.

examples.kr: 나는 오늘 아침부터 배가 아파. 아마 매운 음식을 먹어서 아픈 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Naneun oneul achimbuteo baega apa. Ama maeun eumsigeul meogeoseo apeun geot gatayo.
examples.en: I've had a stomachache since this morning. It seems like it's because I ate spicy food.

examples.kr: 그녀가 갑자기 분위기가 달라진 것 같아요. 무슨 일이 있었는지 아는 사람이 없어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga gapjagi bunwigiga dallajin geot gatayo. Museun iri isseossneunji aneun sarami eopseoyo.
examples.en: She seems to have suddenly changed her mood. No one knows what happened.

examples.kr: 어제 비가 왔는데 오늘은 반짝반짝한 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Eoje biga watneunde oneureun banjjak banjjakhan geot gatayo.
examples.en: It rained yesterday, but today it seems to be sparkling.

examples.kr: 밖에 사람들이 없는 것 같아요. 모두 어디로 갔는지 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Bakke saramdeuli eomneun geot gatayo. Modu eodiro gassneunji moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: It seems like there's no one outside. I don't know where everyone has gone.

title: ~커녕 [keonyeong] (Let alone, far from)
short_explanation: Used to express an idea contrary to expectation; 'let alone', 'far from'.
long_explanation: '~커녕 [keonyeong]' is a connector used in Korean to indicate that a certain expectation is not met—in fact, the reality is far from that expectation. It is often translated as 'let alone' or 'far from' in English and is used when one thing is not done, let alone something even more unlikely or difficult.

examples.kr: 지영이는 한국어를 통해 간단한 대화를 나누는 것 커녕, '안녕하세요' 정도밖에 하지 못해요.
examples.romaji: Jiyeongineun hangugeo-reul tonghae gandanhan daehwareul nanuneun geot keonyeong, 'annyeonghaseyo' jeongdo bakke haji mot haeyo.
examples.en: Far from having a simple conversation in Korean, Jiyoung can barely say 'hello'.

examples.kr: 나는 주말에 책을 읽을 시간이 있다 커녕, 집안일에 치여서 어려워요.
examples.romaji: Naneun jumare chaekeul ilgeul sigani itda keonyeong, jibanire chiyeoseo eoryeowoyo.
examples.en: Far from having time to read a book on the weekend, I'm overwhelmed by housework.

examples.kr: 성진이는 시험 공부를 마치고 잔다 커녕, 게임을 하다가 밤새우기도 해요.
examples.romaji: Seongjineun siheom gongbureul machigo janda keonyeong, geimeul hadaga bamsaeugido haeyo.
examples.en: Far from going to sleep after studying for the exam, Seongjin often stays up all night playing games.

examples.kr: 그녀는 살을 빼려는 것 커녕, 매일 밤마다 간식을 먹어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun sareul bbaeryeoneun geot keonyeong, maeil bammada gansigeul meogeoyo.
examples.en: Far from trying to lose weight, she eats snacks every night.

title: ~게 되다 [ge gatda] (Become, end up)
short_explanation: Means 'to become' or 'to end up' and is used to express the result of a change or transformation.
long_explanation: The construction '~게 되다' is used in Korean to indicate the end result of a change or transformation, often due to certain circumstances beyond the speaker's control. It is comparable to saying 'to become', 'to get', or 'to end up' in English.
formation: Verb or adjective stem + 게 되다

examples.kr: 어제 친구들과 멀리서 축구를 했는데, 너무 피곤해져서 지금은 잠밖에 잘 수 없겠어요.
examples.romaji: Eoje chingudeulgwa meolliseo chuggureul haenneunde, neomu pigonhaejyeoseo jigeumeun jambakke jal su eopgesseoyo.
examples.en: I played soccer with my friends yesterday and became so tired that now I think I can only sleep.

examples.kr: 그는 열심히 공부해서 성공적으로 비즈니스맨이 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun yeolsimhi gongbuhaseo seonggongjeok-euro bijeuniseumani doeosseoyo.
examples.en: He studied hard and successfully became a businessman.

examples.kr: 그 책을 읽고 나서 고뇌에 빠지게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Geu chaegeul ikgo naseo gonoe-e ppajige doeosseoyo.
examples.en: After reading that book, I ended up falling into deep distress.

examples.kr: 긴 시간 동안 추위에 노출되어 우리의 건강이 나빠지게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Gin sigan dongan chuwie nochuldoeeo uriui geongangi nappajige doeosseoyo.
examples.en: We were exposed to the cold for so long that our health ended up deteriorating.

title: ~게 하다 [ge hada] (Make)
short_explanation: Used to express causing someone or something to be in a certain state.
long_explanation: '~게 하다' is a grammatical construction in Korean that means to make or cause someone or something to be in a particular state. It is used with descriptive verbs (or adjectives) to indicate a change in state. This is similar to the English verb 'make' or the phrase 'cause to be.'
formation: Descriptive verb (or adjective) stem + 하게 하다

examples.kr: 그녀는 저를 행복하게 해요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun jeoreul haengbokhage haeyo.
examples.en: She makes me happy.

examples.kr: 셰프가 이 감자 스프를 맛있게 해요.
examples.romaji: Syepeuga i gamja seupeureul masitge haeyo.
examples.en: The chef makes this potato soup taste delicious.

examples.kr: 엄마가 저를 준비하게 했기 때문에, 시험에 통과할 수 있었어요.
examples.romaji: Eommaga jeoreul junbi hage haetgi ttaemune, siheome tonggwahal su isseosseoyo.
examples.en: Because my mom made me prepare, I was able to pass the exam.

examples.kr: 교수님이 저를 집중하게 했기 때문에, 저는 모든 정보를 기억할 수 있었습니다.
examples.romaji: Gyosunimi jeoreul jipjunghage haetgi ttaemune, jeoneun modeun jeongboreul gieokhal su isseotseumnida.
examples.en: Because the professor made me focus, I was able to remember all the information.

title: ~게 하다 [ge hada] (To make someone do something)
short_explanation: Used to indicate causing someone or something to perform an action.
long_explanation: '~게 하다' is used to express the act of making or causing someone to do something. It is typically used with nouns or action verb stems to show that one party induces or forces another to take an action. This is similar to saying 'make (someone) do' in English.

examples.kr: 여자친구가 커피를 좋아하니까, 매일 아침 커피를 마시게 했어요.
examples.romaji: Yeojachinguga keopireul joahnikka, maeil achim keopireul masike haesseoyo.
examples.en: Because my girlfriend likes coffee, I made her drink coffee every morning.

examples.kr: 부모님이 학벌이 중요하다고 생각해서, 아이들을 혼자 공부하게 했어요.
examples.romaji: Bumonimi hakbeoli jungyohadago saenggakhaeseo, aideureul honja gongbuhage haesseoyo.
examples.en: Because the parents think that education is important, they made their children study alone.

examples.kr: 친구가 해외여행을 하고 싶어서, 저는 그를 도와 비행기표를 예약하게 했습니다.
examples.romaji: Chinguga haeoeyeohaeng-eul hago sip-eoseo, jeoneun geureul dowahwa bihaenggipyo-reul yeyaghage haesseumnida.
examples.en: Because my friend wanted to travel abroad, I helped him make a reservation for an airline ticket.

examples.kr: 선생님이 학생들을 일찍 일어나게 했어요.
examples.romaji: Seonsaengnimi haksaengdeureul iljjik ireonage haesseoyo.
examples.en: The teacher made the students wake up early.

title: ~키가 크다/작다 [kiga keuda/jakda] (To be tall/short)
short_explanation: Expressions used to describe a person’s height, literally meaning 'big in size' (tall) and 'small in size' (short).
long_explanation: '키가 크다 [kiga keuda]' and '키가 작다 [kiga jakda]' are simple expressions in Korean used to indicate the height of a person. '키가 크다' describes someone as tall, while '키가 작다' indicates someone is short. These expressions directly refer to physical characteristics, specifically height.

examples.kr: 우리 학교에서 제일 키가 큰 사람은 우리 반의 철수야.
examples.romaji: Uri hakgyoeseo jeil kiga keun saram-eun uri banui Cheolsu-ya.
examples.en: The tallest person in our school is Cheolsu from our class.

examples.kr: 그녀는 키가 커서 모델처럼 보여요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun kiga keoseo modelcheoreom boyeoyo.
examples.en: She is tall, so she looks like a model.

examples.kr: 나는 키가 작아서 아직도 어린이 좌석을 이용할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun kiga jakaseo ajikdo eorini jwaseogeul iyonghal su isseoyo.
examples.en: I am short, so I can still use the children's seat.

examples.kr: 그는 키가 작아도 그의 인간성은 큰 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun kiga jakado geuui inganseong-eun keun geot gatayo.
examples.en: Even though he is short, his character seems big.

title: ~키로 [kiro] (By means of, with)
short_explanation: Used to express the method, means, or instrument by which an action is performed.
long_explanation: '~키로' is a grammatical marker in Korean that indicates the tool, means, or method by which an action is carried out. It is similar to the English phrases 'by means of' or 'with' and provides additional information about how something is done.

examples.kr: 저는 매일 아침 한 번 피아노를 치기로 해서 음악 실력을 향상시켰습니다.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun maeil achim han beon pianoreul chikiro haeseo eumak silryeogeul hyangsangshyeotseumnida.
examples.en: I decided to play the piano once every morning to improve my musical skills.

examples.kr: 우리는 이 사건을 해결하기 위해 대화하기로 결정했습니다.
examples.romaji: Urineun i sageoneul haegyeolhagi wihae daehwagikiro gyeoljeonghaetseumnida.
examples.en: We decided to resolve this issue by means of conversation.

examples.kr: 그녀는 매주 월요일 글을 쓰기로 시작해서 글쓰기 실력을 키웠습니다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun maeju woryoil geuleul sseugikiro sijakhaeseo geulsseugi silryeogeul kiwotseumnida.
examples.en: She began writing every Monday, thereby improving her writing skills.

examples.kr: 난 작년부터 매일 운동하기로 했고, 건강이 크게 개선되었습니다.
examples.romaji: Nan jaknyeonbuteo maeil undonghagikiro haetgo, geongangi keuge gaeseondwoetseumnida.
examples.en: I decided to exercise daily from last year, and my health has greatly improved.

title: ~타다 [tada] (To take, ride)
short_explanation: Used to express the action of taking or riding a mode of transportation.
long_explanation: '~타다' is a verb used in Korean to indicate the action of taking or riding transportation (such as a bus, train, taxi, or bicycle) or using mechanical/electronic devices. It is typically attached to a noun that indicates the type of transport or device.
formation: Noun indicating transport or mechanical device + ~타다

examples.kr: 저는 일주일에 비행기를 두 번 타다 보니까 비행기에 익숙해진 것 같아요. 아무래도 직장이 멀어서 비행기를 종종 타야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun iljuile bihaenggireul du beon tada bomyeon, bihaenggie igsukhajin geot gatayo. Amuraedo jikjangi meolseo bihaenggireul jongjong taya hamnida.
examples.en: Since I take a plane twice a week, I think I have become familiar with flying. Because my workplace is far, I often have to take planes.

examples.kr: 아무래도 자전거를 타다 보면 체력도 좋아지고, 건강에도 좋으니까 자전거를 자주 타보세요. 그리고 자전거를 타는 것이 운동으로도 좋습니다.
examples.romaji: Amuraedo jajeongeoreul tada bomyeon cheryeokdo joajigo, geongaedo joheunikka jajeongeoreul jaju taboseyo. Geurigo jajeongeoreul taneun geosi undongeurodo joheumnida.
examples.en: Riding a bicycle improves your stamina and is good for your health, so try riding one often. Also, riding a bicycle is excellent exercise.

examples.kr: 택시를 이렇게 자주 타다 보면 돈이 많이 드는 것 같아요. 그러니까 가능하면 지하철을 타거나 도보로 가시는 것이 좋을 것 같습니다.
examples.romaji: Taeksireul ireohge jaju tada bomyeon doni manhi deuneun geot gatayo. Geureonikka ganeunghamyeon jihacheoreul tageona doboreo gasineun geosi joheul geot gatseumnida.
examples.en: If you take a taxi this often, it seems like it costs a lot. So, if possible, it would be better to take the subway or walk.

examples.kr: 이렇게 늦은 밤에 버스에 혼자 타다 보면 아무래도 좀 불안하겠죠? 그러니 이런 늦은 시간에는 가능하면 택시를 타는 것이 더 좋아요.
examples.romaji: Ireohge neutun bame beoseue honja tada bomyeon amuraedo jom buranhagessjyo? Geureoni ireon neutun sigueneun ganeunghamyeon taeksireul taneun geosi deo joayo.
examples.en: If you ride a bus alone this late at night, it probably feels a bit unsafe. So at such a late hour, it’s better to take a taxi if possible.

title: ~테니까 [tenikka] (Because)
short_explanation: Used to explain the reason or cause of an action or state.
long_explanation: The form '~테니까' is used in Korean to express 'because.' It clarifies the reason for a situation, behavior, or outcome. The clause before '~테니까' usually contains known or unimportant information, while the important or new information follows. This pattern emphasizes a strong cause–effect relationship compared to the simpler '~서' pattern.

examples.kr: 밖이 추우니까 옷을 더 입고 가세요.
examples.romaji: Bakk-i chuuni-kka ot-eul deo ibgo gaseyo.
examples.en: Because it's cold outside, wear more clothes.

examples.kr: 너무 늦게 잤으니까 아침에 일어나기 힘들었어요.
examples.romaji: Neomu neutge jasseuni-kka achim-e ireonagi himdeureosseoyo.
examples.en: Because I slept too late, it was hard to get up in the morning.

examples.kr: 서울에서 살고 있으니까 가끔 한강에 산책하러 가요.
examples.romaji: Seoureseo salgo isseuni-kka gakkeum Hangang-e sanchaekhareo gayo.
examples.en: Because I live in Seoul, I occasionally go for a walk by the Han River.

examples.kr: 한국어 공부가 즐거우니까 매일 열심히 공부하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Hangugeo gongbuga jeulgeounikka maeil yeolsimhi gongbuhago isseoyo.
examples.en: Because studying Korean is enjoyable, I study hard every day.

title: ~토록 [torok] (So that, to the extent that)
short_explanation: Used to express 'so that' or 'to the extent that'.
long_explanation: '~토록' is a postposition used to indicate a degree or condition that compels a certain result or action. It is synonymous with 'so that' or 'to the extent that' in English and is often used to emphasize a high degree or strong cause–effect relationship.

examples.kr: 그는 프로젝트를 성공시키고 싶어서, 자신의 건강까지 희생하토록 노력했어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun peurojegteureul seonggongsikigo sip-eoseo, jasinui geongangkkaji huisaenghatorok noryeokhaesseoyo.
examples.en: He wanted the project to succeed so much that he worked hard to the extent of sacrificing even his health.

examples.kr: 그녀는 회사에 늦지 않토록, 일찍 일어나기로 결정했어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun hoesa-e neotji antorok, iljjik ireonagiro gyeoljeonghaesseoyo.
examples.en: She loves her company so much that she decided to wake up early so as not to be late.

examples.kr: 인구가 심각하게 증가해서, 여기서 살 자리가 줄어들토록 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Inguga simgakage jeungaheseo, yeogiseo sal jariga jur-eodeultorok doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: The population increased so dramatically that the available living space here was reduced.

examples.kr: 가난이 심해져서, 밥 한 그릇도 먹기 어려우토록 힘들었어요.
examples.romaji: Ganani simhaejyeoseo, bab han geureutdo meoggi eoryeoutorok himdeureosseoyo.
examples.en: Poverty was so severe that it became difficult to even eat a bowl of rice.

title: ~하게 되다 [hage dweda] (End up doing)
short_explanation: Used to express that something happens as a result of circumstances, often beyond one’s control.
long_explanation: '~하게 되다' is a verb ending in Korean that indicates an action or state that comes about unexpectedly or unintentionally as a result of circumstances. It often implies that the result was not planned and may evoke a sense of surprise or resignation.

examples.kr: 그렇게 많은 숙제가 쌓여서 나는 결국 주말 내내 숙제를 하게 되었어.
examples.romaji: Geureohge manheun sukmjaega ssahyeoseo naneun gyeolguk jumal naenae sukmjaereul hage doeeosseeo.
examples.en: So much homework piled up that I ended up doing homework all weekend.

examples.kr: 보통은 말하지 않겠지만, 어제는 상황이 그래서 너에게 모든 걸 말하게 되었어.
examples.romaji: Botong-eun malhaji anhgetjiman, eoje-neun sanghwang-i geuraeseo neo-ege modeun geol malhage doeeosseeo.
examples.en: Normally I wouldn't say it, but yesterday the situation was such that I ended up telling you everything.

examples.kr: 처음에는 운동하기 싫었지만, 친구가 자꾸 권해서 헬스클럽 회원이 되게 되었어.
examples.romaji: Cheoeum-eneun undonghagi silh-eossejiman, chinguga jakku gwonhaeseo hellseukeulleob hwe-won-i doegae doeeosseeo.
examples.en: At first, I didn't want to exercise, but my friend kept encouraging me, so I ended up becoming a health club member.

examples.kr: 시험을 공부하려고 했는데, 재미있는 드라마를 보게 되었어.
examples.romaji: Siheom-eul gongbuharyeogo haessneunde, jaemiissneun deurama-reul boga doeeosseeo.
examples.en: I was going to study for the exam, but I ended up watching an interesting drama.

title: ~하고 있다 [hago itda] (Is doing)
short_explanation: Used to describe a continuous or ongoing action.
long_explanation: '~하고 있다' is a grammar pattern used in Korean to express an ongoing action or a state that continues to exist. It is equivalent to the English 'is doing' or 'am/are doing'. This form focuses on the progression of the action, not on its result or completion.

examples.kr: 요즘 한국어를 배우고 있어요, 그래서 아직 완벽하게 말할 수는 없어요.
examples.romaji: Yojeum hangugeoreul baeugo isseoyo, geuraeseo ajik wanbyeokhage malhal suneun eopseoyo.
examples.en: I am learning Korean these days, so I cannot speak it perfectly yet.

examples.kr: 지금 점심을 먹고 있어요, 바쁜 하루 중에 잠시 쉬는 시간이에요.
examples.romaji: Jigeum jeomsimeul meokgo isseoyo, bappun haru junge jamsi swineun siganieyo.
examples.en: I am eating lunch now; it's a short break during a busy day.

examples.kr: 어머니는 저녁 요리를 준비하고 있어요, 맛있는 음식을 기대하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Eomeonineun jeonyeok yorireul junbihago isseoyo, masitneun eumsigeul gidaehago isseoyo.
examples.en: My mother is preparing dinner, and I am looking forward to delicious food.

examples.kr: 우리 강아지는 밖에서 산책하고 있어요, 이렇게 해서 운동을 통해 건강을 유지하죠.
examples.romaji: Uri gangajineun bakkeseo sancaekhago isseoyo, ireohge haeseo undongeul tonghae geongangeul yujijyo.
examples.en: Our puppy is taking a walk outside; in doing so, it keeps healthy through exercise.

title: ~하고 나서 [hago naseo] (After doing)
short_explanation: Used to express sequence of actions; 'after doing'.
long_explanation: '~하고 나서 [hago naseo]' is a sentence pattern in Korean that means 'after doing something'. It is used to indicate that one action is completed before the next action takes place. The sequence is crucial, as the latter action happens only after the first is finished.

examples.kr: 공부하고 나서 놀러 갈 거예요, 그래서 시간을 잘 관리해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Gongbuhago naseo nolreo gal geoyeyo, geuraeseo siganeul jal gwanrihaeya haeyo.
examples.en: I will go out to play after studying, so I have to manage my time well.

examples.kr: 아침 식사를 하고 나서 운동을 합니다, 그렇게 하면 하루를 활기차게 시작할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Achim sikshareul hago naseo undongeul hamnida, geureohge hamyeon harureul hwalgichage sijakhal su isseoyo.
examples.en: I exercise after having breakfast; by doing so, I can start the day energetically.

examples.kr: 숙제를 다 하고 나서 친구들과 영화를 봤어요, 그래서 즐거운 시간을 보냈습니다.
examples.romaji: Sukjereul da hago naseo chingudeulgwa yeonghwaleul bwasseoyo, geuraeseo jeulgeoun siganeul bonaessseubnida.
examples.en: I watched a movie with friends after finishing all my homework, so we had a good time.

examples.kr: 회의를 마치고 나서 점심을 먹었어요, 그런데 배가 너무 고파서 힘들었어요.
examples.romaji: Hoeireul machigo naseo jeomsimeul meogeosseoyo, geureonde baega neomu gopaseo himdeureosseoyo.
examples.en: I had lunch after finishing the meeting, but it was hard because I was so hungry.

title: ~하고 싶다 [hago sipda] (Want to do)
short_explanation: Expresses a desire to perform a certain action.
long_explanation: '~하고 싶다 [hago sipda]' is a verb ending in Korean that indicates the speaker's desire or wish to perform a certain action. It is equivalent to 'want to do something' in English and is commonly used to express personal wishes or plans.

examples.kr: 저는 한국어를 유창하게 말하고 싶어요, 그래서 매일 열심히 공부하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangug-eoreul yuchanghage malhago sip-eoyo, geuraeseo maeil yeolsimhi gongbuhago isseoyo.
examples.en: I want to speak Korean fluently, so I'm studying hard every day.

examples.kr: 내가 가장 좋아하는 가수의 콘서트에 가고 싶어요, 하지만 티켓을 구하기가 어려워요.
examples.romaji: Naega gajang joahaneun gasuui konseoteue gago sip-eoyo, hajiman tikeseul guhagiga eolyeowoyo.
examples.en: I want to go to my favorite singer's concert, but it's hard to get tickets.

examples.kr: 나는 운동을 많이 하고 싶지만, 너무 바빠서 시간이 없어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun undong-eul mani hago sipjiman, neomu bappaseo sigan-i eobs-eoyo.
examples.en: I want to exercise a lot, but I'm too busy and don't have time.

examples.kr: 요리를 배우고 싶어요, 그래서 요리 수업에 등록을 생각하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Yorireul baeugo sip-eoyo, geuraeseo yori sueobe deungrogeul saenggaghago isseoyo.
examples.en: I want to learn cooking, so I am thinking of registering for a cooking class.

title: ~하기로 하다 [hakiro hada] (Decide to do)
short_explanation: Used to indicate that a decision about doing something has been made.
long_explanation: '하기로 하다' is used when you want to express that a decision to do something has been made. It can be a personal decision or a mutual decision made by a group. It translates to 'decide to do' in English, with the action indicated by the attached verb.

examples.kr: 우리는 휴가를 가기로 결정했습니다. 주말에 휴식을 취하러 해변에 가기로 했어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun hyugareul gagiro gyeoljeonghaessseubnida. Jumalen hyusigeul chwihareo haebyeone gagiro haess-eoyo.
examples.en: We decided to go on vacation. We decided to go to the beach for a rest on the weekend.

examples.kr: 나는 영화를 보기로 결정했어. 오늘 밤에 집에서 미드를 보기로 했어.
examples.romaji: Naneun yeonghwareul bogiro gyeoljeonghaesseo. Oneul bam-e jib-eseo mideureul bogilo haesseo.
examples.en: I decided to watch a movie. I decided to watch a drama at home tonight.

examples.kr: 그녀는 한국어를 배우기로 결정했습니다. 그녀는 올해 한국어 수업을 듣기로 했습니다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun hangugeoreul baeugiro gyeoljeonghaessseubnida. Geunyeoneun olhae hangugeo sueobeul deutgiro haessseubnida.
examples.en: She decided to learn Korean. She decided to take Korean lessons this year.

examples.kr: 회사는 직원들에게 보너스를 주기로 결정했다. 고용주들은 내년에 직원들에게 연봉 인상을 주기로 결정했다.
examples.romaji: Hoesaneun jikweondeul-ege bonuseu-reul jugiro gyeoljeonghaessda. Goyongjudeul-eun naenyeon-e jikwon-deul-ege yeonbong insang-eul jugiro gyeoljeonghaessda.
examples.en: The company decided to give the employees a bonus. Employers decided to give employees a raise next year.

title: ~하기는 하다 [hakineun hada] (Do to some extent)
short_explanation: Used to admit that something is done to some degree, but not fully or enthusiastically.
long_explanation: ~하기는 하다 is a Korean grammar point used when someone does do something, but not completely, regularly, or with enthusiasm. It shows that an action occurs but implies some limit or deficiency in how ideally it is done.

examples.kr: 나는 요리하기는 하는데 맛있게 하는 건 아니예요.
examples.romaji: Naneun yorihagineun haneunde masitge haneun geon aniyeyo.
examples.en: I do cook, but it's not that I cook deliciously.

examples.kr: 그는 운전하기는 하는데 안전하게는 운전하지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun unjeonhagineun haneunde anjeonhage-neun unjeonhaji anhayo.
examples.en: He does drive, but he does not drive safely.

examples.kr: 어머니는 영어를 이해하기는 하지만 말하기는 좀 힘들어하세요.
examples.romaji: Eomeonineun yeongeoreul ihaehagineun hajiman malhagineun jom himdeureohaseyo.
examples.en: My mother does understand English, but she finds speaking it somewhat difficult.

examples.kr: 나는 운동하기는 하는데 정기적으로 하지는 않아요.
examples.romaji: Naneun undonghagineun haneunde jeongigjeogeuro hajineun anhayo.
examples.en: I do exercise, but I don't do it regularly.

title: ~하기보다 [hakiboda] (Rather than doing)
short_explanation: Used to express preference or a better option; 'rather than'.
long_explanation: '~하기보다' is a grammar point used to indicate that one option is preferred over another. It is equivalent to 'rather than' in English and compares two alternatives to express the speaker's preference.

examples.kr: 강아지를 사 주는 것보다 입양하는 것을 추천드려요.
examples.romaji: Gangajireul sa juneun geosboda ibyanghaneun geoseul chucheon deuryeoyo.
examples.en: I recommend adopting a puppy rather than buying one.

examples.kr: 택시를 타기보다는 버스를 타는 게 더 싸요.
examples.romaji: Taeksireul tagibodaneun beoseureul taneun ge deo ssayo.
examples.en: It's cheaper to take the bus rather than a taxi.

examples.kr: 많이 먹기보다는 품질 좋은 음식을 먹는 것이 더 중요해요.
examples.romaji: Mani meokgibodaneun pumjil joheun eumsigeul meokneun geosi deo jungyohaeyo.
examples.en: It's more important to eat good quality food rather than just eating a lot.

examples.kr: 친구에게 거짓말하기보다는 진실을 말하는 것이 낫다고 생각해요.
examples.romaji: Chinguege geojismalhagibodaneun jinsireul malhaneun geosi nasdagosaenggakhaeyo.
examples.en: I think it's better to tell the truth to a friend rather than lie.

title: ~하나 [hana] (But, however)
short_explanation: Used to express contrast or contradiction, similar to 'but' or 'however' in English.
long_explanation: '~하나' is a conjunction often used in Korean to indicate a contrast or contradiction between two ideas or situations. It introduces a contrary point of view or an exception to a previous statement, much like 'but' or 'however' in English.

examples.kr: 나는 그 일을 마친 줄 알았는데, 하나 사람들은 아직 끝내지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun geu ireul machin jul aratneunde, hana saramdeureun ajik kkeutnaeji anatseoyo.
examples.en: I thought I had finished the work; however, the people had not finished it yet.

examples.kr: 그녀는 예쁜 것 같아요. 하나, 성격이 너무 나빠요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun yeppeun geot gatayo. Hana, seonggyeogi neomu nappayo.
examples.en: She seems pretty, but her personality is very bad.

examples.kr: 이것은 어렵게 느껴질 수 있으나, 하나 연습하면 쉬워질 거예요.
examples.romaji: Igeoseun eoryeopge neukkyeojil su isseuna, hana yeonseubhamyeon swiweojil geoyeyo.
examples.en: This might seem difficult, however, it will become easier with practice.

examples.kr: 우리는 집에 돌아가야 하는데, 하나 차가 없어서 걸어야 했어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun jibe doragaya haneunde, hana chaga eopseoseo georeoya haesseoyo.
examples.en: We needed to go home, but we had no car so we had to walk.

title: ~하면 할수록 [hamyeon halsurok] (The more... the more)
short_explanation: Used to express a proportional increase or decrease; 'the more... the more'.
long_explanation: '~하면 할수록' is a grammar structure used in Korean to illustrate that as one action or state increases (or decreases), another does so in proportion. It is similar to the English expression 'the more... the more'.

examples.kr: 저는 한국어를 공부하면 할수록 더 재미있어지는 것 같아요, 한국의 문화와 역사를 더 이해할 수 있게 되니까.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangugeoreul gongbuhamyeon halsurok deo jaemiisseojineun geot gatayo, hangukui munhwa wa yeoksareul deo ihaehal su itge doenikka.
examples.en: The more I study Korean, the more fun it becomes, as I gain a deeper understanding of Korean culture and history.

examples.kr: 이 집안에서 책을 읽으면 읽을수록 더 많은 지식을 얻을 수 있어서 저는 항상 책을 읽는 것을 즐깁니다.
examples.romaji: I jiban-eseo chaeg-eul ilgeumyeon ilgeulsurok deo manh-eun jisig-eul eod-eul su iss-eoseo jeoneun hangsang chaeg-eul ilgneun geos-eul jeulgibnida.
examples.en: The more I read books in this house, the more knowledge I gain, which is why I always enjoy reading.

examples.kr: 요리를 하면 할수록 자신감이 더 생긴다, 그래서 나는 항상 새로운 레시피를 시도해본다.
examples.romaji: Yorireul hamyeon halsurok jasin-gam-i deo saeng-ginda, geulaeseo naneun hangsang saeloun lesipileul sidohae-bonda.
examples.en: The more I cook, the more confident I become, so I always try new recipes.

examples.kr: 그녀와 함께 시간을 보내면 볼수록 그녀를 더 사랑하게 되는 거 같아요, 그녀의 성격이 정말 매력적이니까요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeo-wa hamkke sigan-eul bonae-myeon bolsurok geunyeo-reul deo salang-hage doeneun geo gat-ayo, geunyeoui seonggyeog-i jeongmal maelyeogjeog-inikka-yo.
examples.en: The more time I spend with her, the more I fall in love with her, because her personality is truly charming.
